PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Disarmament
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
Nuclear Disarmament
To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That your petitioners are concerned about foreign owned military bases on Australian territory and the entry into Australian waters and territory of foreign warships and aircraft carrying nuclear weaponry. And that the Australian Government should take an active and constructive role in the promotion of a nuclear-free world. You petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should:
1. Promote the expression of Australian sovereignty by legislating to bring foreign military bases on Australian territory under the control of the Australian Government.

2. Make it compulsory that the disclosure of weaponry carried by foreign warships and aircraft be given in confidence to the Australian Government prior to a request for entry. And that foreign warships and aircraft that carry nuclear weaponry be banned from Australian waters and territory.
3. Legislate for the cessation of all uranium mining in Australia and its subsequent export.

4. Urge the Government of the Commonealth of Australia to pose to the Governments of the United States and the Soviet Union that both countries agree to immediately halt the testing, production and further deployment of all nuclear weapons, missiles and delivery systems in a way that can be checked and verified by both sides.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Excise on Grape Spirit
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the 1983 Budget imposition of the excise on grape spirit used in fortifying wine places at risk the future of the fortified wine industry in Australia.
That the requirement to pay the excise within 7 days of the fortification occurring is inequitable.
That the excise will be reflected in increased costs to the consumers of fortified wines of up to 100 per cent and consumer choice will be restricted.
That this will cause reduced fortified wine sales which will result in reduced intake of grapes from grapegrowers.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government will reconsider their previous decision and either withdraw this tax or modify its method of application and collection.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Lewis (from 131 citizens) and Messner (from 223 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Mr Mart Niklus
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

(1) That we are deeply concerned for the well-being of Mr Mart Niklus, a leading Estonian and Baltic human rights activist who is in ill health and imprisoned in solitary confinement in Perm Labour Camp No. 389/36 in Siberia.
(2) That Mr Mart Niklus has been imprisoned as a 'prisoner of conscience' for the non-violent exercise of his beliefs and is denied visiting and communication rights.

(3) That the Australian Government give its support to any initiative in this case by Amnesty International which has adopted Mr Mart Niklus. Amnesty International believes he has committed no real crime and has never used or advocated the use of violence.
(4) That we urge the Australian Government to make representations to the Government of the Soviet Union to promptly release Mr Mart Niklus and grant him a passport and exit visa.
(5) That in its representations to the Government of the Soviet Union advise that the Australian Government has approved the sponsored entry of Mr Mart Niklus into Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I make this personal explanation as Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. Last night on the PM and Nationwide programs on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, Mrs Babette Francis, in the course of a vigorous exchange on the Sex Discrimination Bill, used the report of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee on that Bill as part of her argument. Naturally, neither I nor the Committee have any objection to that. In fact, we are pleased when any such report is used to foster community discussion of legislative proposals which are before this Parliament. But I think the report has been construed to do more than it set out to do. I should like to offer some clarification.

SPEECH.PARA: The first thing for clarification ought to be the composition of the Committee. Mrs Francis said that the Committee had a majority of Australian Labor Party members, at least to her belief. In fact, it does not have a majority of Labor members. It is, as is appropriate to its function, comprised in a way which does not allow any particular party to have a majority. In fact, the composition of the Committee at the time of the preparation of the report on the Sex Discrimination Bill was Senator Tate as Chairman, Senator Alan Missen as Deputy Chairman, Senator Nick Bolkus, Senator Rosemary Crowley, Senator the Hon. Peter Durack and Senator Janine Haines.

A true appreciation of the function of the Committee and an examination of its report on the Sex Discrimination Bill would not entitle one to say, as Mrs Francis said, that the Committee referred to this Bill as a threat to civil liberties. The Committee's role or task is to alert senators to particular clauses in any Bill coming into this chamber for debate where arguably there might be some clash between a particular provision and certain civil liberties criteria. Several such clauses of the Sex Discrimination Bill were identified by the Committee. Using language appropriate to alerting senators to the possibility of a clash, we outlined some misgivings. No definitive conclusion or recommendation concerning any of these particular clauses was made. Certainly it would be quite wrong to draw any inference as to the Committee's assessment of the Bill as a whole. Any thorough-going condemnation or commendation of a Bill would be quite alien to our purpose.

Unlike some Bills which are given hasty passage through the Parliament, this Bill has been exposed for public comment over several months. It was in that spirit that the Scrutiny of Bills Committee offered its comments and expects a response from the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women (Senator Ryan).

DEBATE.TITLE: CONSTITUTION ALTERATION (SIMULTANEOUS ELECTIONS) BILL 1983CONSTITUTION ALTERATION (PARLIAMENTARY TERMS) BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motions (by Senator Gareth Evans) agreed to:
That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to alter the Constitution so as to ensure that Senate elections and House of Representatives elections are held at the same time.
That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to alter the Constitution to extend the duration of the House of Representatives and the terms of service of senators.
Bills presented.
Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans) agreed to:

That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the questions with regard to the several stages for the passage through the Senate of the Bills being put in one motion at each stage, and the consideration of such bills together in Committee of the Whole.
Bills read a first time.
Standing Orders suspended.
Second Readings

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.
INTRODUCTION

These two Bills will give effect to proposed changes to the Constitution endorsed by the Australian Constitutional Convention at its meeting in Adelaide earlier this year. The first will alter the Constitution to provide for the holding of simultaneous elections for the House of Representatives and half the Senate. The second provides for four-year terms for the House of Representatives . They are proposed in substitution for the Constitution Alteration (Fixed Term Parliaments) Bill which I introduced into the Senate on 12 May 1983. Since that Bill was introduced, the Government has given further consideration to the package of referendum proposals designed to streamline and modernise the machinery of the Australian Government which it believes should be put to referendum early in 1984. Without resiling in any way from the view that the fixed term Parliament proposal would have important benefits as an acceptable solution to some of our more intransigent constitutional problems, the Government has come to the view that it is preferable that the proposals relating to parliamentary terms which were endorsed at the Adelaide meeting of the Constitutional Convention should be put to the people. There has been no consensus in favour of the fixed term proposal but, by contrast, the proposals for simultaneous elections and four-year terms have both previously attracted strong support from the present Opposition. The most unequivocal recent declaration of that support was the announcement by the former Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, on 7 February that, if re-elected, his Government would itself put both of them to referendum as soon as possible.

Although the two proposals are more modest in their concept and scope than the fixed term proposal, they would significantly improve the operation of government by creating the conditions for fewer elections, better long term planning and a more rational political climate generally. There is no doubt that the present electoral arrangements have resulted in Australia being plagued with too frequent elections. The average term of Parliaments post-war has been two years five months, and in the 14-year period from 1963 to 1977 there were no fewer than 10 separate national elections. There has been increasing community dissatisfaction about the lack of sufficient continuity and stability in government, with a resultant atmosphere of uncertainty and controversy and strong pressure on governments to adopt short term expedient policies to ensure electoral success. There has been greater recognition of the need for governments to have sufficient time betwen elections to develop new policy proposals, to put them into operation and to assess their results. Particularly in the area of economic management, measures can take several years to develop and to implement fully. Moreover, governments which must face frequent elections are at a disadvantage when proper economic management calls for the implementation of initially unpopular measures, the beneficial result of which may take some time to emerge.

Frequent elections not only have an adverse effect upon government planning; they also adversely affect private sector planning and business confidence, which would benefit from stability of government and more continuity in government programs. And, not least, there would be less cost and less inconvenience to the electorate if there were fewer elections. Both of the measures now proposed will contribute to the desirable aim of a more rational system of national government. The simultaneous holding of elections for the House of Representatives and half the Senate will avoid the need for separate elections. Apart from the special circumstances of the double dissolutions in 1974 and 1975, elections for the Senate and the House of Representatives have been out of phase for the greater part of the last 20 years. They are again out of phase following the double dissolution election earlier this year.

The move to simultaneous elections will ensure that the composition of the Senate at any given time more accurately reflects the current wishes of the people. It will also provide greater accountability of the Senate to the extent that senators themselves will have to face the people if the Senate forces a premature House of Representatives election. But the proposal does not otherwise affect the powers of the Senate, which will retain all of its present power to review, amend or reject legislation. The lengthening of the term of the House of Representatives to four years is consistent with the terms of the lower Houses in New South Wales, Tasmania and the Northern Territory and with developments in other States. Two Bills, one Government sponsored and one Opposition sponsored, providing for four year terms are now before the Victorian Parliament. It is also in line with international standards. A study made in 1974 by the Inter- Parliamentary Union of the duration of the lower Houses in 56 countries showed that in 24 there was a five-year term, in 25 a four-year term, with Australia being one of only four countries with a three-year term.

The four-year term proposal will preserve the existing discretion of the Prime Minister to call an earlier election. Nevertheless, the change will provide greater continuity and stability in the electoral cycle, since the average length of parliaments may be expected to increase substantially. The present three-year election cycle, in which-for governments of any colour-the first year tends to be taken up with planning and with implementing immediate election promises and the third year with electioneering, does not allow sufficient room for the development and implementation of programs. Increasingly, new programs call for capital expenditure, particularly in the installation of equipment such as computers, which cannot be accomplished quickly, and more time is required for this to be put in place and the program to be operating for its benefits to be assessed by the electorate at the next election.

Although both the simultaneous elections and the four-year term proposals are directed to eliminating the undue frequency of elections the Government believes that the electorate should be given an opportunity to vote separately on each of the proposals. For that reason we put them forward as separate proposals, but we do of course believe that adoption of both proposals is desirable. I turn now to consider each of the proposals in more detail.
SIMULTANEOUS ELECTIONS BILL

This Bill provides for half-Senate elections to be held at the same time as elections for the House of Representatives whenever those elections may occur. The proposal in the Bill is substantially the same as the one submitted to referendum by the Whitlam Government in 1974 and by the Fraser Government in 1977. In 1977 the proposal only narrowly failed to obtain the required support, when it achieved fully 62.2 per cent of the national vote. It was clearly passed in New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia and was supported by 48.5 per cent of the voters in Western Australia and 47.5 per cent in Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many in Tasmania?

—I readily concede, Senator Harradine, there were not all that many in Tasmania. No doubt you will have another opportunity to demonstrate that once again. The Bill proposes a re-writing of section 13 of the Constitution to provide for senators to hold office normally for two terms of the House of Representatives instead of for six years as at present. This will, of course, be subject to any earlier double dissolution of both Houses that might take place under section 57 of the Constitution.

SPEECH.PARA: An incidental, but significant, feature of the proposed new section 13 is the provision which it makes for determining which senators should be long term and which should be short term following a double dissolution. It will establish and entrench the principle, based on the existing procedure, that the terms allotted to senators should accord with the relative order of their success at the double dissolution election. This accords with the unanimous opinion of the Constitutional Convention at its Adelaide meeting and a recommendation by the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform in its report tabled last week. The precise means by which the relative success of senators at the double dissolution election is to be established will be a matter for the Parliament or , in the absence of legislation on the matter, for the Senate. The proposals in the Bill would allow the Parliament to adopt the particular procedure recommended by the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform.

Proposed new section 13 also deals with the case where a senator dies, resigns or becomes disqualified before the division of senators into two classes takes place. The point is expressly covered by a specific provision requiring the division to be made as if the place of the senator had not become vacant.

The new section 13 contains transitional provisions relating to senators holding office at the time when the amendments take effect. Subject to any double dissolution which might take place, the effect of these provisions will be as follows:
Senators whose terms are due to expire on 30 June 1985 will hold office until the first expiry or dissolution of the House of Representatives after the commencement of the amendment;
Senators whose terms are due to expire on 30 June 1988 will hold office until the second expiry or dissolution of the House of Representatives after the amendment takes effect.

There are a number of other incidental and consequential matters covered by the Bill. Section 9 of the Constitution will be amended to empower this Parliament, rather than the State parliaments, to make laws determining the times and places of electing senators. This is the logical consequence of bringing elections for both Houses of the Parliament together.

The Bill will also make two other consequential changes, one to section 12 of the Constitution and the other to section 57 of the Constitution. Section 12 of the Constitution, as it now exists, provides for State Governors to cause writs to be issued for the election of State senators. Where the election follows a double dissolution, the writs must be issued within 10 days after the proclamation of the dissolution. The proposed new section 12 will place a like obligation on a State Governor to cause a writ to be issued for the election of senators at a half-Senate election within 10 days of the expiry of the term of the retiring senators.

The amendment to section 57 will expressly provide for an election of senators to be held on the same day as the general election of members of the House of Representatives next following a double dissolution. This will remove one ground of criticism of the 1977 Simultaneous Elections Bill, namely, that whatever may have been its intent it did not in fact require simultaneous elections to be held.
PARLIAMENTARY TERMS BILL

This Bill proposes to amend the Constitution first by extending from 3 years to 4 years the maximum term of the House of Representatives and, secondly, by increasing the fixed terms of senators from 6 years to 8 years. Where a double dissolution occurs, the terms of all senators holding office at the time of the double dissolution would be cut short and, following the ensuing election, half of the senators for States would have terms of 4 years while the remainder of the State senators would have 8 year terms.

In the event that the simultaneous elections proposal is also passed, so that senators' terms coincide with those of members of the House of Representatives, the amendment is written in such a way that the fixed 8-year Senate term becomes a maximum 8-year term.

The proposals will not affect the terms of office of the present members of the House of Representatives or, accordingly, the term of office of the present Government. Those elected at the first election of the House of Representatives following the commencement of the amendments will be elected for 4-year terms instead of 3-year terms. The first senators to be elected for an 8-year term will be those elected at the first Senate election occurring after the commencement of the amendments.

Special provision is made for senators holding office at the commencement of the amendments. Those senators elected on 5 March 1983 and whose terms of office now expire on 30 June 1985 will have their terms extended to 30 June 1986. Those long-term senators, also elected on 5 March 1983 but whose terms now expire on 30 June 1988, will have their terms extended to 30 June 1990. In each case, the extension is subject to any earlier double dissolution of the Senate. These provisions are necessary to maintain the Senate rotation system of a half-Senate election every 4 years and to bring the half-Senate elections reasonably into phase with the expected House of Representatives elections. Otherwise, a half- Senate election would be due before the middle of 1985 whereas the next House of Representatives election is not due until the first half of 1986.

In the absence of provisions of this kind, even the holding of an early House of Representatives election in late 1984 or early 1985 would not serve to keep the House of Representatives and Senate elections in phase without either an indefinite number of subsequent early elections, which would entirely defeat the purpose of the 4-year term proposal, or else frequent national elections with half-Senate elections taking place between successive House of Representatives elections. The proposed transitional provision, at the cost of a modest extension of the terms of the present senators, makes possible the synchronisation of elections for the two Houses for the foreseeable future. Of course, the difficulty does not arise if the simultaneous elections proposal is accepted. In that case, the transitional provisions relating to existing senators will not come into effect. This will be achieved by clause 5 of the Parliamentary Terms Bill.
CONCLUSION

The Government intends to withdraw the fixed term proposal but proceed with the three other measures now before the Senate, namely, the amendments to provide for interchange of powers between the Commonwealth and the States, the giving of advisory opinions by the High Court and the removal of obsolete and expended provisions from the Constitution. These three measures, together with the two which I am now introducing, will provide a package comprising all of the machinery of government proposals which have received either unanimous or strong majority cross-party support at the Australian Constitutional Convention. They should, if consistency counts for anything in politics, continue to attract cross-party support.

None of the proposals involves the Commonwealth in any attempt to acquire new powers at the expense of the States. Indeed, the proposal for interchange of powers should provide for better co-operative arrangements between the Commonwealth and the States. The decision of the High Court of Australia in the recent Victorian Pipelines case has emphasised the inflexibility of some of the existing provisions of the Constitution in financial matters and the desirability, accordingly, of adopting the interchange of powers proposal as a basis for negotiations on these and other matters. It is the Government's intention that all five constitutional change proposals now before the Parliament be debated and passed by both Houses this session, and put to referendum on 25 February 1984. I commend the Bills to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Durack) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discharge of Order of the Day

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That Government Business, Order of the Day No. 32, Constitution Alteration ( Fixed Term Parliaments) Bill 1983, be discharged from the Notice Paper.
I do so more in sorrow than in anger.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not oppose this motion, because if the Government desires to change its course in mid-stream, to go elsewhere and make foolish errors, we cannot stop it from doing so, but I think some comment should be made about what is being done. Senator Evans has told us this morning that what he is putting forward is a second-best proposal rather than the fixed term proposal of which he was an advocate, of which I was and continue to be an advocate and which I regard as the best solution. I know that he has been overborne in his Caucus by the pragmatists of his Party, those apparatchiks who have now managed to persuade the Australian Labor Party that what it needs is not to remove the Prime Minister's prerogative of having elections when he wants to, which is the very thing we need to get out of this Constitution, but to have a four-year term, which leaves the Prime Minister with that iniquitous right.

SPEECH.PARA: There were always alternatives. In 1977 we endeavoured to get something like this. I agree that the proposal being put forward now is better and picks up one or two things that were used against the concept in 1977. I warn him against putting his faith in princes-the people who went to the Australian Constitutional Convention and who there said that they would support these proposals. I wonder how many of them, when they went home, had already decided that they would oppose these Bills. I think he will still have a difficult course. I certainly recognise this as a second-best proposal but a proposal which I support. I campaigned for it vigorously in 1977, and I will campaign for it vigorously again. It is not the best solution. The Labor Party will have ultimately to come around to the view that it must get back to fixed terms. That should have been number one off the ranks and now it will obviously be number two off the ranks.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, why not vote against this motion?

—We cannot stop this proposal going forward if this is what the Government wants to do. If it is not willing to continue with the fixed terms which the many of us have supported I am afraid that it has to take the carriage of this matter. It certainly would be an improvement, but it is only one part of the package. The most important part of the package should have come first. I say to the apparatchiks who have succeeded in this matter: I hope they now get their State organisations to get behind the proposal and do not once again dump the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) and others by sabotaging these proposals. I see that I have not exactly offended the Attorney-General, with whom I know my words will strike some sympathetic chord. Nonetheless, I just want to warn him not to take for his assurance that he will have the sort of support that was necessarily given in the Constitutional Convention but that his second best and more modest proposal, though it may have the support of those who supported his less modest proposal, is one that he will still have to fight for. I will not oppose the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Australian Democrats will oppose the motion to discharge the Constitution Alteration (Fixed Term Parliaments) Bill 1983 from the Notice Paper. This fixed term proposal legislation is a major constitutional reform. I think it is one of the most important pieces of constitutional legislation to come forward in this Parliament for quite some time. The so-called substitutes that the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) has talked about merely tinker again with the system. May I quote the authority that the Attorney-General quoted. Mr Fraser suggested that we ought to hold the two referenda that the Attorney-General has now introduced. A newspaper article dated 8 February 1983 stated:

SPEECH.PARA: But Mr Fraser acknowledged yesterday that his referendum would in no way prevent the Prime Minister calling an early election whenever he wanted. Indeed, the referendum will facilitate this Prime Ministerial power because it removes any subsequent difficulties in the form of a half-Senate election.

That is a very interesting admission about the authority upon which the Attorney -General now relies. According to the article, the present Attorney-General made the following statement at the time the previous Prime Minister made his announcement:
'There is no question of Labor supporting a four-year simultaneous election referendum unless it also provides for fixed terms.
'Under this proposal elections could still be held at two-yearly intervals.'
The article continued:
Senator Evans said a basic flaw in the present system was the capacity of Prime Ministers to call elections whenever they wanted.

Yet now we have precisely a situation in which we have dropped the major reform to try to get the simultaneous election proposal that the present Attorney- General championed here while in opposition. Now, in government, unfortunately this reform is to be jettisoned and we are to have it replaced by two referenda proposed by what another Minister here has called the discredited previous Liberal Prime Minister. Indeed, I think today is a sorry day for constitutional reform.

I will support the other two proposals. However, I must admit that I am not at all enthusiastic about them-I cannot see them doing terribly much-but at least they might go some way, particularly the simultaneous elections proposal, to rectifying the situation. I suggest we have lost an opportunity to put to the people, not to this House-the proposals would have passed this House and the other place-a proposition of fixed terms to remove that prime ministerial power. I think that in a democracy the people have the prerogative to make a deliberation on a major proposal that has been floated now for some years, whether or not the proposal was supported by the Constitutional Convention. As I said, I think this is a sorry day for constitutional reform. I hope that at some stage in the future a government will be willing to bite the bullet on this issue and go to the people and ask them for their deliberation on this extremely important question.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion. I note that when this legislation was last before the Senate I did not get the chance to finish what I was saying on that occasion. I will not endeavour to do so at this stage. I must say that this is not a sorry day for those who have taken any interest at all in this constitutional proposal. I congratulate those members of the Australian Labor Party who have finally applied their minds to the Constitution Alteration (Fixed Term Parliaments) Bill as it was presented to the Parliament. The Bill did not create fixed terms. Because the words 'fixed terms' were in the title, everyone seemed to believe that this Bill in some way or other created a fixed term. It did no such thing. It determined that every three years there would be an election on a particular day, in addition to any other elections which might be called by the House of Representatives prior to that election. In effect, all it did was to take away from the Senate and the Governor-General the present controlling provisions and place the calling of elections totally in the hands of the House of Representatives which, of course, meant totally in control of the government of the day. How that could be described as a constitutional reform by those who applied their minds to this subject is totally beyond me. I thoroughly support the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will, of course, support this motion. I note that Senator Missen strongly supports a view contrary to the official Opposition view on this matter. I am very pleased indeed, as is Senator Lewis, to see the demise of this proposal. It is one which has always greatly troubled me. We opposed it when it was first put forward by Senator Evans when he was in opposition and we were in government. We have continued to oppose it. I put down the Opposition's view on this measure when it was introduced by the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) in May. I do not propose to re-open that debate. I adopt the view taken by Senator Lewis this morning on this issue.

SPEECH.PARA: But I also wish to say that the proposal was put forward by Senator Evans and the present Government in two guises. It was put forward as their solution to what they perceived to be the problems of 1975. They saw it as an indirect way of weakening the power of the Senate. I always had great doubts about whether it would have worked that way, but that was what it was designed to do. Its merits were very hard to detect except that, clearly for the purposes of the last election campaign, it was seen to have some political merit at the time because of the feeling in the community that there were too many elections. It was presented as a fixed term proposal to attract support from people in the electorate who were worried about the frequency of federal elections. That is now proved to have been a cynical exercise by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Government at the time of the election. The Government traded on that concern. After being in government for only a short time, it has abandoned the Bill.

Although I thoroughly support that decision, and indeed am very thankful for it , nevertheless I cannot avoid commenting on the way in which the Government has handled this matter. It is not only a very great rebuff for the Attorney-General , who had made such a major issue of this proposal when in opposition, in the election campaign and again in government, but also it is a very sorry day for the Goverment and for the political process in this country when a proposal of this kind can be put forward in an election campaign as one of the high flying policies of that party when in opposition, as the Australian Labor Party then was during the election campaign, and then be abandoned so shortly afterwards in such a very public and dramatic way.

Nevertheless, as I have said, this proposal was never put forward openly and honestly as a genuine fixed term proposal. It was put forward for other reasons. It was a purely academic solution which took no account, or very little account, of the way in which the parliamentary democracy in this country operates. It would not, as Senator Lewis clearly indicated, have provided a fixed term. In fact the result of the legislation probably would have been more elections rather than fewer elections. As I said, I do not want to redebate the matter now . I simply express my great satisfaction in the fact that the proposal, which would have been quite unworkable, has been withdrawn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a motion moved by the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) which gives moment to the decision of the Government to change its decision to allow the people to vote at a referendum. The question that the Government originally proposed was that the decision to hold early elections would be taken out of the hands of politicians who would do it for pure party political purposes and would give the people some rights for a change, namely, that the terms of parliament should be fixed.
—The poll showed about 75 per cent were for it too.

—I thank Senator Missen for his interjection. It was a commendable view. I commend the Attorney-General for his courage and the strength with which he fought for so many years-he fought for it also in Cabinet-for this constitutional reform. I score no points off Senator Gareth Evans this morning because he has been a credit to constitutional reform. He has been a credit to his party in trying to bring about this reform.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats will vote against this motion because we believe at the very least that the people ought to have a chance to vote. For the moment let us assume that what Senator Durack and what Senator Lewis of the Liberal Party have said has some logic in it.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a very wild assumption.

—That helpful interjection will be recorded in Hansard and I point out that it was made by an honourable senator from the Opposition. I will not embarrass the honourable senator who said it but he suggested that my comment about assuming that there was some logic in what Senator Lewis said was a very wild assumption. I put that to one side for the moment. Given that there is logic in the argument put forward by Senator Lewis, he is saying: 'No. We will not allow the people of Australia to express an opinion on this subject'. That is what he is saying. He is not arguing about the substantive matter. He is saying: 'I, Senator Lewis, think it is stupid. We in the Liberal Party think it is stupid and, therefore, it is not worth while giving the people of Australia a chance to vote on it'. That is what this vote is all about. It is not about the substantive issue.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the record. Senator Durack made what I regard as one of the most extraordinary statements I have heard in this place for a long while when he said: 'A Bill bringing in fixed terms will mean that there are more elections'. That is the sort of logic which confounds me. It may be that to my simple mind those sorts of fundamental truths are too difficult to grasp. If the Constitution is amended so that there will be fixed terms to take away from political leaders the right to go to the people for an election when it suits them, and thus throw the whole economy into instability over a period, it confounds me as to how that might cause more elections. Under the present system , if my counting is correct, in the last 11 years this country has been plunged into six Federal elections-it could be argued that only the 1975 election was caused by reasons other than the whim of the then Prime Minister-by Prime Ministers who decided that for party political purposes the country should go to the polls prematurely. I do not have the exact figures with me but since Federation this country has had an election on average every two years and one month. Every 25 months, or something like that, this country has been plunged into an election because some petty politician who happened to lead a political party at that time said: 'Now is a good time for me to grasp power again. I will go to the people a year early'.

TALK.START.PARA: —After what happened to Fraser, they will think twice.

—That was a goof. Maybe it will teach future Prime Ministers not to treat the people with so much contempt. One could argue that it also happened to a former distinguished Premier of South Australia of a different political persuasion who treated the people with contempt by going over a year early for his own political purposes.
—And in Tasmania.

—And indeed Tasmania. I thank Senator Withers. One might ask whether this is good for the country. I would have thought that a 3-year parliament any term gives a political party that wins government precious little time to rectify the mess in which a previous government might have got the country. In the first year of office, a government tries to rectify some of the basic problems. In the second year it continues on that path. In the third year, the government is in an election year and there is a massive temptation to give an election Budget. That has been the history of political parties which have been in power in this country. In election year the government puts down a give- away, tempting, electioneering Budget which is irresponsible and puts the economy into an upward spiral of inflation. When the government is re-elected, in the first year it brings down a horror Budget in May, causing further instability. The second year is the only year in which political parties have been able to govern responsibly. After the second year, the government is in an election year again. It produces an electioneering Budget and the whole yo-yo concept of this thinking hits the business and social community of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats took some hope that this allegedly reformist Government, with certainly a reformist Attorney-General, might have taken us to this reform of fixed term parliaments, but apparently the pragmatists in the Australian Labor Party said to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke): 'Look, Malcolm Fraser and Bob Menzies did this for years to suit their own political purposes. Don't be a mug and give away this opportunity of going to the people'. Human nature being what it is, I suppose it was a pretty strong argument to put to a Prime Minister, but it is not a right argument, it is not an argument to which he should have acquiesced. We believe it would be very rare to find Democrats opposing the right of the people to vote in any referendum. Leaving aside the merits or demerits of this question, I argue that the vote which we are about to make in this place concerns the fact that the Liberals and the Labor Party are saying: 'No, the Australian people should not be trusted to have a say on whether they want fixed term parliaments'. Because that is the vote before the Senate, the Democrats will vigorously oppose it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Withers Sen The Rt Hon R.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise but briefly. The Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Chipp, has been prating on for some time about the democratic rights of people to vote in a referendum. If he carries that argument to its normal, political and logical conclusion, the more elections the better, because people ought to be able continually to decide which government they want. They cannot have it both ways.
—That is rubbish. It is not worthy of you. You are normally much better than that.

—The honourable senator should not get excited just because he has been found out. I did not rise to gloat over the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans). I think what has happened to the Government is that the reality of government has caught up with the euphoria of opposition. That is always a very good thing. I rose to ask a couple of simple questions: Firstly, if one takes the assumption-to use Senator Hamer's words, a very wild assumption-that fixed term parliaments really meant fixed terms absolutely, with nothing in between, how can one go from being an ardent supporter of fixed terms to now being an ardent supporter of simultaneous elections? That to me is an even greater jump in consistency than that which I made between 1974 and 1977 on the same question. It is an even greater jump than Senator Evans is making here today on allegedly fixed terms. Surely the argument for allegedly absolutely fixed terms was that there would be no elections at all between the fixed election dates.
—There are always exceptions.

—No, it was propounded as though there would be no exceptions; that is why they call them fixed terms. To go from that to simultaneous elections, which means that there is no discipline at all in having a Senate and House of Representatives election separately, means that there would be more and more temptation to have more and more elections. I can understand one who is opposed to fixed terms desiring simultaneous elections. I understand an ardent supporter of simultaneous elections being totally opposed to fixed term parliaments. For the life of me I cannot understand how one can support both propositions. Perhaps the Attorney-General, when he replies, will be kind enough to explain to me how one can jump from one to the other. That would be a bigger 180-degree turn than I made between 1974 and 1977.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose this debate is not a very rewarding one because the decision to withdraw the Constitution Alteration (Fixed Term Parliaments) Bill 1983 is in the Government's power. I agree with that decision. I regret it, but I do not think, referring to the remarks made by Senator Chipp, that there is any great merit in putting a proposal to the people which will be opposed by a substantial party organisation. Historically, such a referendum is doomed to failure. I think it is a pity. Opinion is by no means unanimous. It is not really a party issue at all. The South Australian Liberal Party, only a few days ago, resolved in favour of fixed terms. It is not an issue on which the Liberal Party has a firm view because it is a pragmatic issue. It is a question of how parliament could work better. There is nothing in Liberal philosophy either for or against this proposal. It is a pragmatic issue of whether it would work better or not.

SPEECH.PARA: I have intervened in this debate because there seemed to be a couple of misunderstandings worth clarifying in case, and I hope it will, this proposition comes up again. I do not think that the proposal which the Government intends to put forward of simultaneous elections and four-year parliaments is the answer or the end of the road on this matter. I think we have to look at more significant changes to our system. The comments I would like to make refer to Senator Chipp' s remarks. He seemed to imply that the provision of fixed-term parliaments would have avoided the election held in March. In fact, fixed term parliaments-I have pointed out several times that that is an unfortunate term because the terms were never fixed-would remove the discretionary power which a Prime Minister effectively has to call an election the moment he thinks it fits his political advantage. He sometimes gets it wrong, but he has that power to use it if he wants to use it.

Nevertheless, Senator Evans's Bill and any fixed term, if I can use that expression, parliament Bill must have exceptions because there are circumstances in which parliament could not continue. The two circumstances which were provided for in his Bill were, firstly, if a double dissolution or the deadlocked procedure applied. That was the procedure that brought about the election last March. That was provided for in the Attorney-General's Bill and would have to be included in any Bill on fixed terms. The second provision, although I disagree with the Attorney-General that this provision would be more frequently used, would be if a government which had the confidence of the lower House could not be formed. There must be some provision then for some form of election. By the way, that situation has not occurred in our 83 years of constitutional history and it is not very likely to happen. I think it is highly improbable that using that provision would result in more elections. In my view it would certainly result in less frequent elections.

The one area that has not been solved by any of the proposals put before us is the difficulty of the abuse by all governments of the double dissolution power. This deadlock provision was put in at the Constitutional Convention to deal with a particular problem. A piece of legislation to which obviously the Government attached importance was rejected in a formal way by the upper House. The idea of the constitutional authors was that that piece of legislation would have to be resolved. One thing they looked at was putting it to referendum, which was very popular in the 1890s. Ultimately they decided on the double dissolution, possibly followed by a joint sitting. But this provision was designed to deal with a particular urgent, critical piece of legislation. In fact, as we all know , it has been used in a quite different way to serve up a piece of unacceptable legislation early in a Parliament to provide a trigger, a means whereby the Government can have a double dissolution whenever it wants. This seems to me to be a great abuse of this power and one for which there is no place in our constitutional system.

I will propose in due course-I do not know whether it would get through but I think that we should look at it-a constitutional amendment which would bring this particular provision under control. I do not accept that the purpose of the provision in the Constitution is to allow the Government to get rid of the Senate whenever it chooses by taking the whole Senate out whenever it likes to have a House of Representatives election. I think we should look very carefully at having an arrangement whereby, if the rejection of a particular piece of legislation gives the Government the power to call an election, a double dissolution, and the Government does not exercise that power within three months of gaining it, the piece of legislation can no longer be considered urgent and the power lapses. I will be making proposals to this end in due course.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: — I support the proposal to discharge from the Notice Paper Government Business order of the day No. 32 relating to the Constitutional Alteration (Fixed Term Parliaments) Bill 1983. The reason for my so doing is that the title of the Bill is both false and misleading. It is incumbent upon members of parliament to ensure that the public is properly represented and that Bills which pass this legislature, particularly those which go to the people in the form of constitutional referendums, are properly represented to the people.

SPEECH.PARA: As has been stated, by earlier speakers in this debate, the underlying assumption which our constituents could justly make in regard to a constitutional alteration referendum on fixed term parliaments is that the terms of the parliaments would be fixed and that these parliaments would be up for election once every, as it was, three years on a particular day of a particular month. That was not the case, in the Bill. Certainly those elections would take place but they would be in addition to any other elections which might be necessary as a result of decisions taken in the Parliament itself. So in fact the title of the referendum would have been misleading and false. Therefore, I think it is commendable that the Government has seen fit to discharge this Bill from the Notice Paper.

I hold the view, as was held at the previous referendum in 1977 and the one before it in 1974, that the simultaneous election proposals are also misleading. The Constitutional Alteration (Simultaneous Election) Bill is also a misleading and false title. But we are not debating that at this point. I am glad that the Government has seen fit to propose the discharge of the fixed term parliaments Bill. I would hope that wiser counsels may prevail and that in a couple of months the Government might be proposing to discharge the Bills which have now been placed before the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-The only question before the Senate is whether the Constitution Alteration (Fixed Term Parliaments) Bill ought to be further debated by this Parliament and therefore remain on the Notice Paper. I indicate that I do not believe it is appropriate to debate the intrinsic merits of that legislation or, indeed, of any other constitutional reform proposal, despite the invitation from Senator Withers and others to do so, an invitation which I have a lot of difficulty resisting but this is not the time. Let me simply say this: I understand the public spiritedness of the Australian Democrats in opposing the motion to discharge the fixed term parliaments Bill. They want to see the Bill debated and put to referendum and indeed, as several speakers have noted in the course of this debate, I have a certain sneaking affection for the proposal myself. But I indicate to the Senate that the gesture of the Democrats-and regrettably this is not a unique occasion in this respect-has a certain quixotic quality about it because it is simply not the Government's intention, even should the matter remain on the Notice Paper, to bring the Bill on for debate, the reason being that we are substituting for this proposal one that we believe will be less divisive and have a better chance of succeeding at referendum. We believe that even the cynicism so often demonstrated by the Liberal and National parties would not extend to their voting to bring the matter on for debate in order then to defeat it, and we believe, as a result, that it is a thoroughly empty gesture to be opposing the discharge motion.

SPEECH.PARA: Might I indicate that there has been no cynicism whatsoever in the Government's own approach to this legislation. We still believe, as a party, that there are real advantages and real merits in the fixed term proposal, and it may be that it would be appropriate to reconsider that proposal at some time in the future. But it is clear that opinion on this issue as between the major parties is hopelessly divided at this point, notwithstanding the spirit of compromise with which the proposal was originally brought forward. Given the history of referendums on constitutional matters in this country, it does make it extremely implausible that the proposal would attract the necessary majority support were it to go ahead in that particular environment. The other proposals now brought before the Parliament will, we hope, as I indicated before, if consistency means anything, attract the genuine support of the major Opposition parties and as a result have a much better chance, second-best proposals though they may be in many people's eyes, of attracting widespread community support. I simply hope that after the high moral tone that my opposite number, Senator Durack, has adopted in this debate, the Opposition will show its willingness to behave in a consistent, principled and public spirited fashion in the course of this debate and add its weight to improving the quality of democracy in this country by ensuring the ultimate passage of the four-year and simultaneous election proposals. I commend the discharge motion to the Senate.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Gareth Evans's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, the two leaders, Senator Chaney and Senator Button, were absent from the chamber but wish to indicate that they supported the motion.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Walsh) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill will provide legislative authority for the entry into force of new comprehensive double taxation agreements with Ireland, the Republic of Italy, the Republic of Korea and the Kingdom of Norway. A revised comprehensive double taxation agreement with the United States of America is another important element of the Bill which also includes a limited airline profits agreement with the Republic of India.

The agreements were all signed between May 1982 and May of this year. Details of the agreements were announced when the agreements were signed, and copies of them were made available to the public at that time.

The comprehensive agreements deal with all forms of income flowing between Australia and the other countries concerned. As implied in the title, the Airline Profits Agreement with India is restricted to the taxation of profits derived from international air transport.
Australia and India are to exempt from their respective income taxes profits derived from such transport by the other country's international airline.

The practical effect of the agreement is that Australia will have the sole right to tax Indian source profits from the international airline operations of Qantas and India will have the same right with respect to Australian source profits from international operations of Air India.

Although this agreement with India is restricted to international airline profits, India is included in the current negotiating program for comprehensive double taxation agreements and negotiations for such an agreement will be commenced at the earliest mutually convenient time.
I now turn to the comprehensive agreements contained in this Bill.
In general, comprehensive double taxation agreements have two primary objects- the elimination of international double taxation and the prevention of fiscal evasion.
The first of these objects is achieved by the contracting countries agreeing to the allocation of taxing rights between them.
There are various ways by which this is done, depending upon the nature of the income involved.
For example, some types of income will be taxed only in the country of residence while other income may be taxed only in the country in which it has its source.

A third category is comprised of income which may be taxed in both countries, with the country of source generally agreeing to limit its tax, and the country of residence of the taxpayer agreeing to allow a credit against its tax on such income for the tax paid in the other country.
The comprehensive agreements contained in this Bill accord in all essential respects with the position that Australian governments have taken over the years in relation to double taxation agreements.
The agreements provide for the country of source to limit its tax on dividends, interest and royalties.

Generally, the country of source is to limit its tax to 15 per cent of the gross income concerned in the case of dividends and 10 per cent for both interest and royalties flowing to the other country.
In the agreement with Korea, the limit is 15 per cent for dividends, interest and royalties.

For its part, Australia will reduce the rate of withholding tax on dividends flowing to the other country from the normal 30 per cent rate to the 15 per cent rate specified in the particular agreement.
As the rate of withholding tax on interest under Australia's domestic law is 10 per cent, this will not be affected by the limits on source country tax on interest provided for in these agreements.

In Australia, royalties paid to non-residents are taxed by the ordinary assessment basis on the net amount, after deduction of expenses and, accordingly , the limits specified by the agreements by reference to gross royalties will not affect the amount of Australian tax on royalties unless the tax which would otherwise be assessed on the net royalties is greater than the limit expressed in the agreements.

For its part, each of the other countries will reciprocally apply a 15 per cent rate on dividends flowing to Australia and 10 per cent in the case of interest and royalties, except of course that the Korean rate on interest and royalties will be 15 per cent.

Korea may, however, in some cases, in accordance with its industry incentive legislation, wholly or partially exempt from Korean tax certain interest and royalty payments made to Australian residents.

If nothing were done to avoid the situation, the tax so forgone by Korea would simply result in a corresponding reduction in the credit to be allowed by Australia against its tax on the relevant interest and royalty payments.
In other words, the Australian revenue would pick up the tax forgone by Korea, thus nullifying the incentive.
To avoid that result, provision is made in the agreement for Australia, as a ' tax sparing' measure, to allow a credit against its tax for tax forgone by Korea under agreed Korean incentive.
Legislation, as if notional tax equal to 10 per cent of the interest or royalty income had been paid to the Republic of Korea.

The comprehensive agreements contain measures for the formal relief of double taxation of income that may be taxed in both countries, with the country of residence of the taxpayer affording the necessary relief by the allowance of a credit against its tax for tax paid to the country of source.

So far as Australian residents are concerned, income in respect of which a limit is imposed by the agreements on the tax of the country of source-dividends , interest and royalties-will generally be taxed here with credit being allowed for the tax of the country of source.
However, because of the general rebate on inter-company distributions, there is effectively no tax on dividends received from foreign sources by Australian resident companies.
The Bill does not disturb the position that other income that is taxed in full in the country of source is exempt from Australian tax.

So far as the object of preventing fiscal evasion is concerned, provisions are made in each agreement for the exchange of information and for consultation between the tax administrations of the contracting countries.

Apart from the provisions I have mentioned, the agreements also contain usual provisions of a kind common to double taxation agreements relating to the taxation of business profits, professional services, employees, public entertainers, students, pensioners and so on.
The comprehensive agreements with Ireland, Italy, Korea and Norway are all important additions to Australia's growing network of such agreements.

Apart from achieving the primary objects of avoiding double taxation and assisting in the prevention of fiscal evasion, the agreements are an expression of accord between our governments and reflect the many ties that Australia has with these countries.
In that and other respects the revised agreement with the United States is particularly significant. It replaces an existing agreement which was signed in 1953 and has become very much out of date.

The existing agreement became inadequate in a number of respects over the years , largely as a result of amendments to the taxation laws of Australia and the United States and, also, of the ever increasing complexities of international commercial transactions.
The revised agreement with the United States, as mentioned earlier, accords in all essential respects with Australia's double taxation agreement policies.
It improves our position in dealing with visiting entertainers.

It introduces articles providing for source country tax of no more than 10 per cent of gross payments in respect of interest and royalties. The old agreement had no interest article, and only a very limited royalties provision. The 10 per cent limit contrasts, I note, with the United States domestic rate of 30 per cent that has applied until now. The new agreement does contain an article entitled 'non-discrimination' which is not to be found in any of our other agreements.

This article, which will not be given the force of law in Australia by this Bill, expresses each country's best intention that, in enacting taxation measures, it will not treat citizens or residents of the other country, and enterprises or companies owned wholly or partly by them, in a less favourable way than it treats its own citizens or residents, enterprises or companies.

An important feature of this non-discrimination article is that it will not affect, in any way, the operation of existing provisions of the Australian income tax law, or any similar provisions enacted since signature of the agreement on 6 August 1982, or provisions designed to prevent avoidance or evasion of taxes.

Beyond that, the non-discrimination article does no more than call for consultation between the Governments of both countries when any taxation measure is considered to be contrary to the principles of the article. It will not be able to be called in aid by a taxpayer in an objection against a taxation assessment.
The agreements contained in this Bill cannot enter into force until all necessary constitutional processes are completed both by Australia and the other countries.
For Australia, this Bill will, when assented to, complete the processes required of us.
Details of the provisions of the Bill are contained in an explanatory memorandum being circulated to honourable senators.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the end of my speech yesterday I moved an amendment with respect to the omnibus Bill, the Health Legislation Amendment Bill. I believe it may have been taken to have been with respect to another Bill. I therefore seek leave to withdraw the amendment with respect to the Medicare Levy Bill and have the amendment placed correctly with respect to the omnibus Bill, the Health Legislation Amendment Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I now move my amendment with respect to the Health Legislation Amendment Bill:

SPEECH.PARA: Leave out all words after 'That', insert:
'the Senate declines to give the Bill a second reading as it is of the opinion that the Australian system of health care delivery and financing should be based on-

(a) the private professional practice of doctors and other health professionals charging a fee for service supported by a private sector insurance system, and sympathetic government assistance to the aged and the disadvantaged; and

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to complete my remarks on the Medicare legislation. I do not remember what comma I was at last night-
—Start all over again.

—Thank you, Senator Georges. There are a few points that I want to add to my remarks. One claim that the Opposition has brought before us and which has been publicised is that by the voluntary health funds which wish to be agents for Medicare. I draw the Senate's attention to the fact that these same funds in 1975 refused to run Medibank and so the Health Insurance Commission was given the task, and very well it did it too. We have little reason to suspect that the Health Insurance Commission will not again manage as well as it did that previous time, but we do have considerable doubt about how the health funds would function, particularly in light of their history of refusal and non-co- operation. They complain also about the potential loss of jobs, as also has Senator Haines; it is right and proper to complain about any potential loss of jobs. But in passing I would like to ask the Senate to recall who complained when Medibank was wound down about not only the loss of jobs to the people working in the Health Insurance Commission but also the enormous cost to the taxpayers of Australia. It is also important to note that the Minister for Health, Dr Blewett, has made it quite clear that employee preference will be given to anybody from the private health funds who may be displaced from work in that area. As the private health funds will have an ability to take up the insurance for private hospitals and extras and to extend their insurance coverages to other areas besides health, the potential loss of jobs may be less than they anticipated in the first place.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Haines is also quoted in the Age as saying that it was illogical for the Government to spend more than $50m and put 2,000 people out of work to 'just satisfy socialist ideology'. I simply remind the honourable senator that it is not just simply socialist ideology that provokes the Labor Government to ask the Health Insurance Commission to administer Medicare. It is because under the Health Insurance Commission the system will be well administered with one data collection centre leading to proper data for epidemiological and research matters and for the pursuit of medifraud and overservicing. There will be a faster turn around time for patients; therefore, it will be cheaper. For all of those reasons I think the Government can be unashamedly proud of placing Medicare under the Health Insurance Commission. I ask Senator Haines whether she would care to comment later on what impressions she has of a Minister for Health who is on one occasion Attila the Hun and on another occasion a spoilt brat- peculiar assessments, I think, of our current Minister.

The Opposition claims that it is suspicious that there will be an increase in medical fraud under Medicare. I simply remind it that currently, under the scheme it introduced, $100m is a conservative estimate of the extent of medical fraud in 1982-83. It would seem to be remarkable that it would be worried about medical fraud when it clearly cannot under its own scheme cope with it. Medicare has not been planned in ignorance of this fact. In fact, it has provisions in it to deal with medical fraud to make it more likely and more readily able to follow up any potential for fraud. In addition, the Health Insurance Commission' s plans for Medicare have been made with a view to cost containment. It is no accident that there is no gap insurance or that private practice and public facilities will now need to be a contractual arrangement between the private practitioner and the public facility.

In summary, the Liberal Opposition criticises the Government principally with Senator Baume's argument that the Health Insurance Commission will be a monopoly . This leads me once again to say that the honourable senator misunderstands what the Health Insurance Commission and Medicare is about. It will simply provide basic health care insurance. The private funds will continue to offer private hospital and extras insurance to the many Australians who choose to exercise that option. It is not a monopoly. It is a provision for basic health care cover for all Australians. The funds are not complaining. Indeed, they are appreciative, but the Opposition is bleating. It has given us five health schemes in seven years. It dismantled Medibank at great cost to the taxpayer. It ignored the jobs lost in that process. It has left two million Australians uninsured for health costs. It charges people on $300 a week exactly the same as people on $1,000 a week. It produces evidence by the bucket of its incompetence and inadequacy, evidence from its time in government. It has no coherent alternative to Medicare; in fact, it has no alternative. Worse still, it is no alternative.

There is considerable division in the Opposition's ranks. I will not quote to the Senate what Mr Carlton and Mr Peacock disagree on. It was reported the other day that the Opposition has even come up with a compromise sex Bill; we always know that compromising sex is not a satisfactory outcome. If that is the best solution it can offer in that area, it is probably a solution of equal value that it offers for Medicare. In the face of Liberal nothingness the Government stands proud.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is currently debating the Government 's legislation to introduce Medicare. Four Bills are being debated cognately. Senator Crowley has just finished her remarks by making a statement about what Medicare is. Let me refute her statement. Medicare is certainly not about improving Australia's health care system. It is about paying for our health care and the creation of a monopoly. The Medicare legislation now before the Senate highlights the difference between our parties. The parties on this side of the chamber-the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia- believe that if people do not pay something for their medical services they do not appreciate the cost of those services and that difficulties are created in controlling such services.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Labor Party believes that the way to control the cost of Medicare services is to introduce some police state methods. I refer here to the use of computers which will be able to check up on how much medical care a person has and how much medical care a doctor delivers. By applying averages across the nation it will be determined that a patient is receiving too much medical care and that a doctor is providing too much of that care. But among the ALP's number there are fortunately one or two who recognise the merits of our argument. I refer to something said on 14 September by Dr Klugman, the ALP member for Prospect in the House of Representatives. I refer to page 745 of the House of Representatives Hansard of that date, on which he is reported as saying :

. . . I accept the argument to some extent, that there has to be some payment by the patient so as to restrict unscrupulous patients and unscrupulous doctors from overusing medical services. The only way one can restrict that is by having some sort of patient moiety. In other words, the patient pays a very small amount, but nonetheless an amount, towards the cost so that at least he has an account rendered to him, which he has to pay. I know that many people on my side of the House disagree with that, but I think it would be a restraining influence .

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?
—Dr Klugman, the ALP member for Prospect said that. Dr Klugman is, of course, a medical doctor, not a doctor of deception like his Minister in the other place, the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett).

—I raise a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President. I think the relevant standing order is standing order 418. That was certainly an imputation against a member of the Parliament and I ask you to request the speaker to withdraw it.

—I withdraw the allegation, but I shall go on to prove that this legislation deceives the people of Australia. The people of Australia can draw their own conclusions as to whether my allegation is true. We are not talking about the socially disadvantaged. Let us make that clear. They are already receiving free care under the existing system. I add that they used to receive free care when we had the honorary system. Before Medibank was introduced they used to receive excellent free care under the honorary system. That was destroyed by Medibank. They now receive free care and will continue to receive such care under this proposal. They will not receive any better care. They cannot receive any better care. They will not be better catered for under this proposal; they will just continue to receive the care that they have been receiving in the past. We are not talking about socially disadvantaged people. We are talking about the payment for the medical care of the rest of the community, that is, the people of Australia who can afford to pay for their medical services. What is proposed here by the ALP is that instead of people paying for medical care out of their pockets, by insurance or some other way, they will have to pay for it out of their taxes. That means that, in effect, they will not know how much they are being charged and, what is more, because of the monopoly situation, they will be deprived of the freedom of choice which they have under the existing system.

SPEECH.PARA: For philosophical reasons only the Australian Labor Party has introduced this socialist measure. I repeat, Madam Acting Deputy President: There in no improvement in the quality of health care in any way in this proposal. All it does is increase costs to the nation by $1.7 billion and in fact hide the costs from the people of Australia. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a statement of the full year costing of Medicare in 1983-84 values, which I gave to the Government Whip earlier and he approved my having it incorporated.

TALK.START.PARA: —I now quote what Mr Carlton said about these figures in the other House:

SPEECH.PARA: What is important here is not that the thoroughly misleading balancing figure of $62m-
which is what the Minister published these figures for-

but the additional expenditures of $1,742m, offset only by the saving in $80m on the reinsurance trust fund. Thus there is a net additional expenditure of $1, 662m-nearly $1.7 billion-requiring an increase in taxes of $1,662m to pay for it .

Now that is the additional cost of Medicare for a full year. This Government now misleads the people of Australia as to the cost of the scheme with a shonky levy . We heard Senator Crowley say that the people will be paying for Medicare through the levy. What a lot of absolute nonsense, because the reality is that the cost of medical care in Australia is $8 billion. The amount intended to be raised by this levy is $1 billion. So people will receive their tax assessments which will show the words: 'Medicare levy, one per cent'. People will then believe that that is all it is costing them for their medical care whereas in fact the seven-eighths of their medical costs will be hidden in the tax assessment above that statement. So the real cost of medical care will be hidden from the people of Australia. By this means, the cost will be totally obscured. It is inevitable that the people will come to realise that it is not a free service. Unfortunately it will take some years before that fact dawns upon them.

Every time I use the word 'free' in this speech I almost feel like asking Hansard to put it in quotation marks because, believe it or not, 'free' surgery visits and 'free' public hospital beds will in fact disguise the true costs to the consumer. The people of Australia know these services will not be free. Of course they recognise that they cannot go to a hospital or a doctor, have X-rays or have medical care without the services costing someone in the country a lot of money. What will they do? Thanks to this Government's misleading of the people, thanks to this Minister's statements which mislead the people, many people will drop their private hospital cover, trusting that Medicare is comprehensive, but in fact it is not. Medicare covers only 85 per cent of doctors' fees with no choice of doctor in public hospitals. Medicare provides no cover in private hospitals and it attacks private health provisions. It aims to make doctors totally dependent on government, reduces the competitive position of the private hospitals and the Government says it will solve all of our problems by doubling computer surveillance equipment, in other words, adopting police state methods to deal with the possibilities of overservicing.

In fact a significant section of the Australian population will be spending so much more for a lot less. As I have mentioned, the current costs Australia-wide of our health care is $8 billion. The levy will raise $1 billion. From where will the difference come? Is there something up in the sky that will pour $7 billion into the coffers of the people who are providing these services? Of course not. Inevitably the people of Australia will have to pay the difference. Of course increasing demands will be put on specialist services because they appear to be 'free'. There will also be increasing demands on casualty and ancillary services. People will want physiotherapy that they may not have wanted in the past because they believe that the service will be provided free. That inevitably means there will be much greater queueing in public hospitals as people queue up to get these services. But we all know that some people will receive privileged services. For example, does Senator Crowley believe that, when she goes to a public hospital to get some sort of service, the medical profession will make her, a fellow doctor, wait in the queue until her turn is reached? Of course not. She will be moved to the front of the queue and she will receive privileged treatment. She will become one of the privileged minority. Of course there will be people in this country who will receive privileges because they know the doctor.

TALK.START.PARA: —If you are part of the union, you will be all right.

—She is part of the union and she will be all right. All the doctors are part of the union and of course they will expect to treat their colleagues before they treat the rest of the patients. What will inevitably happen is that those people in this country who do not have the ability to be in a privileged position will end up at the bottom of the queue.
