It is very much the same as the position in the Soviet Union, where the party officials always get priority. They get the hospital treatment and the good food and everyone else has to queue. This is the sort of nonsense that is being introduced by the Australian Labour Party. This will be the inevitable consequence of these proposals. This is what happened under Medibank. If honourable senators talk to any hospital officials, the people in casualty sections, the people providing the ancillary services and the medicos they will be told that every day the queues got longer and longer. That was the inevitable result of providing so- called free services.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me make it perfectly clear, Madam Acting Deputy President, that I make no criticism of doctors for overservicing. I believe that many doctors, out of the kindness of their hearts, try to provide the best service that they possible can for their patients. It frequently appears that they may be overservicing. But many patients go to their doctors for reassurance that there is nothing seriously wrong with them. They may have some sort of pain and they want reassurance from the doctors that they have not got a cancer or an ulcer or that they are not dying. They need this reassurance. So they expect their doctors to provide them with every possible service that they can in order to reassure them that they are not suffering some fatal illness.

With modern technology and the belief that health care is 'free', it is inevitable that overservicing will occur, as patients will want the latest technology to check up on their health to make sure that they do not have some fatal disease. A good example of this is the new multimillion dollar CAT scanner . Who decides when it is to be used? Who is going to make this decision? Surely even members of the Australian Labor Party would recognise that there must be some rationing of these services. How do they propose to do it? They are going to do it with a computer. It would be so much better if these services were paid for out of a person's pocket so that the person could understand what the service costs. The Labor Party is going to try to control the use of a CAT scanner with a computer. How on earth can it do so? What a lot of nonsense!

I make the prediction now that in due course this Government will in fact ration health services to the people of Australia. I will tell the Senate how it will do so. It will do so by refusing to increase funds sufficiently to provide the money that is needed for these services. That is how it will squeeze the people of Australia in terms of health care. The people of Australia will not get a better service as a result of the monopoly that will be created by this legislation. The people of Australia will in fact end up being squeezed in regard to their services because the Government cannot go on providing funds endlessly. There must be a bottom in the bucket somewhere.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Crowley will always be at the head of the queue.

—As my friend Senator Messner says, of course Senator Crowley will always be at the head of the queue because she is part of the club. She will receive the privileged treatment. I openly acknowledge that probably I will receive some privileged treatment as will probably every other senator and member of the House of Representatives and other people who know the doctors who care for them. What about the little people of this country? What about the people we should be concerned about? How are they going to get their names up before a doctor? It is inevitable that they will have to wait at the bottom of the queue. People will have to sit in a surgery for six or eight hours before they can see a doctor. This will happen because this Government, for philosophical reasons, thinks it would be a good idea to change the current system. The Government claims that the new system will be simpler. It will not be simpler for those who have to take out extra health care cover at another place. They will be shopping in two places. They will have to pay a levy for basic Medicare cover. Those who apply their minds to the provision of extra health care will then go to the private funds to get more insurance. In any event, is simplicity some sort of a virtue that we ought to look at?

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, the Government claims that there will be greater equity under Medicare. I will admit that the scheme will alleviate the plight of the uninsured which was always of concern to us and which the coalition parties had proposals to overcome. Instead of overcoming that simple problem, what the Government proposes to do is to create an absolute monopoly around this nation and to create major difficulties for doctors in the provision of decent medical services to the people of this country. The Government talks about the equity of the scheme. Let me make a couple of points about that. Two-income families will be paying twice for health care. Single people will pay the full levy. I am not unhappy about all that because I, as a member of a single income family, will come out on top. I will be paying the levy only once. However, the Australian Labor Party Federal Government ought to face up to one basic fact, and that is that people who are higher income earners, having paid higher taxes anyway, will now have to pay higher rates for health care.

Let me talk about the costs. Of course there will be some winners and losers. I have always indicated that Senator Crowley and I will undoubtedly be winners out of this system. On the other hand, there will be losers in this system. At least one-third of those existing insured will be paying more for a comparable cover. How on earth can these payment provisions in any way make medical services in this country cheaper? At the moment medical services in this country cost $8, 000m a year. Putting in a big computer in the Medicare offices will not reduce the cost of medical services in any way. No matter how big the computer is and no matter how much it is able to check up on so-called overservicing, the cost of medical care will not be reduced in any way.

TALK.START.PARA: —It won't take away jobs.

—What in fact it will do-and Senator Georges has reminded me of this-is put 5,000 people out of work at a time when unemployment ought to be a matter of major concern to the Government. This Government is proposing to put 5 ,000 people out of employment. Of course, we all know that in any event this Government in its Budget abandoned the unemployed. It has totally abandoned the unemployed people of this nation with a Budget which is going to create savage problems for those people.

SPEECH.PARA: This so-called free public hospitals treatment will mean that private hospital insurance will be less attractive and, of course, the result inevitably must be that greater pressure will be put on public hospitals to the detriment of the private hospitals. In due course many private hospitals will fold. That, of course, is another inevitable consequence. What is that going to mean? It will mean that the taxpayers of this country will have to find capital sums to increase the size of the public hospitals because of demand on public hospitals. Meanwhile, the private hospitals facilities will collapse. The people who run private hospitals will go broke. They will have to sell their hospitals which will then be used as office space or whatever. Meanwhile, this Government will spend thousands of millions of dollars on building new hospitals to cope with the increasing pressure on public hospitals.

The people of Australia are not stupid. They know that this will be an inevitable result of the sort of crass stupidity which is being introduced in this legislation. As I have said, 5,000 people will lose their jobs, there will be a massive increase in the demand for public hospital services, private hospitals will be underutilised and underused and inevitably many will go broke and be forced out of the health care system. All of this will happen because of some stupid philosophical nonsense about a desire to nationalise medical services. We have seen the result of such a change in Great Britain and Canada. We saw what happened between 1973 and 1975 under a Labor Party government. Yet the Labor Party is still unable to realise what an absolute disaster such a system will be to the people of Australia.

May I say in conclusion that Medicare is a great backward step in removing responsible decision-making from patients and doctors who provide services. What we are doing with this legislation is placing those decisions more in the hands of public servants and politicians. I guarantee that when we stand up and remind honourable senators opposite that we told them in 1983 that this Government would ration health services by squeezing the amount of money which ought to be provided for those services they will try to find some other excuse in order to explain away the disaster for this country that Medicare will bring about.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be remiss of me if I did not make some comments in relation to Senator Lewis's speech. For the last 20 minutes or so we were entertained by rhetoric which I imagine Senator Lewis used in days past when he addressed a jury. 'Never mind the facts', Senator Lewis probably thinks, 'but let me win the case'. We had a classic example of 'never mind the facts'. Let me remind him that he will not win the case. I would like to make just a couple of other points about Senator Lewis's speech. Early in his speech he used words to the effect that the different approaches of the two major parties to medical care in Australia highlight the difference between the two major parties. If that is the fact, I say: 'Thank goodness for that'.

SPEECH.PARA: Two other matters need special attention. One is the fear technique that is being used. I am not sure whether it will be used by all members of the Opposition but I deprecate the fear technique too of saying that this Government will introduce a police state. Senator Lewis said that it is necessary to have some mechanism to ensure that overservicing does not take place. The mechanism to be used by this Government is similar to the one that was used by the previous Government. To talk about a police state is not worthy of those Opposition senators. Finally, in remarking on the speech that we have just heard , I wish to make some comment about the ultimate irony that was expressed in it.

Senator Lewis started to complain about a certain loss of jobs, and about unemployment. I came to the Parliament in 1975 when we had just been told by the caretaker Prime Minister who became the Prime Minister after the election that year, that he would provide jobs for everybody who wanted to work. We expected to see a dramatic drop in the unemployment rate. But every year for the seven years that I sat in opposition from 1975 onwards, the unemployment rate increased until we had such record unemployment that that Government was thrown out. Today we have had the ultimate irony of someone from the Opposition talking about those of us on this side of the chamber creating unemployment. I leave Senator Lewis's speech at that stage.

I wish to make some remarks about what happened in the past with Medibank, what is happening at the moment with Medicare and what will probably happen in the future once Medicare is introduced next year. Medibank was introduced about mid- 1975, not between 1973 and 1975, as Senator Lewis said. Between 1973 and 1975 there was a great deal of discussion in the community and in the Parliament about the introduction of Medibank. But it was not actually introduced until mid -1975. Of course, we all know that within six months the Government that introduced it was no longer in power. But although Medibank legislation was in operation for only a short period when the Australian Labor Party was the government, it was one of the most significant pieces of social legislation that had ever passed through the Parliament. Its passage through the Parliament was not without trauma. At that time, there was a concerted campaign against it by the then Opposition and a concerted campaign against it by the medical profession. If at that time one went into a private medical practitioner's surgery, one saw anti-Medibank posters on the wall. If one did not feel sick before visiting the doctor, one certainly felt sick as soon as one got into the surgery and saw the smear technique being used there.

When legislation came before the Parliament for the original Medibank-I am talking about the previous scheme now-the then Liberal-National Country Party Opposition voted against it. It voted against it not once, but twice, to make it one of the 1974 double dissolution Bills. The legislation had to be passed by a joint sitting but, even after it was passed by a joint sitting, the Senate, which was not in control of the Government at the time, would not give approval for the levy. The scheme had to be funded from taxation revenue.

With the opposition that we have at this stage to the Medicare legislation- opposition from some of the people on the opposite side of this chamber-it is almost as if history is repeating itself. I mention the fact that we are even facing the same sort of thing at the moment, with newspaper articles, provided by the medical profession, which distort the facts, to put it mildly, or actually contain false information. I refer to an article that I happened to read in the Sunday Sun, a Brisbane newspaper, last weekend. The heading is 'Mums -to-be face a Medicare slug'. The article starts off:
The AMA has warned mums-to-be they may have to pay up to $1000 in hospital delivery fees under the new Medicare system.

I could go on and read the rest of that article. It is in the Sunday Sun of last weekend. But it is arrant nonsense. What the Australian Medical Association is saying could happen after Medicare is introduced is exactly the same as what happens now. If a person wants to have a private hospital facility, he must have health cover of some sort. If he does, he will not pay that $1,000 that the AMA is saying he would have to pay. The situation in that respect is exactly the same now as it will be after February next year. This is the sort of misleading information that is being given. Even though this misleading information is being given, we know what happened with Medibank. Medibank became operational, and so will Medicare early next year.

Although the old Medibank was in operation for less than six months when the 1975 election was held, it was already well accepted by the public. It was so well accepted by the public that the then caretaker Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, claimed in his 1975 election speech that he and his Government would retain Medibank. I remember watching the telecast of that speech by Mr Fraser. I certainly watched Mr Fraser's telecasts, recalling the old saying: 'One needs to know one's enemy'. I remember watching that telecast and I remember the resounding cheer that his supporters gave him when he said that he would retain Medibank. But the claim proved to be a hollow one.

The years of the Fraser Government which followed were characterised in the health field by a series of costly, confusing health care changes. I could spell out in detail what happened over those years but the details would be of no assistance to us now. But I must say that during the period from 1975 to 1982 I saw every year, with only one exception, a major change introduced by the Fraser Government to health fund proposals. In fact it became something of a ritual for us to come in here once a year and to hear what the new changes were. The changes were costly and, perhaps more importantly to the consumers, they were confusing. How can we have one health care system, change it to another next year and another the year after and at the same time give the consumers, the people who want some consistency in health care funding, some understanding of what is going on? Public understanding certainly was not the case with the previous Government. Although Mr Fraser said that he would retain Medibank, all that remained was the name, and that name was associated with a private health fund.

I move now to the legislation before us. Fortunately for the health care consumers of this nation, there was a change of government in March this year. The swing towards Labor was partly due to the proposals that we put forward for health care insurance. These health care proposals had been set out in detail to the public well over 12 months before the election. Policies such as our Medicare proposals which Labor put before the people for so long before the election do not just happen. There was a realisation in our Party that the original Medibank provided Australians with a sound health scheme. There was a realisation that if that scheme could be improved in the light of experience that improved scheme could service Australia well. However, there was also a realisation, not only by Labor members of the Federal Parliament but also by a majority of Australians, that the Fraser Government could not provide an equitable answer to health cover. As I have said, our proposals did not just happen; they were worked out and refined during countless committee meetings and Party room discussions. All of that-the planning, the failure of our opponents to deliver the goods and the public acceptance of our Medicare proposals-brings us to this point when the legislation is before this chamber.

There will be detailed debate about minute aspects of the legislation at the Committee stage. Thus I shall mention only some broad aspects of what will occur when this legislation is passed. From the first day of February next year Medicare will be operating. Every person in Australia will have medical cover. The scheme will be financed by a one per cent levy on income and I expect that that figure will be held over time. Below certain income thresholds no levy is payable; $128.80 for a single person; $214.25 for a married couple and $21.15 for every dependent child.

Of course, some irresponsible statements have been made about the one per cent levy. These statements have been made by irresponsible people such as the former Minister for Health in Queensland, Mr Austin, who claimed only recently that the levy would soon increase to 2 per cent. Last night we heard in this chamber the same scare tactics that I mentioned earlier in my speech, from the Opposition health spokesman. He said that the one per cent levy will not hold. I will quote that statement at the time of the next election and we will see whether that one per cent levy is holding. This Government intends to honour its promise by keeping that one per cent levy. People such as Austin in Queensland and his fellow travelling knockers should know that the Medicare scheme and the levy will stand the test of time. If there were not an election in Queensland this year, and if Mr Austin were not fighting to retain his seat in the State Parliament, it is doubtful whether he would have found fault with the Medicare proposals. But politics being what they are he has dragged Medicare into the politics of the Queensland election.

Medicare benefits will be payable to every person in Australia at the rate of 85 per cent of the schedule fee for a medical service with a maximum payment of $10 for any one item. Medicare benefits will cover the full range of doctors' services, including treatment by specialists, surgery and diagnostic services such as radiology and pathology. A short time ago I mentioned Queensland and there was some rumbling about Queensland from members on the other side which I cannot quite understand. Under those circumstances I feel somewhat comforted when I think of my lack of proper hearing. Queensland was referred to and it does deserve a special mention. For many years in Queensland-the State that I represent-we have had a free hospital system. This free hospital system was introduced when the Hospitals Benefits Agreement Act was enacted in 1945 by the Cooper Labor Government. However, by the time the free hospital system was set up, Hanlon was the Premier and it was the Hanlon Labor Government that generally gets the credit for introducing the system. That free hospital system has been maintained at great cost by successive governments ever since.

There would be few Queenslanders who have lived in that State for all of their lives who have not used the free hospital system at some stage. I was thankful for the system when, as a young person, I was involved in a serious road accident and needed long-term medical attention. I obtained excellent attention in the free hospital system at that stage. That would also be the case for many people throughout Queensland. However, because of Queensland's free hospital system and because this is an election year in Queensland, a great deal of debate has occurred over the introduction of Medicare in that State. For Queenslanders who currently have no private health insurance, automatic medical cover for visits to their general practitioner will be provided, as will cover for a doctor's home visit and specialist and diagnostic services, including optometry, pathology and radiology. Of course, after the introduction of Medicare if a doctor direct bills patients they will not have to pay anything. One could ask the question: Why have this cover when a free hospital service exists?

I mention these facts: Many people in Queensland live a long way from a free hospital facility. Even people in some suburbs of Brisbane live a long way from a free hospital facility. If a young mother living in the suburb in which I live or a surrounding suburb wanted to take her child who had some illness to the free hospital system, they would have to travel for one and a half hours on public transport to get there and one and a half hours to get back. That is three hours dead time. As well as that, the mother would have to pay fares for herself and perhaps for the child if it were at an age at which a fare had to be paid. Such people will benefit greatly from being able to go to the local general practitioner, which may be as much as a quarter of an hour's walk from home, rather than travelling by public transport for an hour and a half to a free hospital facility. Some people in the country are in this situation but I expect that the greatest immediate advantage will be to people, such as the person I have mentioned, who will be able to afford to go to a local general practitioner rather than to the free hospital system which is so far away.

What will be the position of some people who are not well enough to get to a hospital but who are probably not ill enough to be an inpatient at a hospital? They will be able to get the doctor to come to them rather than travel a long distance to a free hospital. This is one of the reasons why we need this system in Queensland as well as in other parts of Australia. It should be remembered if we are talking about Queensland that through Medicare there will be a boost to the funds which will be made available to the Queensland hospital system. In 1982-83, under the Fraser Government, $93m was paid to Queensland in what could be identified as health grants. In the first Hawke Budget, $131m was paid which is a 41 per cent increase. Following the first full year of Medicare operating, the figure will be $173m, an 86 per cent increase over the funds allocated by the former Federal Government to Queensland's public hospitals.

Look into the future of Medicare. I see Medicare being widely accepted by the Australian community. No political leader in the future, despite what is being said by some honourable senators opposite at the moment, will dare suggest that Medicare will not be maintained. But, even more importantly, no political leader will dare dismantle Medicare in the way that the previous Prime Minister dismantled Medibank. The health of every person in Australia is precious. It is to this Government's credit that it is ensuring that every person in Australia will be able to afford health care. When the original Medibank scheme was introduced it was, to a large extent, due to the tireless work of the current Minister for Foreign Affairs, Bill Hayden. I often think that Mr Hayden did not receive the credit that he justly deserved for bringing Medibank to fruition. This scheme, Medicare, owes a great deal to the hard work and tenacity of the Minister for Health, Dr Neal Blewett. He deserves credit for having brought Medicare this far. I am sure he will deserve further credit when Medicare is up and running on 1 February next year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before saying anything else about the package of Bills before us, I too would like to refer to a number of comments made by Senator Lewis. On behalf of the members of the Australian Medical Association, the Doctors Reform Society, the General Practitioners Society in Australia, the Australian Association of Surgeons and any other associations of medical practitioners, I would like to take umbrage at the gratuitous insult that Senator Lewis offered to members of the medical profession in insisting that the majority of them, if not all of them, offer special treatment either to members of their own profession or to people in influential positions. I do not believe they do. Before Senator Lewis came into this place he practised as a lawyer. It may well be that it is the practice of some lawyers-it may even have been the practice of Senator Lewis, I do not know-to offer this sort of preferential treatment. I do not believe that the majority of medical practitioners in this country would put people of wealth, influence or those in specific professions before other people in need, simply because of their status .

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Lewis also said that he believed Medicare was not about improving health care; it was about paying for health care. I suggest that while I am not 100 per cent satisfied with this legislation I realise that in fact the principle behind the legislation before us today is to improve the payment of health care. Senator Lewis said that we were not talking about disadvantaged people. He referred to the three million pensioners, unemployed people and other beneficiaries-I presume that is who he was referring to-who are already entitled to free medical treatment in public hospitals and for whom most doctors will bulk bill. He carefully avoided mentioning another several million people who are in the twilight zone-that is, between those who qualify for pensioner health benefit cards or disadvantaged persons' cards and those who are well enough off to be able to fund themselves. The previous Government's disadvantaged persons' card, with its absolute cut off limit, did not help a significant number of low income earners who will be assisted by this legislation because the levy applies to taxable income with certain ceilings applicable according to marital status, the number of dependants and so on. The group of people who fall into that twilight area, if one likes, and who were not catered for under the previous Government's health provision will now be catered for.

The intention of the package of Bills before us today is to introduce a universal basic health insurance scheme funded by a one per cent levy on taxable income. It will take into account a number of criteria, as I said, relating to the number of dependants and so on. The hysterical assertions expressed by Senator Lewis and by some other members of his Party would be more believable if they had tried to do something about their concerns relating to this legislation in the past three months instead of simply limiting themselves to scaremongering tactics and inflammatory statements relating to what sort of dismantling job they will do if they get back into power.

There is no question that the Government promised the Medicare legislation to the people of Australia both before and during the election campaign. If this Government has a mandate for anything at all, it has a mandate to introduce a universal basic health insurance scheme funded by a one per cent levy. I find it rather strange that a previous speaker in this debate launched into such a vitriolic attack on the levy scheme and on its size when in fact a previous Liberal government, in one of its many messings about with the health care of this country, introduced its own 2 1/2 per cent levy scheme. A previous Liberal Prime Minister was not at all averse to appropriating a social security levy into Consolidated Revenue by some sort of sleight of hand. I find these convenient lapses in memory by some members of the Liberal Party rather extraordinary. Not only does the Government have a mandate for this legislation which was expressed on 5 March but also the latest opinion polls show that the majority of Australians in all States favour this scheme.

It has one other element that relates particularly to me, and that is that part of the Australian Democrats' health policy called for universality as far as basic health insurance is concerned. One of the problems that have existed in the past is that the young and the healthy have been able to opt out, thereby placing an unnecessary burden on those people who either are responsible in their attitude to health insurance or need it for some reason or anticipate that they will need it.

Universality is an essential element in this area, particularly as it relates to basic health care. Therefore, because it is part of our platform, because the Government has a mandate and because the majority of Australians approve of a universal basic health insurance scheme we have always said that we would support the Government's legislation in this area. I repeat that commitment now. That does not, of course, mean that we have no reservations about the way in which the Government is approaching the administration of the scheme. While we support the universality element and applaud this Government's attempt to take into account ability to pay as far as health insurance is concerned, we are concerned about a number of areas. We would prefer-indeed our health platform indicates this-that people have a choice of either taking basic health insurance through the levy or going to the fund of their choice. Nevertheless, I repeat that the Government proposed a mandatory levy which was approved by the people of Australia. Should a succeeding Liberal government choose to go back to the alternative scheme, I am quite sure that the Australian Democrats will look sympathetically at that area. We were concerned too about the original plan for Medibank Private to be given sole agency rights. In a very short time that would have destroyed the existence of the other private health insurance funds.

Senator Crowley said in her speech that the funds are not complaining at the moment. I am not entirely sure that I or the funds would agree. At the moment their complaints are muted. Certainly, they are not complaining in the way in which they complained in the early 1970s; neither, of course, is the Australian Medical Association or any other responsible, reasonable organisation. However, that is largely due to the fact that, over the last three months, the funds, the AMA, the private hospitals and the Australian Democrats have engaged in very extensive negotiations with the Government. In doing that, we have achieved a number of concessions, some of which are written into the legislation and some of which are matters for ministerial direction, which we believe have mitigated the most dangerous elements of the Medibank Private monopoly. These concessions include the deregulation of the funds so that the private health insurance funds can diversify and go beyond simply supplying health insurance to providing other sorts of insurance and engaging in other activities if their entrepreneurial skills and desires should move them in that direction.

Certain constraints are applied to Medibank Private, for example, regarding its advertising principles. It has been agreed by the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) that Medibank Private will not piggyback with Medicare in its advertisements. For that reason I must say that I am a little concerned at reports that I have received in the last 24 hours that a Western Australian newspaper has been carrying an advertisement for Medicare which has contained also an advertisement for Medibank Private. I have not seen a copy of that advertisement, but I have been told that it exists. I would appreciate it if the Minister could make some sort of investigation into that matter and repeat his assurance that he will be directing that Medibank Private advertising and Medicare advertising do not take place in any combined form.

In addition, constraints have been placed on Medibank Private with regard to blending its running costs with those of Medicare, with sharing the sites of around 86 new Medicare offices and some others that will prevent Medibank Private from being given an unnecessary advantage over the other private health insurance funds. The Government has agreed to eliminate to a very large extent the two-stop shopping inconvenience by making available Medicare forms at the offices of the other private funds so that these can be used as a sort of post box element. The Government agreed also to take on board-in fact, it has introduced a very complicated amendment to this effect-some form of gap cover for those people who are chronically ill or whose health bills for a specific reason become excessive in any financial year.

At this point I wish to refer again to something that Senator Lewis said, namely, that he believes-in fact, his comments were that the Liberal Party believes-that if people do not pay something for their medical services they do not appreciate them. Presumably the Liberal Party as a bloc-certainly Senator Lewis believes that the Liberal Party as a bloc-is opposed to gap insurance. Since it believes that paying this 15 per cent means that people will appreciate the medical services which they receive presumably, therefore, they will not be tempted to treat themselves to some patient induced overservicing. While I am dealing with Senator Lewis's speech, I must say that I agree with him about assertions relating to overservicing induced by medical practitioners. Before I became a member of the Senate, I had some involvement with the field of mathematics. I learnt very quickly that conclusions drawn only from raw statistical data frequently miss the point by a mile. I would suggest that something other than computer listings of various doctors' treatment habits should be used before overservicing is determined.

During the recess three weeks ago, the Government agreed to place limits on Medibank Private's contributor numbers in each State and to make easier the amalgamations of the funds. As I said a moment ago, some of these provisions are enshrined in the legislation, others are matters of ministerial direction. I would like an assurance repeated in this place, if possible, from the Government that those areas which have not required legislation and which are not covered in the legislation will still apply, as the Minister indicated during the negotiation discussions that they would. The concessions that have been arrived at by negotiations with the AMA, the Voluntary Health Insurance Association of Australian, the private hospital organisations and the Democrats have, I believe , produced a Bill which avoids the worst problems inherent in the British and Canadian systems. I admit that it is not entirely problem free; but, then, what legislation is? I understand that it is something of a truism that any piece of legislation that contains more than 50 words contains at least one loophole. So one is then left to wonder what number of loopholes there are applying to a piece of legislation the size of this omnibus package.

Some of the other concerns which I and my Party have relate to some inconsistencies in the Bill regarding parliamentary scrutiny of government directions, guidelines and so on and the removal of consultation with the Australian Medical Association from the Medical Benefits Advisory Committee or, as it is soon to be known, the Medicare Benefits Advisory Committee. We believe that an organisation which represents a profession which has not only its own interests to look after but also the interests of its patients, ought at least to be consulted when it comes to the MBAC. We are concerned at the definition of a bed day as being 12 hours when it comes to the qualification of a hospital for receipt of a bed day subsidy. We believe that the period ought to be eight hours . A period of twelve hours causes enormous problems for people such as those on dialysis machines and those who go into hospital for an operation which requires a general anaesthetic but which does not require an overnight stay. If the Government insists on retaining the 12-hour rule, I believe it will lead to unnecessary extensions of overnight stays. In the case of minor operations on children or on the mothers of children, it will cause unnecessary problems in families. I have raised these matters with the Minister. I hope that he has given them some thought and consideration.

The Liberal Opposition has indicated that it has prepared some amendments in this area. If they cover all the concerns which we have raised, we will certainly be looking at supporting them. If they have not raised amendments relating to the AMA's consultative role and the 12-hour rule, we shall move in that direction.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are included, Senator.

—I thank Senator Baume. However, I must state at this point that support for some or all of the Opposition's amendments relating to some inconsistencies in the legislation, consultation with the medical profession and the 12-hour rule are contingent on this legislation being passed by the Parliament this week. Most people are aware that a piece of legislation has to pass both Houses of Parliament in identical form before it can be enacted.

SPEECH.PARA: If any member of the Opposition chooses to filibuster through this legislation so that it drags beyond the stipulated time-heaven knows, it was debated in full in the House of Representatives- we will be forced to move the amendments that we consider necessary to improve this legislation by way of private members legislation instead of supporting the Opposition's amendments. I trust, however, that members of the Opposition in this chamber are sufficiently responsible, as was indicated by their lead speaker, Senator Baume, not to conduct some sort of ambush activity on this matter. I pay Senator Baume a compliment for restricting his speech to 20 minutes. I applaud him for that.

There are a number of other issues that we would like to raise. I will raise them in the second reading debate instead of during the Committee stage in order to limit as much as possible debate at that stage. Those concerns related particularly to the categorisation of private hospitals and the rigidity or otherwise of the guidelines that apply. I am thinking, in particular, of bush nursing hospitals, psychiatric hospitals and other hospitals which may be in isolated areas where people have no opportunity to get to a public hospital or which, for one reason or another, have a high staff-patient ratio. I am concerned also at the provisions relating to the role of visiting medical officers in public hospitals which do not restrict specialist activities to sessional work. I would be interested to know what the contractual arrangements are, how flexible they are likely to be and who is likely to be party to determining them, as well as what will happen to existing contracts.

I do not think it is going too far to say that there has not been a great deal of logic and sweet reason in some parts of the debate on Medicare which has taken place over the last few months. That has been true of people on both sides of the debate. There have also been some unfortunate and not very subtle hints at revenge for things that happened in the early 1970s. There have been some suggestions of blackmail, some outright bloody-mindedness and the intrusion of certain vested interests, all for their own sakes rather than for any commitment to the greatest good for the greatest number. Thanks to the reasonableness of most people who participated in the negotiations that took place over the last few months I believe that the damage that could have been done has been kept to an absolute minimum.

The legislation that is before us today is a necessary social reform. That it is not without some likely problems is, of course, inevitable. I believe that some of the problems that may occur should be correctable if the Government is prepared to look at them as they arise and take immediate action. It has been asserted that strains will be placed on the public hospital system due to the fact that, under Medicare, basic health care can be provided only at a public hospital. At the moment, people who take up basic health insurance with a private health insurance fund are entitled to go to a private hospital if they so choose. By moving everybody into the public sector and with no means test on the occupancy of a bed, I believe that it could significantly disadvantage pensioners and other disadvantaged people who have been the traditional users of the public health care system. However, this should be patently apparent in a fairly short time. If the Government has any desire to be re-elected I suggest that it move fairly quickly to prevent any excess in that area.

I doubt whether the rather bland and hopeful assertion by the Minister for Health that most doctors will bulk bill will come about. I do not see why the medical profession should be pushed into the position of having to forgo some of its income simply to satisfy some ideology on the part of the present Government . I object to it, in particular, in that I do not think the accounting criteria on which the Government's arguments are based are all that accurate. It simply maintains that some general practitioners will have to lose 15 per cent of their income. When one is on the extraordinarily high incomes that the Government asserts most medical practitioners are on, it says they can well afford that. I suggest, respectfully, that the $11, $12 or $13 or whatever is charged by a medical practitioner for a standard consultation is not all profit or not all the cost of the doctor's time but takes into account, of course, an assortment of overheads. So by lopping off 15 per cent, even allowing for the tidier accounting process that doctors will then use, I think it is dealing some sections of the medical profession a blow heavier than is necessary.

I repeat: This is a socially necessary reform. It is something that the Australian Democrats support for a variety of reasons. We hope that the debate today will allow us to support some, or all, of the Liberal Opposition's amendments relating to consultations with the AMA, relating to the number of hours a bed has to be used before the patient or the hospital qualifies for the Government subsidy and so on. We will not, of course, support the Opposition's amendment to the second reading motion since, of course, we will be supporting the second reading of the Bill. This is not to say we do not believe that there is a role for private health care in this country. We do. I believe that, thanks to the negotiations taken part in by the AMA, the private health insurance funds and the private hospital sector over the past three months, a social reform in which there is a real and long term role for private health care in this country has been achieved. That means a role for private medical practice, the private hospital system and the private health insurance funds. I believe that it will be done with the least confusion to members of the general public and with maximum benefit to the consumers of health care in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government believes that the health insurance legislation which is before the Senate is designed to overcome a great deal of the confusion and difficulties that have taken place since the original Medibank legislation was passed by the Parliament in 1974. There has been a great deal of change, we believe, in the attitude of both the Parliament and the Australian community, including the medical profession, because of the changes that came about as a result of the early introduction of Medibank and the subsequent moves made by the Liberal and National Country Party Government in the following seven years. Those changes have brought about a desire, on the part of the Australian people, to have a comprehensive and understandable health scheme which this legislation seeks to provide.

SPEECH.PARA: The changes in public opinion, therefore, have arisen as a result of the community's experience. I think the mere fact that the federal branch of the Australian Medical Association has indicated its desire to co-operate with the Government's legislation is a radical departure from the attitude that it took almost a decade ago. I think the fact that the Australian Labor Party, by announcing, through Mr Hayden and Dr Blewett, its Medicare proposals more than a year ago, enabled the Australian people to make a value judgment about the improvements in the scheme. We now have a refined and improved Medibank scheme. It obviously found acceptance in the minds of the Australian people. I believe, therefore, that it is a socially important piece of legislation. It is an innovative piece of legislation and its universality has won wide acceptance amongst the Australian people. I believe it will stand the test of time. It is not a piece of legislation which will be changed capriciously by governments as previous legislation was changed from 1975 to 1983.

The main purpose of my entering the debate is to relate the legislation to that section of the Australian community for which I have parliamentary responsibility. I am pleased that the Bills introduced into the Senate today implementing the Government's health insurance scheme make special provision for repatriation beneficiaries. First of all, it should be stressed that repatriation beneficiaries, as Australian citizens, will have access to the benefits of Medicare on an equal footing with other members of the population. However, they will also continue to receive the full range of treatments to which they are presently entitled under existing repatriation arrangements. I have had correspondence and resolutions from ex-service organisations expressing some concern in relation to the immature way in which Opposition spokesmen have attempted to portray the Government's motivations and intentions in this legislation. I want to assure the veterans' organisations that no veteran currently able to receive repatriation benefits in their totality will be affected by the legislation.

The repatriation treatment service will not be changed by the Medicare arrangements. All veterans now entitled to free treatment for all disabilities- that is, personal treatment entitlement card holders, including war widows, ex- prisoners of war, World War I veterans, veterans receiving disability pensions at the 100 per cent rate and above, Second World War veterans with 50 per cent disability pensions and any service pensioners with fringe benefits-will, under this legislation, continue to receive free treatment through the Department of Veterans' Affairs. Those veterans who are covered for specific service-related disabilities will also continue to receive treatment for their conditions.

It is obvious that the Opposition parties are in disarray about the Sex Discrimination Bill, are in disarray about their wages policy and are in disarray in respect of this legislation. Consequently, the point has to be made that the Government has not only a mandate but also a responsibility to put an end to the confusion that has been developed by some rebel doctors and by those on the Opposition benches who see this legislation as some form of discrimination against the medical profession.

Let me return to the influence and the effect that this legislation will have upon my Department. Holders of Department of Veterans' Affairs personal treatment entitlement cards with no dependants will be completely exempted from paying the levy. However, if they have dependants and their taxable income is above the threshold levels included in the legislation, they will pay only half the normal levy. Those veterans probably now have private health insurance to cover their dependants, and as has been indicated by the Government speakers both in the House of Representatives and in the Senate, those people will find that the levy payable will be less than the amount now being paid either to Medibank Private or to one of the private insurance organisations.

I think it is pleasing that the Government amended the Bill in the House of Representatives to recognise de facto relationships on the same basis as married relationships. I think that is an important recognition of changing community standards and values. De facto relationships have long been recognised by repatriation legislation, and similarly social security legislation has recognised those relationships for many years. It would not have been equitable to ignore those relationships under the provisions of this Bill.

The Bill recognises the special position of veterans and the Government's commitment to the care of veterans who have suffered disabilities in the service of their country. The Government's commitment to veterans has been further strengthened in the recent Budget, which provided significant funds for the upgrading of facilities and equipment in repatriation hospitals. Contrary to Senator Lewis's assertion that there would be no improvements under Medicare in medical care or hospital care generally, the passage of this legislation will extend to veterans a greater freedom of choice in terms of their requirements than under existing provisions which require them to go to repatriation hospitals in order to enjoy the benefits from the Department. They will now, of course, have a wider choice and be able to go to other hospitals, perhaps closer to their places of residence, and have more suitable alternatives to those which currently exist. We are used to hearing Senator Lewis and his rhetoric, and obviously we will hear more of that from Senator Walters, who will follow me in this debate. But the improvements to be made in the care of persons will be recognised and will be obvious to those who will benefit as a result of the passage of this legislation by the Senate.

It is worth reminding the Senate of what happened on the last occasion when Medibank was introduced to the Senate and how the Senate took advantage of its majority in those days to remove the levy. Of course we see a rerun of that attitude in the way in which Opposition speakers are committed today. As we read the debate which took place in the House of Representatives, a debate which is echoed in this place, we gladly recognise the philosophical differences. We gladly accept that such differences exist between the Opposition parties and the Australian Labor Party. Their objection to the levy comes largely from the more conservative and reactionary forces in the Opposition. The wets and the dries cannot make up their minds what legislation they should support from time to time but it is known, of course, that many Liberals not only in the community but also in the Parliament accept the advantages of universality that this legislation will provide and that payment for such health services will be according to means. That very principle is embodied in the Medicare legislation- a principle that was not part of the Liberal Party health schemes which, as previous speakers on the Government side have indicated, changed many times in the seven years from 1976 to 1983.

We see, from time to time, evidence of a conservative obsession with private sector spending rather than public sector spending. It is claimed that Medicare will add $1.7 billion to government outlays. But what does it matter whether that money comes from a single government fund rather than the 65 private funds? It still comes out of the pocket. Government revenue comes out of the pockets of citizens, and it is much better and much more rational to place it in one single fund than to have the present multiplicity arrangement. In essence, of course, it makes absolutely no diference to Australia's overall health expenditure. I think in the final analysis it will be found to be much more rational and much more economic.

The dries claim that the one per cent levy will increase taxes by $1 billion. It does not matter that that is an income related tax rather than a flat rate tax which is paid to the health funds. At least the Medicare levy is income related. Therefore, it is affordable, whereas basic private insurance, which is the only way in which citizens can look after their health expenses, costs them at least $14 a week. Of course that cannot be afforded by many of those on low and middle incomes.

Let us just look at the figures: Currently a family on $200 a week pays 7 per cent of its income for basic health care, whereas a family on $50,000 a year pays only 1.4 per cent of its income. Where is the equity in that? The inequity of that situation is why some two million Australians have no health cover either through the private funds or the Commonwealth cover for pensioners, the unemployed and low income groups. Of course, we see an attempt by many people to abuse the pension system because they want to get the fringe benefits. The attempt by these people to get around legislation and to arrange their affairs in such a way as to get themselves out of their tax responsibilities is designed also to get them into the fringe benefit areas for hospital and medical care. So , that enticement that has hitherto existed will be overcome as a result of this legislation and the strict means test that previously applied will lose its relevance to many of our citizens.

The Opposition claims that the one per cent levy is a political ploy unrelated to health costs. However, the private health insurance funds are not able to stand on their own feet without Government assistance. They are propped up with subsidies to the tune of $420 per annum, which the Commonwealth pays in doctors' bills for the privately insured; $100m went to the private funds in reinsurance subsidies to reduce the effect of heavy drawers on the level of premiums; and $ 550m was provided by the Commonwealth as a tax rebate on basic insurance premiums. So in fact the Commonwealth is paying out that money. It is losing revenue to about the same extent as it will collect revenue as a result of the one per cent levy. It is absurd for the Opposition to take the view that it has, because in my belief and in the belief of the Government the Commonwealth is already subsidising that industry very heavily. As part of Medicare we have restructured these subsidies to ensure that the greatest benefit from that money goes to those in the greatest need. That should be the basis of all welfare systems, and of course is the basis of this legislation. We are using that money as well as the income from the one per cent levy to provide affordable health cover for all Australians.

Contrary to what has been said by Opposition speakers, there is no evidence that patients are involved in any of the Medibank frauds. In fact, if there has been any overservicing at all it has been carried out by a few medical people. It is a few medicos who have been found to be involved in the process of overservicing. It is not the citizens. I believe, as the Government believes, that the average citizen of this country plays his part-plays the game in respect of these matters-and will be very happy to see the implementation of this legislation which will restore some sanity to the whole medical and hospital requirements of the Australian people. We have no doubt that once this legislation is passed-in February of 1984 the processes will be effected which will provide universal treatment to all citizens of Australia regardless of who they are and where they are-it will be accepted by the Australian people. That will enable this legislation to be regarded as an important step forward in the health care of Australian citizens and one which I think will endure for all time.
Debate interrupted.
Sitting suspended from 12.44 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy and concerns what Senator Coleman yesterday described as the Government's prevarication on the uranium mining issue. I ask: For what specific reasons has the Government so far refused to allow the mining of uranium at Jabiluka and Koongarra? In particular, is it a fact that the Government has been forced by those Government members opposed to uranium mining not to proceed, or does the Minister believe there is either an insufficient demand for Australia's uranium or insufficient prices for uranium for mining to be economically viable?

—I cannot remember which party Senator Kilgariff is in at the moment. I know he changes around from time to time. Mr Anthony, who is the leader of the party to which Senator Kilgariff once belonged, in December knocked back a draft contract between the Jabiluka partners and the Central Electricity Generating Board of the United Kingdom because the pricing arrangements were not satisfactory. I made that point yesterday and have made it many times before. That is one of the factors that the present Government takes into consideration, as did the previous Government. As has been said countless times in the Senate, general uranium policy is subject to a comprehensive review and is currently scheduled for Cabinet decision next month.

—Has the Attorney- General seen the new Northern Territory Criminal Code? Is he aware of the strong objections which have been raised to the Code? I ask: What action does he propose to take regarding those objections?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen a copy of the new Code which was recently rushed through the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly, although it had been preceded by some months of earlier gestation. My attention and that of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has been drawn to the strong objections to it being voiced by a number of groups apart from the Australian Labor Party Opposition in the Northern Territory. I refer particularly to the Northern Territory Law Society and legal aid and welfare groups concerned with the rights of Aboriginals. On a preliminary examination certainly a number of provisions in the Code concern me as raising really quite fundamental issues of criminal law and procedure and civil liberties.

ANSWER.PARA: In conjunction with the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs I am having the Code fully examined and analysed. As part of that review process I am also considering what, if any, action might be appropriate for the Commonwealth to take. While it is of course the case that the Commonwealth retains full constitutional powers as far as the Northern Territory is concerned, the self- governing status of the Territory, equally obviously, imposes practical limitations on what the Commonwealth can do on matters like this. It may be that redress for any excesses in this legislation will have to await the enactment of national human rights legislation of general application. But certainly the matter is being considered and is under review because it raises very alarming questions about the sensitivity to civil liberty considerations of the present Government in the Northern Territory and has quite profound implications for many citizens of that Territory, not least Aborigines and others who are disadvantaged.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Social Security. I refer to the new Disability Advisory Council which the Government has set up to replace the National Advisory Council for the Handicapped. In view of the Minister's statement at the time of establishing the Council that the Government will be looking to disabled people themselves for advice on Government policy affecting them, is he able to inform the Senate why there is no representative of adult people with psychiatric disabilities and emotional disturbances? Will the Minister assure the Senate that he will have immediate discussions with groups like the Psychiatric Rehabilitation Association with a view to providing these people with a voice on the new Council?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The new Disability Advisory Council of Australia was, as Senator Messner says, established by the Government to replace the National Advisory Council for the Handicapped. I point out that most of the members of the new Council are, in fact, disabled people. They represent a broad spectrum of disabilities, unlike the previous National Advisory Council for the Handicapped. In drawing up the membership of the Council, after consultation with people from various States and organisations, I tried to strike a balance between a broad representation across the States, representation of both males and females and representation of as many disabilities as possible. It is quite obvious that there is no way a Council of 14 members could have a representative of every form of disability. Therefore, we made the representation as broad as possible. We appointed half the Council for two years and the other half for three years, so that in the future we will be able to change the membership. We will be able to rotate it so that eventually every broad group of disabilities will be represented.

ANSWER.PARA: To establish a Council containing a representative of every form of disability in this country would involve making that Council far too large to be an effective representational or consultative body. For that reason we took the action we did. Of course, some groups are not represented-the deaf, for instance . I have had representations from many groups asking why they were not represented. The answer is that in future they will be represented as much as possible. In fact, they will be consulted by their fellow sufferers in future so that we get a much better standard of advice and advice which is much closer to the real feelings of the disabled.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer. I wonder whether he would agree that the problems of the psychiatric disabled are unique and distinct from those of many other groups and therefore demand special consideration.

—I do not deny what Senator Messner says, but I think the same thing could be said about the deaf and many other disabled people. The simple practicalities of the matter are that to try to get representation right across the board is very difficult. In the future we will attempt to have such groups represented.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Has the Government received representations from medical practitioners concerning undue delay in the processing of accounts rendered under bulk billing arrangements? Does the Government concede that such inordinate delay, sometimes amounting to many months, does occur and is likely to dissuade many doctors from jeopardising the cash flow of their practices by using the scheme when Medicare is introduced on 1 February 1984? What assurance can the Government offer that bureaucratic difficulties will be overcome to the benefit of a co-operative relationship between doctors and the Medicare scheme?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Tate says, the Government, and I am sure all honourable senators, have received representations from medical practitioners throughout Australia concerned at the delays caused by the eligibility checking procedures on bulk billing claims which were introduced by the previous Government. I point out that this problem is due entirely to the current complex and discriminatory insurance scheme and the incompetent management in this area by previous Ministers. The previous Government introduced a system of eligibility checking earlier this year which increased the number of claims being rejected from 5.5 per cent to 14 per cent and therefore increased the number of claims requiring double handling in this area by over 150 per cent. So what we have is a bureaucratic maze of cross checking, between the number on the assignment voucher and the social security entitlement records, which is unacceptable to this Government and, I think, should be unacceptable to any government.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Health informs me that he has recently approved the employment of an additional 111 temporary staff to help reduce this backlog of bulk billing claims. As long as we remain with the present insurance system, it will be difficult to provide an acceptable turnaround on those claims. With the implementation of Medicare on 1 February 1984, I believe these problems will be eliminated because the same rate of benefits will be provided to all Australians and therefore the need for eligibility checking will be removed. Combined with the modern on-line processing systems of the Health Insurance Commission, we believe that the delay will be reduced to one or two weeks and this will satisfy the medical profession, the Government and the patients.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I ask him: Has his attention been drawn to reports in various sections of the print media claiming that on last Friday he, Senator Button, told a Press conference that he believed a capital gains tax should be introduced, and further, that he would put the case for the introduction of a capital gains tax to the Government? Are the reports to that effect correct? If they are, when does the Minister expect to put that case to the Government? Does he propose to put the case to the Economic Planning Advisory Council and to seek its support for that view? Would the introduction of the tax advocated by him constitute a clear breach of the election promise given by his party in the recent campaign? If it would, what explanation does he give for advocating a clear breach of yet another election promise made in recent months? Will the introduction of a capital gains tax add a further imposition or difficulty to the accumulation of capital for investment in the development of small business and, therefore, a further impediment to increased private sector employment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am asked whether I have read reports in the newspapers that at a Press conference last Friday I spoke with favour of the introduction of a capital gains tax. Yes, I have read the Press reports and the Press reports, I am happy to say, are correct. I did so advocate that. It is my view that there should be a capital gains tax in Australia and I will continue to advocate it both publicly and within the Government. I am then asked when I will put that case to the Government. I will put it to the Government at every opportunity that I get, and I will continue to do so. Whether I am successful remains to be seen. The question of the introduction of a capital gains tax is a matter for government determination and that determination will be made at the appropriate time. I have no doubt there will be a number of different views within the Government about that issue, in respect of which my view is only one.

ANSWER.PARA: I am asked further whether I will put the case to EPAC. I do not see it as being my function, as a Minister in the Government, to put cases to EPAC. I am reasonably confident that EPAC will examine this issue and may in turn, at an appropriate time, put a case to the Government about it, one way or the other. The function of EPAC is to advise the Government about those matters. No doubt it will put a case. Of course both EPAC and I are entitled to our views about this and will put our respective cases at the appropriate time. I am asked further whether the introduction of a capital gains tax would be a clear breach of the undertaking given by the Government prior to the last election. I invite Opposition senators to possess their souls in patience, to see whether a capital gains tax is introduced and what form it will take, before they leap to conclusions about that question.

I am also asked whether the introduction of a capital gains tax, as advocated by me, would be a further imposition on industry and business and would constitute a further disability to those sectors of the economy. I think it goes without saying that, if I thought that that was so, I would not be advocating a capital gains tax. I do not happen to think that is so at all. One of the disasters this country has suffered over many years is the direction of capital into the wrong areas in the economy. It has been a grave disability to the growth and development of the Australian economy that that has been allowed to go on for so long.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. The implication in the answer is that Senator Button might from time to time, in a desultory way , put his views to the Government if the occasion arises. I ask him: Does he in fact intend to put a case to the Government in favour of the introduction of a capital gains tax, or is he merely going to deal with this matter in the offhand and casual way in which he has just answered my question?

—With the greatest of respect, Mr President, that is not really a supplementary question. The first part of the question was directed towards my state of mind on a particular issue. The second part of the so-called supplementary question was directed towards my style which I find in a sense somewhat offensive. I am asked: Will I adopt a desultory approach to the pursuit of this question or will I adopt the sort of vigorous approach which one sees on the other side of the Senate-honourable senators leaping up every day with relevant questions, driving the Government almost mad with their persistence about particular issues? Will that be my style or will I be desultory about it? I indicated in the earlier part of the question that at the appropriate time, when these matters arose for discussion by the Government, I would put that position.
—You will put your bib in; you will put your little word in.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition has had a supplementary question.

—Senator Chaney keeps on interjecting. He says that I will put my little bib in. What are his interjections all about-putting his little bib in. I imagine that Senator Chaney knows full well that I am not going to rush out of Question Time, pen a case for a capital gains tax and rush around to the Cabinet room with it-of course not. I will do that at the appropriate time.
—Why not? What are you going to do, talk big to the media? Why don't you do something?

—Senator Chaney seems perilously offended by the answer I am giving him. He has a mind like a laser on this issue, if I might say so-bright but very narrow. I have given an answer to the question. If he wants to pursue it further, let him ask me another question.
—Are you going to do anything or not?
—The honourable senator could ask that about anything in government. If he keeps on asking, we will give him answers.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. I ask him whether he has seen an article by Graham Williams on page 1 of the Sydney Morning Herald today entitled 'Now a quarter of Australia survives on welfare . . .' Will he tell the Senate whether the Sydney Morning Herald was correct in including service pensioners in its list of 4,016,470 Australians dependent on Commonwealth benefits as their prime source of income, but in excluding disability pensioners? If not, how much higher should that figure be?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I have seen the article that Senator Giles has referred to , which I think was a very useful article about the changes in the economic scene in Australia in the last decade. The newspaper article indicates a very considerable proportion-one in four-of persons now dependent upon cash payments from the Commonwealth on a regular basis. However, the table does in fact exclude the 410,473 war disability pensioners and their dependants as at June 1983. The Sydney Morning Herald's decision to exclude those persons from the calculation is basically correct because the payments of disability and other related pensions are substantially means-test-free. This means, in effect, that recipients either supplement their disability pensions with adequate and independent sources of income or are eligible for other benefits such as the age or service pension. So most of this latter group would be counted elsewhere in the table. It, of course, shows that there has been a dramatic change in economic conditions so that the Federal Government now has to support a very large proportion of the Australian people. We should bear in mind, of course, that something approaching 800,000 people are in receipt of the unemployment benefit.

ANSWER.PARA: However, this question about the disability pension brings me to an important point. There is a great deal of unjustified confusion amongst veterans in particular, which unfortunately I find some honourable senators opposite have deliberately fanned, about the impact of the foreshadowed assets test on disability pensions. I reiterate, as I have done on a number of occasions, in the strongest possible terms that the Government regards such pensions as compensatory payments for disability suffered during service in war and not as a welfare-related measure. I again assure the Senate that the Government will not be applying any income or assets test to such disability pensions.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs the following question which is divided into three parts: Firstly, does the Government regard Pine Gap, Nurrungar and North West Cape as being in the category of prime nuclear targets in the event of an outbreak of a superpower war? Secondly, if so, does this mean that these areas of Australia have nuclear weapons aimed at them from Soviet bases? Is it the view of the Government that Darwin and Perth, because of their links with nuclear arsenals, and Canberra, because of its strategic significance, are also prime nuclear targets?
—We can only hope so.
—I want no help in my question from the intellectuals of the Liberal Party from Western Australia or Tasmania.
—Order! Will the honourable senator ask his question.
—I acknowledge that is a contradiction in terms, Mr President.
—Will the honourable senator continue with his question.

—Finally, so that a logical and reasoned debate on this issue can take place among Australians, does the Government agree or disagree with the recent view of the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, which I understand was unanimous, that if United States bases and military presence were removed from Australia the possibility of Australia being a nuclear target would be very unlikely?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government addressed these matters recently in the statement by the Minister for Foreign Affairs on the outcome of the review of ANZUS. The view that has been taken about the first of the matters that Senator Chipp raised is this: The contingency of global nuclear war, despite the horrors associated with that, is, for the moment anyway, one that continues to be assessed as remote on the basis that mutual deterrence between the superpowers continues to be an enormously powerful constraint.

ANSWER.PARA: In the event of global nuclear war the Government, of course, recognises that there would be a risk of the joint Australian-United States defence facilities being under attack. However, the degree of likelihood or the likely priority of such attacks on the joint defence facilities could be only a matter for speculation.

TALK.START.PARA: —But what is the Government's view? I am asking that.

—I am telling the honourable senator what the Government's view is. Darwin and Perth are not linked with nuclear arsenals any more than are any other ports in Australia that are visited by foreign warships. Such port calls are usually for periods of less than a week and are for rest and recreation purposes. Peacetime visits of this nature are not assessed by the Government as presenting significant risks of attack on the ports concerned; nor is Canberra taken as having the kind of strategic significance that is implied in the question.

ANSWER.PARA: The B52 aircraft which use the facilities at Darwin are engaged only in sea surveillance and navigation training operations. These aircraft are unarmed and carry no bombs. There is no United States military presence in the sense of combat units stationed in Australia. If the question seeks to hypothesise a situation in which there were no joint defence facilities in Australia and no United States military units, either ships or aircraft, visiting Australia, there would have to be weighed in the balance, in answering the question that Senator Chipp finished with, the loss of the contribution that would thus be made to the overall deterrence of nuclear war which those joint facilities make and the weakening which that would represent of the co-operation in defence matters which is taken as supporting Australia's security.
The general view of the Government on this matter remains as summarised by the Minister for Foreign Affairs in his statement on 15 September. I finish by quoting him:
. . . the contribution made by the . . . facilities to the deterrence of nuclear war fully justifies any risk that might be seen as arising from our having those facilities in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. It was because I had carefully read the Minister's statement of 15 September that I asked this question. The Minister's statement of 15 September gives no answers as to whether any points in Australia are regarded by either the Government-by that, I mean the Australian Labor Party-or the Foreign Affairs Department as a nuclear target. Is not a major known function of the North West Cape base communications with United States Navy's nuclear powered and nuclear armed submarines which carry 5, 000 nuclear warheads? Is not the North West Cape one of only three such bases in the world and the most powerful of all three? In view of that, does or does not the Government list North West Cape as a prime nuclear target in the event of an outbreak of a nuclear war between the two superpowers?

—I repeat what I said as to Perth, Darwin and Canberra. The answer is no, they are not assessed to be nuclear targets in the sense in which Senator Chipp asked his question. As to the joint United States-Australia defence facilities to which he referred again in his supplementary question, the assessment is that there would be a risk of attack in the event of a nuclear war situation.
