Where we would rank in the scale of potential targets around the globe is something which has to be a matter for speculation and on which the Government has no clearer information than that which I have already indicated.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Recent submissions to me have voiced concern about how the allocation in the Budget for women's shelters will be distributed. The worry is that much of the money will be used to help States or Territories that have lagged behind in providing shelters in their States or Territories, to the detriment of those States or Territories which have been more forward in such provisions. Could the Minister give details of how the allocations will be distributed across Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like Senator Crowley, I have had various submissions put to me about how we may or may not distribute the extra money which was provided in the Budget for women's shelters. Honourable senators will know that at the moment funds for women's shelters are in fact distributed by the States through the community health grant. In this Budget we allocated an extra $4m which was in fact in addition to the money which was already spent by the States through Federal Government funds on women's refuges.

ANSWER.PARA: We are establishing in the Department of Social Security a section to deal with women's emergency services. It is through this section that the $4m will in fact be distributed. At the moment neither I nor the Government has made any decision as to the exact distribution of these funds. One would imagine that it would probably have to be distributed in the way it is being distributed at the moment while we are negotiating with the State governments as to the future of this program. One would imagine that the money would be distributed on the basis of the number of existing shelters or population, or on a combination of both. As I say, no decision has in fact been made. We hope that the money will go to improve the working conditions and the general conditions in women's shelters, which are a very good example of the sort of exploitation of those people who provide the services. This should be corrected in the future and will be corrected as the women's emergency services program develops. I cannot give Senator Crowley an exact answer on how that money will be distributed State by State but at the moment there is no intention, as far as I am aware, to distribute the money in the way she suggested.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister for Industry and Commerce recall telling the Senate on 10 May this year that a review by his Department of the system of tariff preferences for developing countries 'ought to be completed, possibly by the end of this month but certainly by early next month'? Is it a fact that more than four months later that review has not yet reached finality? What are the reasons for such an inordinate delay in an area which has such serious ramifications for the jobs of many Australians, as the case of the Korean wire manufacturers mentioned yesterday so graphically illustrates? Is this delay just another example of the argument on protection policy which has become so evident in recent days and has included an apparent leadership war involving the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, supporting the former Leader, Mr Hayden, against the Deputy Leader and Minister for Trade, Mr Bowen, and the Leader of the Government in the Senate and Minister for Industry and Commerce, Senator Button, with Dr Theophanous as Chairman of the Caucus Industry Committee involving himself in a way which is not as yet quite so specific?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I recall saying something to the Senate about this issue of the Australian system of tariff preferences and I accept Senator Rae's implied view that it was on 10 May. I certainly said that I hoped the review would be completed shortly. The answer is that it has not been completed as shortly as I would wish because a number of complications have arisen in relation to that view, including questions of our bilateral trade relations with certain countries and so on which are very complex issues. I can only repeat what I said on 10 May, I hope with more precision: I hope that that review one way or another will be completed very shortly and an announcement made about it.

ANSWER.PARA: I am asked whether this is in any sense a by-product of the argument which agitates the Opposition about protection policy, an argument which seems to have been carried on in the media between certain Ministers in the Government and in respect of which I hoped Senator Rae would have been charitable enough to suggest that I played a mediating role. I hope Senator Rae understands that it is not an aspect of that argument. A number of other factors are involved. Although that argument has broad relevance, it is not something which has delayed the review of the Australian system of tariff preferences. It is desirable that in a community which is very much divided on issues of this kind there should be debate about the importance of those issues. It does not seem to me to be important that it should be carried on by Ministers in a government even, provided it is done in a constructive way. It is far more important to have a public debate and far less sordid to have a public debate about protection than about sex.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask whether the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs recalls making the following statement on 18 May this year in relation to teaching facilities at a relocated Queen Victoria Medical Centre in Clayton:

QUESTION.PARA: We support the need for these facilities to move with the relocation of the Hospital to Clayton and I will be sympathetically considering the recommendation on funding from the TEC.
In light of this statement, when can we expect the final go-ahead for the project?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the concerns expressed by people who support the relocation of medical teaching facilities in the new Queen Victoria Medical Centre in the Federal electorate of Bruce. Recognising these, we have sought further advice from the Tertiary Education Commission as to how soon and at what cost these facilities can be supported by the Commonwealth. As the honourable senator would be aware, there is an enormous range of demands on the budget available to the TEC for the next year and I think the question of a special provision for the Monash University Medical School will be dealt with in the next triennial report of the TEC, which will be published next year.

—My question of the Minister representing the Treasurer is in two parts. Will new imposts announced last night in New South Wales, for example on the cost of petrol or cigarettes, add to the consumer price index? If so, what allowances were provided in the forecast Australian annual inflation rate of 7.5 per cent for price rises arising from State government Budgets?

—The answer to the first part of the question is that of course such increases in State taxes, unless they are absorbed somewhere else, will be reflected in the consumer price index. Petrol will have far less impact in the short term than cigarettes for the same amount of tax revenue because cigarettes feed 100 per cent and immediately into the CPI; about half the petrol which is consumed is not covered directly by the CPI. Although it can be argued that there will be second and third round and nth round effects which will ultimately add to the total expenditure on items included in the CPI an amount equal to the tax, in the case of petrol that impact will be significantly delayed. In summary , if one is to compare different types of taxes, whether imposed by State or Federal governments, and evaluate their effect on the CPI in the short term, and if one believes that any tax which increases the CPI is undesirable, increases in sales tax on cigarettes are probably the worst in that respect. An increase on petrol is only about half as bad. In regard to the second part of the question, I do not know what allowances, if any, were made by Treasury when estimating the 7 1/2 per cent year on year increase in the consumer price index. I will refer that to the Treasurer to see whether any information can be obtained.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Finance aware that the expense of caption television decoding equipment is out of the economic reach of many deaf people? At present the commercial television networks are supporting the captioning venture but, if the deaf and hard of hearing are prevented from having access to this service for economic reasons, television stations could be in a position to use poor decoder sales as an excuse to withdraw from sponsorship of the sub-titling service. Therefore, can the Minister have investigated sales tax exemption on decoding equipment, which would help to alleviate the present situation? Furthermore, can the Minister undertake to investigate a complete review of sales tax on all technical aids used by handicapped persons in their homes?

—I am not familiar with the matters which Senator Reynolds raised. All that I can do in response is to say that I will refer the question to the Minister for his views and to see whether he will consider the review as she suggested.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: MATRICULATION RESULTS IN THE AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs approve of today's announcement that there will be behind the scenes adjustments of this year's matriculation examination results which will give artificially improved outcomes for girls only in the Australian Capital Territory year 12 school assessments? Is this affirmative action for girls? Does this positive discrimination in favour of girls in the Australian Capital Territory only possess any integrity? Is it unfair to other year 12 students in Australia? Even if last year it was found 'that girls were not scoring as well as boys in the matriculation results', is that justification for now rigging next year's results to favour girls, or should it not lead to considering improved teaching resources for girls? Finally, does the Minister approve the assessment of school performance on the basis of merit or on the basis of affirmative action with a sex bias?

—The Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority, which is the body responsible for assessment procedures at the end of secondary schooling in the Australian Capital Territory, has made a decision with regard to those assessment procedures which has nothing to do with affirmative action. The decision was not intended to create any advantage for girls but to remove a disadvantage which had been identified as a result of research into the operation of the Australian scholastic aptitude test in the Australian Capital Territory. I do not have available to me here the details of the particular bias that has been established, but it was established by very authoritative education researchers. Ways in which scores were assessed and the loadings for different subjects were found objectively to be discriminatory against girls. The bias is being removed and in this year's ASAT assessment procedures there will be no bias against girls or against boys. Because of that the merit principle will be unviolated by the procedures.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Will the Minister again give consideration to the final parts of my question, with more time, so that members of the public may understand and have confidence in the important matriculation assessments that have effect not only in the Australian Capital Territory but also in the Australian Capital Territory vis-a-vis all other matriculation and so that they will understand that there is an objective assessment of merit in school performance?

—I will certainly undertake to make a public statement to the effect that there will be an objective test of merit of students completing their secondary schooling in the Australian Capital Territory. I do not think any concern is justified on this score. The particular kind of assessment that we have in secondary schooling in the Australian Capital Territory has proved very successful. The success can be measured in terms of the success that students coming out of the secondary school system here have had in securing places in a whole range of subjects in universities throughout Australia. All tertiary institutions throughout Australia accept assessment procedures in the Australian Capital Territory, including the ASAT test, and I am sure that they will continue to do so.

—My question, which is directed to the Attorney-General, refers to the ever increasing popularity of commercial video movies for use within the home. Is the Attorney-General aware that although most video movies bear a basic classification code, actual censorship practised in the home is often extremely neglectful of these guidelines, particularly where children and young people are concerned? As an adjunct to the proposed legislation in this area, will the Attorney-General consider instigating an educational campaign, firstly, to explain film classification codes and their application and, secondly, to promote community awareness of the proven detrimental effects on children and young people of watching violent and pornographic films?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Elstob's question implies, the Government is proceeding with legislation to get some rationality into the system governing video movies for home use. A new uniform system of censorship classification was agreed to at a meeting in Brisbane in July by Commonwealth and State Ministers responsible for censorship matters. The principle underlying the agreement was essentially to ensure maximum freedom for adults to view what they want to in the privacy of their own homes, but at the same time to give guidance to consumers at the point of sale as to what they are buying or hiring and placing some limits on what can be openly displayed or sold to children. The particular legislative model that emerged from that meeting is in process now of implementation with a system of classification, accompanied by appropriate point of sale controls. At the Commonwealth level, regulations are being prepared at the moment to put the system into place. They will be promulgated, hopefully, around November, with an appropriate time lapse to enable vendors and hirers to gear up. We imagine that the system will be in place, at least so far as the Australian Capital Territory is concerned, by February next year.

ANSWER.PARA: One element in that proposed legislative system is for classification labels to be applied to video tapes for sale or hire running parallel with those now applied in the cinema, namely, the classifications G, NRC, M and R, but with a further category X to be added for stronger material which would be refused cinema showing but is nonetheless appropriate for private consumption, in accordance with the principles I have just indicated. Some categories of material will be refused classification altogether. They include child pornography and other very extreme material of that order of offensiveness. Continuing attention is being paid to what the guidelines should be that are appropriate for each one of those layers of classification.

Attention is also being given to clarify some of those labels because there is consumer uncertainty about them. In particular, there is uncertainty about what precisely are the connotations in the familiar cinema classification NRC. A proposal is being considered by the Ministers for both cinemas and video tapes which would replace the classification NRC with the expression more familiar to television viewers, parental guidance, PG, or parental guidance recommended, PGR . I hope that that will serve some of the objectives to which Senator Elstob's question was directed. Whether the Government should go further than that and mount some kind of educational campaign designed to draw the attention of consumers-adults who have charge presumably of these video tapes in the home environment-to the possible dangers associated with particular kinds of material is something to which the Government will have to give further consideration. Certainly there has been no consideration of that at the moment, but it is something that I will ensure is put on the agenda for a subsequent meeting of the Ministers concerned with these matters. Such a meeting is scheduled to be held later this year.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I direct a question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I have noted reports to the effect that the Victorian Government is considering a 25 per cent public interest in the Alcoa development at Portland. Has the Commonwealth Government given any undertaking to assist Victoria in the financing of an investment of this nature?

—I think the Commonwealth Government has been kept informed of the negotiations between the Victorian Government and Alcoa by both parties. However , as I understand it no undertakings have been given by the Commonwealth Government.

—Can the Minister representing the Minister for Finance advise the Senate whether Dr Shrian Oskar owes money to the Commonwealth? If so, has the Commonwealth been able to recover any of the money? Can the Minister advise whether any other governments are owed money by Dr Oskar or whether the same gentleman has tried to dupe other governments?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the first part of the question is yes. The Commonwealth has not yet recovered any of the $2m awarded in its favour against Dr Oskar by the Supreme Court of Western Australia in April. The circumstances behind that are that Dr Oskar had personally guaranteed a $2m Commonwealth loan to establish an oil seeds plant at Bunbury in Western Australia. The State Government had also guaranteed loans of, I think, $4m or $5m. The Commonwealth lent the money on the personal guarantee of Dr Oskar, having first checked with reputable banks that he did, in fact, have funds of that magnitude. That was done by the previous Government. I say that not in a political sense but just for the record. When Dr Oskar's personal guarantee was called on because the company had failed, Dr Oskar denied that it was his signature on the document of guarantee. That was the matter which was contested in court. The court found that it was Dr Oskar's signature and that he was, therefore, personally responsible for the repayment of the $2m Commonwealth loan. On the day that the Supreme Court decision was handed down in Western Australia, Dr Oskar was staying in a suite at the Parmelia Hilton International. He disappeared that night and has not been heard of since, to the best of my knowledge, although until recently some negotiations were still under way for the repurchase, on behalf of Dr Oskar, of the assets of the oil-seed processing company which had failed in Western Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: In the second part of his question Senator Colston asked whether Dr Oskar had gypped or swindled any other governments. The answer to that is also yes. He left behind a string of similar deals in Fiji, Dubai, Ireland and New Zealand before he came to Western Australia. After he had set up the deal in Western Australia he moved to Queensland where the Queensland Premier approved a $6m loan guarantee, in spite of strong resistance by the then Treasurer and Liberal Party leader, Dr Edwards, and resistance also from the Queensland Graingrowers Association, a body with which normally one would expect the Queensland Premier and his Party to have a very close association. Very luckily, quite fortuitously , the proposal did not proceed. Had it proceeded, presumably the Queensland taxpayers would have been left whistling for $6m for a loan guarantee, just as the Commonwealth is now whistling for the $2m it has not been able to recover from Dr Shrian Oskar. I do not know whether, as some people might believe, the Queensland Premier also considered appointing Dr Oskar as the director for industrial development, along with Milan Brych as the director of health and Stephen Horvarth as the Minister for nuclear development, or whether the extraordinary lengths to which the Queensland Premier went, riding roughshod over his coalition partner, over industrial groups with direct interest--

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. The whole object of this exercise is quite clear. Mr President, you made a couple of motions towards the Minister as he spoke. I suggest that he is outside the Standing Orders. This has nothing to do with his portfolio responsibilities and he should be called to order.
—I have listened to the Minister closely. I think he is still answering the question that was asked by Senator Colston. I ask him to confine his answer to that question.

—Certainly, Mr President. As I said, this particular crook, this international con man with a record in Fiji, Dubai, Ireland, New Zealand and Western Australia of gypping governments, was then adopted by the Queensland Premier in spite of the resistance of his coalition partner-I suppose that never did count for very much in Queensland-and in spite of the strenuous opposition of the industrial group with a direct interest in this matter, the Queensland Graingrowers Association. I do not know whether, as some say, the Premier's propensity to sponsor Dr Oskar and insist on approving a guarantee for a $6m loan has any relationship to the Bjelke-Petersen Foundation and whatever Dr Oskar may have done for that. That may be so but I do not intend to speculate on it.
—I raise a point of order. Pursuant to Standing Order 363 I seek to have laid before the Senate the document from which the Minister was quoting in answering this question.
—Does the Minister choose to table that document?
—There is no document. There is a sheet of handwritten notes which include notes relevant to another question.
—Is the Minister tabling the document?
—I am quite happy to table it.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ROYAL COMMISSION ON AUSTRALIA'S SECURITY AND INTELLIGENCE AGENCIES

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Attorney-General. I ask whether his attention has been drawn to some recent published statements in Australia by a Mr Victor Marchetti, a former officer of the Central Intelligence Agency, who is still in Australia, as far as I know. His statements have been critical of evidence given by officers of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation and, I think, the Director-General of ASIO before the Hope Royal Commission on Australia's Security and Intelligence Agencies. Are not some of these statements about matters which are directly at issue before the Royal Commission? If so, has the Attorney-General taken any action in regard to these statements or has he instructed government counsel to do so?

—The Government has a commitment to robust free speech in matters generally and also so far as the Hope Royal Commission is concerned, which is just as well, given the extent to which that right has been exercised by not only Victor Marchetti but also all sorts of other people during the tenure of the Commission. I have not had specifically drawn to my attention any remarks which could constitute formal contempt of the Commission. Certainly the Commission itself has not drawn anything to my attention as justifying examination along those lines. I certainly have not instructed counsel to take any course of action in relation to those remarks, whatever they may have been.

—I direct a question to the Attorney-General. Yesterday I received a copy of an open letter to the Attorney-General from Ray O'Shannassy, who is at present in the Goulburn Gaol as a result of conflict between himself and a magistrate in the Australian Capital Territory. On reading the letter it seems to me that Mr O'Shannassy has a case against the magistrate. On a previous occasion the magistrate was forced by direction of a Supreme Court Judge to stand down from the case. The situation now is that since 5 September Mr O' Shannassy has been in the Goulburn Gaol. The possibility is that he will continue to be in the gaol for some time. What action can the Attorney-General take to see that Mr O'Shannassy is given reasonable justice and is immediately freed from the circumstance in which he finds himself?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did receive what purports to be an open letter to me from Mr O'Shannassy dated 14 September. Furthermore, a member of my staff did have a discussion with a delegation putting Mr O'Shannassy's case. I am familiar with the circumstances of the matter to which Senator Georges referred. The situation briefly is this: Mr O'Shannassy has been arrested on various charges, including refusing to leave Commonwealth premises when directed to do so by a police officer, malicious damage to Commonwealth property, loitering and some other charges as well. In his letter he refers to his appearance before the Canberra Court of Petty Sessions on 5 September before the Chief Magistrate. I understand he refused then to indicate whether he was seeking bail. He was remanded in custody, as Senator Georges said, in Goulburn Gaol. On 6 September he was offered bail of $250 on certain conditions, including a condition that he not go on to the grounds of Havelock House, which is the area where the disputation had arisen. He declined bail on those conditions and was returned to Goulburn Gaol to await his hearing in January. In his letter he says that he objects to the condition because he needs access to Havelock House for the police freedom of information centre which is located there and to work with the homeless action organisations. He also alleged, as Senator Georges said, ineptitude, bias and various other defaults on the part of the Canberra magistracy and the Chief Magistrate in particular.

ANSWER.PARA: I believe that the administration of justice in the courts should not be interfered with by the Attorney-General except for very good cause indeed where something fundamental seems to have gone astray. I have taken steps to monitor the situation and satisfy myself that nothing has gone fundamentally astray in this particular case. There have been further developments in the case as follows: Yesterday, Mr O'Shannassy was before Mr Dainer, SM, on another matter. It will be appreciated that Mr O'Shannassy is a fairly regular visitor to the Canberra courts. Mr Dainer received the papers in question relating to Mr O' Shannassy's present incarceration. Mr Dainer offered Mr O'Shannassy amended bail conditions to allow him to go to Havelock House if he had the permission of its occupiers. But Mr O'Shannassy refused, saying that he would be letting down his fellow homeless action organisers. Furthermore, yesterday-this is important in the light of the matter that Senator Georges raised and which I mentioned about his appearance date being next January, unless it is amended-the hearing was brought forward to 29 September, at considerable inconvenience, I might add, to other defendants who arguably have an equal right to be heard.

TALK.START.PARA: —They were not in gaol, though.

—No, but it would appear to be the case that the system has done as much as it could be reasonably expected to do to accommodate the demands being made upon it by Mr O'Shannassy. I will continue to monitor the situation to ensure that, so far as I can determine, there is no fundamental miscarriage of justice involved in this case. But it would appear that Mr O'Shannassy is not going out of his way to alleviate the situation in which he finds himself.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology. Is not the Government being hypocritical in its support for high technology when, in the Department of Defence, 80 people will be taken out of the Defence Science and Technology Organisation because of a lack of funding in that area?
—It appears that the question is directed to me.
—Don't you know that you look after Barry?

—I am grateful to the Opposition for constructive interjections. I was asked whether the Government is being hypocritical. That is an outrageous suggestion which I refute. With regard to the more specific point in the question about the transfer of personnel of the Department of Defence, I will ask the Minister for advice. Senator Watson is concerned about 80 personnel. I will find out about them and give him an answer.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Jack Evans proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Government's abdication of its responsibilities to the people in small businesses, resulting in the exacerbation of an already perilous situation for many employers and employees in this vital sector of the economy.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —This may be an unusual subject to propose for discussion as a matter of public importance, although I am sure the topic is dear to the heart of practically every honourable senator in this chamber. The matter of public importance states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's abdication of its responsibilities to the people in small businesses, resulting in the exacerbation of an already perilous situation for many employers and employees in this vital sector of the economy.

The topic is unusual because this is neither an attack on the Government nor an attack on Her Majesty's Opposition but is, in fact, a plea to all parliamentarians on behalf of the deserted people in this country in small businesses who fall into the following categories: The self-help people, the individualistic people, the entrepreneurs of this country, the people with resilience and the people who put their lives and their livelihoods on the line. I might add that they include most farmers. In other words, I suggest this is a profile of a typical Australian trier.

Let us just put this matter into context by looking at the value of small businesses to Australia. Economically alone, 92.9 per cent of Australian entrepreneurs employ fewer than 10 people. Far less capital is required to create each new job in small business than in any other field. It should be a very attractive field for any government to overcome its unemployment problem. Small businesses have a virtue which most Australians claim should be made a vital key to this Government and to all Australians, that is, the decentralisation of economic power. The decisions are made at the local level by the small employer, usually, frequently, in consultation with his or her employees and again, frequently, in consultation with his consumers, that is, in direct consultation with the people who are using his goods or services.

There is value to this country from small businesses through the employment potential. Businesses which employ fewer than 100 people make up 61 per cent of the private sector employment field. I think that small businesses are the epitome of the nature of Australians. The whole ethos of Australians is represented in the individualism of small businesses-in the freedom to decide the future of those businesses, the freedom to choose which path each of those businesses will take, the freedom to innovate and to risk. This demonstrates one of the great potentials of small businesses, not just in providing jobs for the sake of jobs, which in itself is important, but in providing a long term benefit to Australia, because small businesses will provide the greatest potential for Australia in the new technology fields and in the sunrise industries where this innovation, this entrepreneurial skill and this willingness to take risks is used in this country probably far more than in any other country in the world. Our people have the ability, the skills and the willingness to gamble everything on establishing new businesses, new services and new ventures that will break new ground, not just for Australia and their own communities, but potentially for the whole world.

Regrettably, small businesses, when debated in this Parliament, tend to become the motherhood issue, a bit like the issue that we have been debating over the last few days, namely, the family. Everybody is in favour of it. Everybody thinks it is great. Everybody thinks it is important. Of course, we cannot do without motherhood. We cannot do without the family. We cannot do without such things as the defence of Australia and we cannot do without that vital sector, small businesses. So we all support the concept in principle. Come election time , it is run to the top of every political party's mast. It is there flying for everybody to see as a vital factor of the policy statement of each political party. After the election it becomes one of the lowest priorities of the party in government, irrespective of which party that may be. Having a low priority-as we have seen already with this Government; certainly we saw it for the eight years of the previous Government-in effect means having no priority. It is as good as not even being recognised to have a low priority with a government, particularly a government which has a busy timetable.

Let us look at how low a priority small businesses have. Before the election small businesses were feted, wooed and cajoled, not just for their votes but also because they were potential donors to political parties of all political persuasions. Let us look at what happened immediately after the election in comparison with a couple of other major industries. The car industry is a classic illustration of the treatment which was dished out very generously by the Fraser Government. Because the car industry was a big and powerful industry with a big and powerful lobby, the Fraser Government looked after it as best it was able and, in many cases, did so to the detriment of the small industries which were in far more desperate plights. Under the present Government we have a similar situation. Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd suddenly ran into trouble. It walked up and knocked on the Government's door and was suddenly given millions of dollars-not just for this year; promises were made for ongoing years-the same millions that could rescue, that could help the survival of, small businesses.

I suggest that this will be an interesting debate. It will be interesting because, as the one who introduced this matter of public importance, I do not intend to tear strips off the Government or the Opposition. I suggest that that will be the pattern of the debate after I resume my seat. Let me suggest some of the predictable criticisms that are likely to eventuate in this debate to prove that each party lets small businesses down. We will be introduced to criticisms of the Liberal and National parties when they were in government by the Australian Labor Party which is the present Government. According to Labor, the previous Government failed to stimulate the economy; it produced an effective negative economic growth in this country; and it created dramatic increases in unemployment.

The present Government will criticise the previous Government because, in its first five years in office which were the good years, economically speaking, it more than doubled the rate of small business bankruptcies in this country. They increased from 1,252 in 1974-75 to over 2,500 in 1979-80. They were the good years; the rate only doubled in those five years. In the next two years it nearly doubled again. The bankruptcy rate of small business in this country climbed to 4,500 in 1981-82. Of course, one does not just take those simple numbers and say that that is the end of the problem, because the flow-on effect of every bankruptcy in this country is dramatic and traumatic for all who are in any way linked with that bankruptcy-whether they be the people in the business itself, its creditors, the relatives, the friends or all of those who try to rescue the business before it finally folds. Of course we do not have to consider only the rate of bankruptcies, but also the fact that another 10,000 small businesses closed their doors each year. That was a disastrous climate for any business and in particular for a small business where the whole livelihood of the owners, the entrepreneurs and the managers was at state.

The Labor Party will undoubtedly also criticise the previous Government for its failed and broken promises. There were many. A typical promise made year after year by the previous Prime Minister was that there would be an option for private companies to be taxed as a partnership. That promise was broken year after year, leaving small businesses at a distinct disadvantage to every major business and to every partnership and sole proprietorship in Australia. The Labor Party may find something good to say about the previous Government. For instance, it may suggest that the increased proportion of profits which could be retained without incurring additional tax went from 50 per cent to 80 per cent under the previous Government. The Labor critics could say that if they were feeling generous.

On the other hand this Government will be in for a serve from the Liberal and National parties. It, too, will be criticised. The method of introduction of the withholding tax has wreaked untold damage on small businesses. As a result, this Government will be criticised for not taking into consideration the dreadful harm that was done by that withholding tax, the prescribed payments tax. It will also be criticised, I suspect, by the coalition parties for the increase in petrol prices. The legislation will not just implement an increase now, it will institutionalise six-monthly increases. I am sure that the Government will be criticised by the Opposition parties for its sales tax policies, the full implications of which are not yet appreciated. It has introduced from out of the blue an excise on grape spirit. It has introduced a 20 per cent sales tax on oils, greases and lubricants. The way the Government botched its sales tax on air conditioning ducting resulted in the introduction of the sales tax being delayed a fortnight. That sales tax was introduced without adequate planning and without adequate care for the people in small businesses who would suffer. I am sure that the Liberal and National parties will criticise this Government for the way it botched the sales tax on fibreglass pools, not because the sales tax was introduced but because of the unjustness of putting a massive sales tax on fibreglass pools which are normally installed in the homes of moderate to average income earners. The Government placed no sales tax on concrete pools which are installed usually in more expensive homes. Fortunately the Government has gained some wisdom. It has reduced that tax from 20 per cent to 7 1/2 per cent as a result of the representations made by people who really cared about what is happening to small businesses.

I guess the coalition parties will also criticise this Government for its failed and broken promises. It will be criticised for the unwillingness, inability or lack of priority so far being given to the establishment of a small businesses council. It will criticise the Government for its promise of an early introduction of a division of small business within the Department of Industry and Commerce which would upgrade the importance of small business. There has been no action on that yet. The Government, I am sure, will be criticised also by the coalition parties for its tax charges policy and for the fact that it promised to introduce means to allow small businesses to retain profits which would help those businesses to develop. The Government has introduced two Budgets, a mini-Budget and a maxi-Budget, and there has been no sign of that. There has been no sign yet of another promise, that is, the introduction of quarterly payments of provisional tax. There has been no sign yet of-another promise not yet kept-of providing for a time lag for the remittance of sales taxes to help small businesses. There has been no sign of changes to the charter of the Commonwealth Development Bank of Australia to allow it to have equity capital in small businesses. There has been no sign of a change to the Trade Practices Act to prohibit discrimination against small businesses by larger businesses, nor to prevent unfair pricing and franchising laws to protect small businesses.

If the coalition parties are feeling generous, they may say that the Government has made some gestures towards small business and has introduced some encouraging measures towards high technology industry development. That does not apply just to small businesses. This is the pattern of both major parties. When there is a benefit that does advantage small businesses, they always seem to go along with similar benefits to the massive businesses, the internationals, the multinationals and the monopolies. This applies to the additional funding of the Australian Industry Development Corporation. The coalition parties may say: ' Good on you, Government, well done. That is an improvement'. Again, the benefit is to large and small businesses.

Both major parties have broken promises to petrol retailers. Mr Deputy President, would you believe that only two weeks ago this Government had the opportunity to do what both parties are now promising in Queensland, that is to get the multinational oil producers out of petrol retailing? I think that both parties must be feeling very guilty about their policies on tyre retreads. At this moment hundreds of people are being retrenched because tyre retreads are being taxed for the first time as a result of both this Government's broken promise and the previous Treasurer's broken promise not to apply a sales tax to retreaded tyres. Two promises have been broken. As a result, tyre retreaders in this country are now in a very serious position.

There are solutions. I suggest that 1984 be the year of small business encouragement. It could lead to a major recovery of this country's economy. It could be a small business led recovery. I suggest that it be launched with a small business summit conference, either Government sponsored or, if the Government is not willing or game to do it, an Australian Democrat sponsored conference along the lines of a mini-summit conference, to conclude with the creation of a mini-Economic Planning Advisory Council. I believe that there is a need for a Federal standing committee on small businesses, with representatives from Government and Opposition, from each State and Territory, to help resolve the inter-government problems which affect small businesses, for example, taxing problems such as payroll tax, which gets battered about between State and Federal governments, or death duties, which get thrown around between State governments as inducements to small businesses to move their place of business. We should provide for uniform business laws, for example, in leasing premises, in franchising and financing and help overcome the problems of overlapping powers. A Federal standing committee on small businesses should be established. We have so many small businesses, but they are ignored in this field. The objective of the year of small businesses should be the establishment of a suitable Australian environment to encourage the development and proliferation of small businesses.

I repeat that this is not an attack on the Government. It is not an attack on Her Majesty's Opposition. It is an appeal to all parliamentarians, not just those in the Senate and in this Parliament but parliamentarians throughout Australia. I believe that we all want to help small businesses. I promise that if this Government moves in the directions indicated, all of us-Government members, Liberals, Nationals, Australian Democrats-will rush the legislation through to assist small businesses because we are all sympathetic to small businesses. I believe and the Australian Democrats believe that small businesses are in a position to revive this country's economy and, beyond that, to provide the desperately needed jobs for people in this country. Small businesses do not often cry out for help, but right now they are on their knees. I appeal to all parliamentarians to help them now while they are still breathing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a matter of public importance relating to small business. The first speaker, Senator Jack Evans, an Australian Democrat from Western Australia, indulged in a series of rhetorical flourishes about small business, many of which I agree with. I certainly agree with him about the importance of the small business sector and the priorities which should be attached to it. He said he was not here to attack the Government and the Opposition. I thought he did a pretty fair job in the circumstances. But I do not propose to be put in that framework which Senator Jack Evans would like to strap us all into, that strait- jacket, and conduct this debate in the way he prophesied it would be conducted. I do not propose to attack the Opposition. I do, however, propose to attack Senator Jack Evans, which is a different thing, in respect of some of the matters that he raised.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me say right at the beginning that I am not unwilling to be generous to the previous Government in respect of its increasing to 80 per cent the amount of profits which could be retained by small business. I think that is highly desirable. On the other hand, I am disposed to be uncharitable to the previous Government in respect of small business policy in that it promised in the 1977 election to expand the charter of the Commonwealth Development Bank of Australia to enable it to take up equity capital in small business and it did not do that. I think Australian business and industry would be much better if some of those things had been done quite a number of years ago. What Senator Evans has done is to put together a sort of grab bag, a smorgasbord of everything that he thinks, as he would put it, is motherhood about small business. He has thrown everything together in a heap and tipped the bucket, as it were, on both the Fraser Government and the present Government with all the contents spilling out. I want to take him to task on a couple of things which he mentioned quite specifically. It is not correct to say that the venture capital proposals announced by the Government last week are directed towards large business as well as small business. If the honourable senator reads the guidelines for the provision of venture capital, he will see that they are quite specific. The companies which will be eligible are companies which employ fewer than 100 people. I think, in a sense, that is one of the many definitions of small business that have been offered in the myriad of definitions that exist for small business. I think it must be said in respect of many of the comments which have been made about various taxes imposed by the Government that sure, some of them bear on small business, some of them bear on big business, some of them bear on a vast variety of citizens. That is inevitable in the taxation process. We cannot single out any one particular sector of the economy and say that it will not be affected by any taxes imposed by the Government.

Senator Evans concluded by advocating that 1984 be known as the year of small business and suggested a number of things that might happen in that year. I do not think that that is a bad idea. All I can say to him is that if he wants to run his matter of public importance again next year he probably will not have much to talk about in terms of the things he has talked about today, provided that he gives us the undertaking that he will pass any legislation that is introduced in the meantime, as he has already done.

This Government recognises the importance of maintaining a strong, viable small business sector. We are very conscious of the role which small business plays in the Australian economy in generating investment, employment opportunities and, more particularly, entrepreneurial skills. One of the great tragedies of small business in Australia over many years has been that the moment a small business becomes a medium size business because of good entrepreneurial activity on behalf of that business it has normally been taken over and the entrepreneurial skills have gone out of the window. As Senator Evans said, 90 per cent of Australia's enterprises are small businesses. One out of every two people in private sector employment is employed by a small business. This Government's recognition of the importance of small business has been demonstrated in a number of ways to which I will refer in a minute. I itemise these matters in no particular order of priority. I remind Senator Evans that he is talking about a situation of small business that has accumulated over 10 years or so when these matters ought to have been attended to. I remind him that this Government has been in office six months and in terms of the things which are of fundamental importance, according to what he says, I want to make clear what has been done in that time. The first thing I mention is that the Government has established the Economic Planning Advisory Council, which will be an important body in providing an alternative source of advice to government. Small business is to be represented on that Council.

But the thing of prime concern that we have to remember is the importance of macro-economic policies to the small business sector. The small business sector has suffered from disastrous economic policies. Low economic growth, high inflation, high interest rates have affected everyone but the burden of those things on small firms places them inevitably at greater risk and at greater disadvantage. I recall that only two or three weeks ago the honourable senator made a speech about the Budget in which he advocated a much more expansionary Budget as a solution to this country's problems. With respect, he cannot have it all ways. That is one of the difficulties the Australian Democrats have-seeking to be all things to all men and not having to deliver on any of the utterances which they make. A fortnight ago the honourable senator wanted a more expansionary Budget. He suggested that that would be a solution to many of the social problems which we have in the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be a great boost to the small business sector.

—That might be true. It might have been a solution to many of the social problems which we have in our community: it would not have been a solution to the problems of small business because nothing impacts on small business more than high interest rates and high rates of inflation which are the fundamental concerns of this Government in terms of its Budget which is less expansionary than Senator Evans and others might have advocated. So these things , in a sense, have to be seen in the context of the Government's overall economic policy. Its policy is designed to halt the disastrous economic slide of the last few years and small business will be the first and major beneficiary if we succeed.

SPEECH.PARA: The growing implications of economic recovery are therefore very good news for small business, and good news particularly for industries like the housing industry in respect of which there is now a clear upturn. It is good news for the small business sector. The recent surveys of the Victorian Chamber of Manufactures, the Confederation of Australian Industry and the Westpac Banking Corporation all, in a sense, imply good news for small business because of those demand factors and the general improvement in economic anticipations which have come about in the six months that this Government has been in office.

But in addition to that, of course, we came to office with commitments to provide the means for small business to take advantage of any recovery which occurred. I do not say we have acted with the sort of Speedy Gonzales approach advocated by Senator Evans to the exclusion of everything else, but let me refer to some of the things which have been done. The goal of the Government's program in relation to this is to enhance the entrepreneurial activities of small business, particularly. I will go through some of the key elements in that task. The key elements which are essential to the revival and growth of small business in Australia, which this Government very strongly advocates and seeks to enhance , are: Finance, taxation, education and training, information and research, competition, and government purchasing.

If I might deal with those points one by one, access to finance has always been crucial, of critical importance, to small business. A number of recent studies have highlighted the problems faced by small business particularly with regard to access to equity and venture capital. I think all of us, in a sense, have moved to deepen our understanding of these problems and their possible solutions . The terms of reference of the review of the report of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry on the Australian Financial System, conducted by Mr Martin, as set out by the Treasurer (Mr Keating), contain specific mention of the need for an adequate supply of finance at reasonable cost for the small business sector. I do not wish to refer in detail to the terms of reference of that review; suffice to say that that specific term of reference is there. The Martin committee will report, I believe towards the end of this year, on that survey of the financial system with particular reference to that and other specific terms of reference that have been given to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will it look at the 100,000 differential?

—I do not know whether it will. It is no good interjecting about what the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System did; I am talking about the Martin committee. The review will clear the way for the consideration of further initiatives in the small business finance area.

SPEECH.PARA: I also make the point that there is a very real role for the Commonwealth Development Bank in the provision of finance to small business. That is a matter which has been recognised by a variety of governments. The Fraser Government recognised that in terms of its dishonoured 1977 election promise. Prior to the election it recognised the importance of that. The close relationship between the Commonwealth Development Bank and the banking system generally and the experience of that bank in handling development proposals for small business make it an ideal institution to take a broader role in the provision of small business finance. This Government has already freed the Commonwealth Development Bank from Loan Council control so that its borrowing entitlements can be widened more easily. We will be looking, and we are looking, in the context of the response of the Martin committee, at allowing the Commonwealth Development Bank to provide equity as well as debt finance. As a further move to increase the flow of equity finance to small businesses, we are investigating the establishment of an over the counter market in unlisted shares in small public companies.

Another key initiative to which Senator Evans was charitable enough to refer is the Government's response to the report of the Espie High Technology Financing Committee, which stressed the importance of establishing a venture capital market in Australia. I again draw the Senate's attention to the fact that the Espie committee found that no country has been able to produce a climate for high-tech investment without government action of this kind. I think Senator Evans knows that insofar as growth high technology industries exist in Australia , they are basically in the small business areas. I draw Senator Evans's attention to the guidelines established by Espie in relation to the sorts of companies and the size of companies which should be eligible for assistance as venture capital companies under the Espie proposals.

The Espie committee proposals and the Government response to them addressed two particular needs. First of all, they addressed the need for finance and, secondly, they addressed the need for management expertise in Australian companies. Both those issues are addressed and have been responded to by the Government. The venture capital proposals will be of great significance to small firms which play a major role in developing and diffusing new technologies and innovations into the economic environment generally. We have also made changes, as Senator Evans said, to the Australian Industry Development Corporation, increasing its statutory capital, making more capital available to it, providing fewer restrictions on its borrowings and investing, providing a government guarantee and specifying the priority areas which the AIDC should be directed towards. Much of this will be an important new means of finance for such important areas of small business as tourism and high technology. Both those areas are being specifically addressed.

The next point I would like to make is that the growth and development of technology orientated small firms will also be enhanced by the support provided in the Budget for research and development, including technology transfer, productivity improvement and innovation. As Senator Evans conceded in his speech on the Budget, the increases made available for those areas were significant. It is also widely recognised that lack of management expertise is probably the single most important cause, other than the macroeconomic matters which I mentioned at the start of my remarks, of small business failure. We have acted in this Budget to enable an upgrading of proposals specifically directed towards small business management, education and training. Funds will be provided by my Department also to expand the range of small business publications, management training courses, films and audio-visual aids and to continue the highly successful small business awards program. We are consulting with the States and small business representatives on proposals to expand further extension services for small businesses. More and better information on the small business sector is essential for the identification of problems and the development of appropriate policies. We will act to upgrade the official statistics on small business and to encourage more research.

All these things are in terms of getting an infrastructure, an environment, which is supportive of small business. These things cannot be done overnight. They take time and it is best that they are done well rather than by way of kneejerk reaction to specific pressures or comments. I concede the criticism of the honourable senator in such matters as the establishment of a small business council and a small business division within the Department of Industry and Commerce. Both those matters are well in hand. I venture to suggest that the honourable senator will not be able to bring forward a matter of public importance this year, given a reasonable time lapse, in which he will be able to mention those matters again, because they are well down the track. But such bodies cannot be established overnight; it is not even desirable to establish them overnight in view of the problems which are involved.

The honourable senator mentioned trade practices legislation. I believe my colleague Senator Gareth Evans will shortly bring down a paper on suggested amendments to trade practices legislation, the implications of which will be helpful to small business. Another question which is being addressed is that of special small business preference in Commonwealth Government purchasing. I believe we will be able to make announcements about that matter in the very near future. I could go through a list of other matters that were specifically raised by the honourable senator, but I do not have time to address them at this time.

The only point I wanted to make in conclusion is that I believe that most of the matters that have been raised as part of this matter of public importance by Senator Jack Evans in the somewhat scattergun approach he adopted are being addressed by the Government. Therefore, if the honourable senator is chiding us with slowness, I say to him only that a lot of things have been done. I am very sympathetic with the general attitudes that he expressed towards small business. Many of the things he chided us for have been done in the six months we have been in Government; they were not done in the previous seven or eight years. A number of other things about which he chided us will be dealt with in the very near future. We will no doubt take account of and deal with in due course any other constructive suggestions which flow from the lucid minds of the Australian Democrats.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The nub of this debate is the Government's abdication of its responsibilities to the people involved in small business. The part played by small business in the economy is, I believe, at last beginning to be recognised. I was pleased to hear Senator Button this afternoon say that his Government recognises its role and responsibility. In fact, it is estimated that there are 400,000 small businesses throughout Australia, excluding primary producers. The Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia has estimated that small enterprises provide between 50 and 60 per cent of the total employment in the private sector. Its contribution to the gross national product is seen as about the same as that of big business. It plays a major economic role as specialist suppliers of parts, components and the like; as a source of innovation in product techniques and services; in providing competition, checking monopoly profits and the inefficiency of monopoly; and as a productive outlet for the energies of enterprising and independent people.

SPEECH.PARA: Reports such as that of the United Kingdom Bolton Committee refer to the importance of small businesses in industries and trade in which the optimum size of the enterprise is small; its importance in providing products and services in a limited or specialised market, which a large firm would not find it worth while or economic to provide; as a breeding ground for new industries; and as a means of entry into business for new entrepreneurial talents. Small business also plays a major social role in its contribution to employment and in its potential to reduce unemployment. Each new job requires less capital in the form of fixed assets than in the case of big business. Also, the usually closer relationship between employer and employee is not to be underrated. It also offers the opportunity for equity ownership of the nation's resources and has the potential, therefore, for decentralisation of economic power. Given the importance of small business, one would have thought that the prosperity and expansion of small business would have been at the forefront of the Government's economic planning, particularly in the current climate of record high unemployment. But whether because it lacks direct political clout or for whatever other reason, the record of the Government so far has been one of abdication of its responsibilities.

We heard the Minister for Industry and Commerce, Senator Button, today make claims about what the previous Government did not do in seven years. At times I was critical of the fact that we did not appear to be doing enough. But when changes occurred for the good I was the first to applaud. I refer, for example, to the relief obtained from improving the tax mix; the raising of thresholds; the accelerated depreciation allowances on plant; the partial relief given by changes made with regard to double taxation of dividends, which the Senate will recall; and the increase of the retention allowance which, I accept, was acknowledged by Senator Button. I in turn recognise the few positive contributions that the new Government has already made in relation to the Commonwealth Development Bank-at least, the announcements have been made-and the Australian Industry Development Corporation, but it is time--

TALK.START.PARA: —They are just developments of what we did anyway, aren't they ? They are not new.

—Yes, that is correct. The announcements are starting to come forth , but we have yet to see implementation of the proposals. It is a bit like the proposals for assistance for new technology. Some time next year, we understand, we might see some legislation. I suggest that it is time for this Government to cease to justify its failures and inactivity on the record of the previous Government. I accept that it is still only six months into its term, and I recognise what that means. But how long is it to continue to say: 'We are still early in government; you were in government for a long time'? That response will not be good enough for too long. It is time the Government started to look at its record in this field which, I submit to the Senate, could only fairly be described so far as one of bitter disappointment.

SPEECH.PARA: In a speech I made on 19 May on this subject I criticised the Government for the marked neglect that it accorded to small business at the National Economic Summit Conference. Honourable senators will remember that that Conference, which was designed to look to future economic directions for this country, was dominated by big business, big government and big unions. Small business had but one direct representative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two.
—Don Gibbons.

—There is an argument as to whether it was one or two. Since then we have had the Budget. We have had the Economic Summit which was a bitter disappointment for small business and now we have had the Budget. In the short time I have for this speech I want to concentrate on how the Budget has failed small business. I want also to remind the Government of the many initiatives it promised small business before the last election. Whether the Government likes it or not it can reasonably expect to hear of those initiatives time and again from us. The hopes and aspirations of many a small businessman were raised on those initiatives. Until half an hour ago I thought that they appeared to be languishing in the Minister's bottom drawer. I understand that they are now out of the drawer and if we are patient we may see some positive developments in that regard.

SPEECH.PARA: There are two aspects to a governments responsibility to small business. Again, Senator Button acknowledged the first, the macro-economic role of contributing to a healthy economy. The second is the positive encouragement and support which government can give. I refer, for example, to its power to remove the anomalies within our regulatory system which specifically prejudice small business at the expense of big business, the need for greater access to finance and contributions to overcome a lack of business ability, training and experience, all of which I expanded up on in greater detail in that former speech to which I referred.

In bringing down its last Budget the Government was presented with a unique opportunity-because of the recent upturn in economic activity in the United States, the ending of the drought, non-farm stock rundown slowing as business prepared for new investment, and evidence of the success of the wage pause in easing wage pressures on production costs-to turn the somewhat fragile starts of economic recovery into a sustained economic upturn which would benefit small business. But to do so the Budget had to be so framed as to contribute to a lowering of inflation. Small business cannot be isolated from other sectors of the economy. In the same way, conditions in the Australian domestic economy cannot be isolated from the world economy.

For a nation where trade amounts to 30 per cent of its gross domestic product an uncompetitive domestic price structure not only endangers the future of our already depressed export markets in minerals and energy resources but also prohibits us from securing additional export markets for an already depressed manufacturing sector. Only through a lower rate of inflation can Australia achieve the international competitiveness necessary for recovery.

Whilst at first glance one would see a projected consumer price index increase of 7 1/2 per cent which would represent a welcome wind down in price rises, further investigation exposes an underlying rate of inflation expected to be closer to 11 per cent, as evidenced by the expected high gross domestic product deflater. That is, it shows a nominal GDP growth for the year 1983-84 of 14 per cent and a real GDP increase of 3 per cent. The difference to the price changes is 11 per cent.

I remind the Senate that the expected average rate of inflation of our trading partners in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries for 1983-84 is around 5 per cent. The Budget therefore holds little hope for Australia having a price structure that will return us to an internationally competitive position. In fact, as the Budget itself warned in Statement No. 2, at page 70:

A further point of concern for a sustainable recovery relates to the current inflation outlook which, even given a favourable wages outcome, is likely to remain substantially above inflation levels of our immediate trading partner countries.
The Budget therefore does no more than condemn us to continued international non -competitiveness.

A more urgent warning was issued by the Australian Chamber of Commerce when it warned that the Government's present strategy will push inflation up even further. The Chamber President saw the entire Budget strategy as counterproductive to achieving greater international competitiveness. Mr Court said:
The Government cannot hold to its present course without pushing Australia's cost structure further out of line with the competitor trading nations.

It is no good, Madam Acting Deputy President, for the Government to say that it could do nothing about it. For example, there can be no doubt that Australia's wage structure will significantly contribute to determine whether we remain a high inflation, high cost and low growth competitor. Regrettably the Budget records a failure to build on the gains achieved by the previous Government's wage pause program.

The Budget Speech of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the accompanying papers leave no doubt that the entire wage strategy of the Government rests on the prices and incomes accord. Even putting aside for the moment the obvious questions of Australia's economic future, if the accord disintegrates, even if the Australian Council of Trade Unions can deliver on the strictly limited claims promise as the quid pro quo full half yearly indexation, Australia's wage structure will still remain out of kilter with wage levels overseas. What if it does not hold? I do not have the time to deal with what is occurring but the Senate is aware of the Heinz wage settlement of $15 a week to $20 a week, the claim of 130,000 building industry workers for an extra $19 a week and the further ongoing pressures that are putting this wages accord very much in jeopardy. It looks, therefore, as if the Government's policy regarding wages will fail as a contribution to containing and reducing inflation.

Another factor affecting inflation will be the effect of the Government's policy on interest rates. It must be noted that the net public sector borrowing requirement is expected to increase by around 2 percentage points of GDP to about 8 per cent. A borrowing requirement of that magnitude must place substantial pressure on interest rates, which in turn could flow through to domestic prices. The cause has in part been discretionary government spending decisions which place at great risk any hope for non-inflationary growth.

Finally, tax policy will affect inflation. Here the trend is indicated by the Government's decision to index excise taxes, which has institutionalised a range of Government charges in the CPI. The result was summarised by the President of the Australian Chamber of Commerce who said:

The Government cannot hold to its present course without pushing Australia's cost structure further out of line with competitor trading nations. It is therefore with regret that one must assess that the Budget has failed as an effort in addressing the scourge of inflation and our inability to internationally compete.
What distressing news for business generally but for small business in particular.

The Government has failed in its Budget and general economic management to help small business. Let us recall its specific pre-election promises, the promises that led to its election being greeted enthusiastically by such groups as the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia. The Government promised a full division of small business in the Department of Industry and Commerce, a small business council which it claimed would be more effective than the present Small Business Advisory Council. It promised tax scale restructuring, including a raised threshold, full retention of profits where the funds are to be used in the business, quarterly payment of provisional tax, a full month for the remittance of sales tax, industrial research and development grants exempt from tax, accelerated depreciation provisions but with phased out investment allowances, an expanded charter for the Commonwealth Development Bank of Australia to allow it to provide equity finance or packages of equity and debt and direct advertising of the CDB as a source of small business finance.

Furthermore, the Government promised to investigate an over-the-counter market in unlisted shares in small public companies, the conversion of the Australian Industry Development Corporation into the Australian Industry Development Bank with technical and financial capacity to provide support for small and medium enterprises, the administration of the monetary and banking system to avoid sharp increases in interest rates on trading bank overdrafts and the strengthening of the Trade Practices Act to prohibit discrimination by large against small and to prevent unfair pricing designed to eradicate rather than to prohibit competition.

It has promised also to investigate the prohibition or mergers which are likely to lessen substantially competition without offsetting public benefits, the effective strengthening of the Trade Practices Commission so that it can effectively monitor unfair competition, the production of franchise laws to protect small business, the development of a co-ordinated national plan for small business training, the establishment of small enterprise counsellor training programs with the help of associations and other groups, the establishment of referral centres in each State and in country centres known as small business bureaus, the provision of grants to trade associations which develop specific management training programs and the establishment of marketing and promotional services through small business bureaus to advise on all such matters. These are the promises apparently filed under 'pre-election'. It is our hope that under 'post-election' action will ensure in the not too distant future .

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot support the proposition that the Labor Government has abdicated its responsibility in the area of small business, but I do endorse the importance of that sector to the economy, and I wish to speak to that subject. The Australian Labor Party was the first party in Australia to develop comprehensive policies on small business. At the State and national levels, we have been formulating policies in this area for a number of years. We were the first to recognise the key role of small business in the economy. It now represents approximately 40 per cent to 50 per cent of the work force employed in the private sector in this country. However, there are real problems in determining that share because there is a vast lack of data on small business in Australia. I am sure that that is something the Government will be moving to remedy in the not too distant future. The small business sector in Australia really needs to be documented more fully to find out its general impact. But we can say with some certainty that small business does dominate the retailing sector, the services sector and it is significant in the building sector and other areas, including road transport.

SPEECH.PARA: I am aware of key studies which have been carried out on small business, and particularly that pathfinding study by the Massachusetts Institute of Technology , which was a complete census of small business records in the United States of America. Over many years it looked at hundreds of thousands of small businesses, and studied their birth, their growth and their general history. The major finding of that census was that it was the birth of small business and its subsequent growth which was the major job creation mechanism in the American economy. Job creation in total had very little to do with large corporations. They were large employers but they did not add a great deal to pay rolls from year to year. In fact it was the birth and subsequent growth of small business which created most jobs in the American economy. We are certainly well aware of those sorts of conclusions.

The ALP has specific policies in the small business area. We are committed to increase equity and loan funding at reasonable rates for small business, probably through the Commonwealth Development Bank of Australia. We endorse the concept of protection from price discrimination and other unfair trading practices in Australia. It is as well to note that on a per capita basis Australia probably has more restrictive trade agreements than any other country. Not so many years ago we had something like 10,000 documented restrictive trade agreements in Australia. We are committed to upgrading small business counselling, training and advisory services. Of course, a key part of that activity occurs at the State level. I am pleased to note that considerable work is being done in this area in my own State where the Small Business Corporation is about to be established.

Our approach in respect of small business is substantially different from that of the coalition parties. They, over the years, have been all too eager listeners and supporters of big business and multinational corporations. I am afraid that to a large extent small businesses have come second over the years with the coalition partners. For years they did nothing to help small business. They watched as the economy became more concentrated, as more production was concentrated into fewer and fewer hands. They watched and did nothing as the economy became more and more overseas controlled and as small business was progressively shut out.
