It is very interesting to note the position under the previous Government in respect of bankruptcies. I do not propose to say very much on this subject. However, I have been reading the annual report of the Attorney-General's Department on the Bankruptcy Act. I found the report very illuminating because it pointed out that in 1975-76, which is basically the last financial year in which there was a Labor Government, there were 1,900 bankruptcies in Australia. The report went on to point out that there had been increases in every year since then in the total number of bankruptcies in Australia. In 1980-81 we had the disgraceful level of 5,154 bankruptcies in Australia under the previous Government-the Government that claimed it was a great supporter of business and business profitability. There was an increase of over 150 per cent in business bankruptcies under the previous Government. That quite disgraceful record resulted in heartbreak and dashed hopes for many people. Many jobs were lost as a result of business failures.

In addition, over that period small business was crippled by the inexorable rise in interest rates. Small business viability and profitability were affected as interest rates rose progressively, particularly in regard to overdrafts of less than $100,000. In 1980, the interest rate for such overdrafts was 10.5 per cent. The interest rate rose to 14.5 per cent in 1982. There was a 4 per cent rise in overdraft rates in less than two years, which had a crippling effect on small business. It was no wonder that as a result of the record levels of bankruptcies and overdraft rates a record number of small business people supported Labor at the election this year.

The Australian Labor Party's general policy is to provide maximum stimulus to the economy without generating inflationary pressures. To implement this we have introduced the prices and incomes policy which is designed to restrain costs and hold down inflationary pressures while boosting the economy. That accord will help improve the viability of small business by helping to restrain its cost structure. That is one of the major general policy initiatives we have taken this year to boost small business activity.

I might note that we devalued the dollar soon after coming to office, and that certainly will improve the competitiveness of those small businesses which compete with overseas companies. Through the Budget we are stimulating the economy to the extent of some $2,600m more than last financial year. That is indicated by the structural Budget deficit. It is a tremendous boost to economic activity in Australia, and that in turn will benefit small business. It is estimated, comparing the June quarter of 1984 with the June quarter of this year , that there will be a 5 per cent growth in gross domestic product. This very large turnaround is a reversal from the horrific decline between June 1982 and June 1983 of 3.9 per cent in the gross domestic product. By turning the economy around in this way, small business in turn will benefit significantly.

Small business will benefit from the growing economy. It will also benefit from falling inflation. It is forecast that there will be a fall from the double digit level of 11.2 per cent last financial year to rather less than 7 1/2 per cent this financial year. That certainly will help small business survive and should in turn allow further reductions in interest rates to occur. I am pleased to say that the increase in gross domestic product should be accompanied by a very substantial increase in business productivity. It is a normal process in any upswing in an economic cycle that, as activity picks up, labour productivity rises significantly. This Budget is based on the assumption of a 3 1/2 per cent increase in productivity this year. With cost restraint, that substantial rise in productivity will lift the profitability of small business significantly. It will help overcome the legacy left by the previous Government referred to in the Budget as 'a currently extremely depressed level of business profitability'.

The Budget provides $15m in the form of a capital injection to the Commonwealth Development Bank of Australia. That in turn should enable the Bank to undertake a more active role in respect of small business financing. Another $12 1/2m has been added as a capital instalment to the Australian Industry Development Corporation, and in turn that will enable the Corporation to lend more money to businesses to expand their activities. Senator Button has referred to venture capital proposals which have been announced in the last week or so at a cost of $20m to the Budget to assist in reducing risk in such high risk areas as high technology. The Government is providing another $19m under the industrial research and development incentives program to encourage research and development in Australia. I am sad to say that our record in this area is almost the worst in the industrialised world, and any program to boost industrial research must be supported and must have benefits for small business.

The building sector of the economy, which is dominated by small business, should do extremely well this financial year as a result of the stimulus in the Budget. For example, there is a 50 per cent boost in the funds allocated by the Commonwealth to public housing. There is the introduction of the first home buyers scheme involving grants of up to $7,000 for eligible couples, to try to remove the deposit gap which is the biggest impediment to home ownership in Australia. Those measures in turn should result in housing commencements being 22,000 higher this financial year than last financial year, and that will give a tremendous boost to the work load of small builders. We estimate that, as a result of that expansion of activity, some 30,000 extra jobs will be created this financial year in the building industry alone. Those programs come on top of the good news this week in respect of the housing sector in which, it has already been noted, significant improvements are under way.

The Government has also indicated its recognition of the role played by small business in the tourism area. Small business dominates the tourism sector through motels, small tour operators and so forth. This financial year we are providing a 75 per cent boost in funds to the Australian Tourist Commission to try to enable it to assist development of the industry. We are allocating $17 1/ 2m this financial year compared with $10m provided last financial year by the previous Government.

The road transport industry is yet another industry in which small business is highly significant. Many family trucking businesses tend to characterise the road transport sector which is a struggling area at the moment. Road transport is a very risky activity to be in at the moment and is characterised by an exceedingly high bankruptcy rate. In the last financial year there were over 600 bankruptcies in the transport and storage sector. Most of those were in road transport and I am sad to say that most of them would have been small businesses . They are struggling at the moment. I am particularly pleased that the Government has recently announced its comprehensive inquiry into the road transport industry-a long overdue inquiry that will look at the industry's problems, help get it back on its feet and help improve the viability of small business in that sector.

The Labor Government recognises the significance of small business in the economy. It recognises that it has problems at the moment. The Government has devised appropriate policies to deal with those problems. We have already taken general measures such as those in the Budget which will boost the sector. We have announced specific policies for small business to aid its survival. We have announced specific policies to aid the recovery of small business and to bring about its growth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to debate this matter of public importance on small business. Despite its contribution to employment and the economy, the dearth of small businessmen in the Parliament is a matter of profound concern. This lack of representation manifests itself in the few parliamentary debates on this subject. It is deplorable that the Australian Labor Party, before the last general election, made what appeared to be sincere promises to this sector, causing many small businessmen to seek comfort in the Labor Party's persuasive slogans, only to find that in both the mini-Budget and the August Budget the promises were almost totally ignored.

SPEECH.PARA: Not one of the ALP's pre-election promises to small business was implemented in the Budget. It is true that pricks of conscience have occurred since then and there have been one or two changes. Labor promised to implement immediately an Australian small business program, to allow full retention of profits, to provide full quarterly provisional tax payments, to extend the time permitted to pay sales tax and to create real jobs in manufacturing. In fact in February, the Hon. John Dawkins, the then Opposition spokesman on finance, said that the Labor Government would make a commitment to revitalise small business with action, resources and legislation. But there has been no action in the Budget. The failure of members of the Government to do anything really points to the shallowness of the ALP promises. But, as I have said, their consciences have pricked them as a result of many representations since the Budget. In small business we all welcome the decision to enable tax deductibility of venture capital for high technology industries.

Prime Minister Hawke wants consultation and information exchange. But the effective exclusion of the private sector from the pre-Budget consultation makes a mockery of Prime Minister Hawke's calls for consultation and consensus. Only one small business organisation, the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia, COSBOA, was represented at the National Economic Summit Conference. Not one small businessman was invited in spite of the fact that 28 big businessmen were present. The Prime Minister obviously prefers the company of big business tycoons to that of representatives of the most dynamic sector of the Australian economy, the small businessmen.

In the debate on the Economic Planning Advisory Council Bill, Senator Peter Rae moved an amendment to ensure small business representation on the Council. The Australian Democrats, who are now absent from the chamber despite their intense interest in the subject and having raised the matter here today through Senator Jack Evans, indicated that they would support the amendment. But later on in the debate Senator Haines said that she would not support the amendment. Where do the Australian Democrats stand in relation to small business? They are not even united on the subject. They should at least have supported that worthy amendment .

When one considers the statistics, the rationale for the Australian Labor Party 's attitude to small business in the Budget is difficult to find. Small and medium businesses employ something like 46 per cent of the total work force and 61 per cent of the total private sector work force. Small and medium business enterprises earn about 60 per cent of the total private sector profits and therefore contribute more to income tax revenue than does the big business sector. But who are these people who we all say we represent? Individually, they have a very small share of a particular market. They are owners or part owners in a personalised way. They are independent in the sense that they are free from outside control. They operate in an incorporated or unincorporated form. They have many problems. They lack capital and generally lack formal post-school management qualifications, which unfortunately contribute to their high failure rate. The mobility of their managers tends to be low and they have problems of fast growth, dependence on borrowing and undercapitalisation.

I will give an example of the situation in my State of Tasmania. About 900 firms start up each year and at least 600 fold. About 5,000 Tasmanians lose their jobs each year when small businesses fail. The social consequences, as well as the economic ones, are quite tragic. Nearly three-quarters of small firms fail within their first five years. Those figures take into account only failure as a result of bankruptcies and liquidations. The range of other reasons for failure is quite immense. But why do they fail? The reasons relate to problems of inflation, lack of sales, lack of expertise and training, lack of initial working capital and bad debts.

It is unfortunate that there is such a lack of fundamental research in this area. Professor Meredith is one exception. In my community, Dr David Back has done much good work. But around the country there are very few statistical collections which monitor the health of this particular sector. Small business thrives in a stable economic climate. That is not what we are getting at the moment. It needs encouragement and more effective and fair competition. Its interests have been neglected traditionally because there has been no spokesman for small business. But the Liberal-National Party Opposition has appointed a spokesman for small business in Roger Shipton, the shadow Minister for small business and tourism. We are offering a constructive approach-a spokesman who will support this issue.

Although I do not believe that governments consciously prejudice small business , small firms often suffer unintended disadvantages in policies which are often designed to be neutral but which have contrary effects. I appeal to the Government in its buying policies to recognise the existence of small business. So often the managers of government departments and quangos find it so much more comfortable and easy to deal with the large corporations. I appeal to them in their buying processes to consider the place of small businesses. The discrimination I mention is often quite unintentional and occurs in the three levels of government-State, local and Federal. In local government, it is often manifested in zoning and rezoning restrictions. Changing the directions of one- way streets can have a fundamental impact on a small shopkeeper. State governments require a wide range of approvals for development and expansion.

Discrimination takes place at all levels of government. But in talking on this matter of public importance today, I want to concentrate on the Federal problems . We have this iniquitous prescribed payments tax. In fact one Second Commissioner of Taxation acknowledged that, as a result of that legislation, a business in the contruction industry might have enough paper to fill a small room to accompany its tax return. This reflects the ignorance of the Labor Government about how the private sector works. It fails to acknowledge the additional working capital costs that will be incurred as a result of this change to the legislation. It ignores the cash flow problems that will occur. At the same time the prescribed payments tax legislation will add considerably to the administrative costs of small businesses. What will the Budget do for small business? It will do nothing. The Hawke Government is seeking a so-called government led recovery. It is not an investment recovery; it is not a consumer recovery. How does this government led recovery assist small business? At present small business is facing one of its greatest challenges.

On Friday the national wage case decision will be handed down. Two of the judges who will hand down that decision are also sitting on the Australian Council of Trade Unions job protection case. What a misnomer! That decision could have the effect of virtually wiping out a lot of small business and big business in Australia. The ACTU's job protection case in the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission will have a mammoth effect. Jobs will be lost for ever because the claim provides for employers to give three months notice, four weeks pay plus another four weeks pay for each year of service, relocation expenses and the cost of retraining. We have an absurd situation at the extreme in which a 60-year-old employee with 40 years service would get a total payout of 198 weeks. All the State Labor governments and the Federal Labor Government have supported the ACTU's case. I think that is particularly relevant to today's debate.

I will refer to some of the statistics which will follow if the job protection claim succeeds. An employee aged only 20, with less than one years service, will get three weeks additional pay. A 25-year old employee with five years service will get 18 weeks pay, a 35-year old employee with 15 years service will get 63 additional weeks pay and a 50-year old employee with 30 years service will get 148 weeks pay. Sir John Moore asked the ACTU advocates what would be the economic consequences of the two claims that the ACTU has before the Commission. They have not yet answered his question and it is doubtful whether they will answer it. These decisions have the possible consequence of closing down thousands of small businesses throughout Australia. We should understand what could happen if the ACTU claim in this job protection case is acknowledged by the Commission. Let us take the situation of a business that has been operating for, say, 10 years and which, because of an economic downturn, has to retrench some of its employees. Not only could this result in the loss of the jobs of those few people who are stood down but also because of the financial problems that that could cause, it could result in the closure of the whole business. In other words, what the claim is seeking to provide for is a contingent liability which has a retrospective effect. Here we come back to the old matter of retrospectivity and the problems that it will cause to the private sector.

What the ACTU is doing, with the Labor Government's blessing, is camouflaging its strategy. It is against recovery and jobs will be lost if this claim is granted. Small businesses are the key to economic recovery; they are the backbone of the private enterprise system. They are labour intensive and they offer great potential for new jobs but they are not being helped at all. High technology and sunrise industries will surely come from this area. The characteristic qualities of small business are vigour, enterprise and ambition, characteristics which make small businessmen natural leaders. This spirit of independence is a strength to the nation. The sector is very viable but what is this Government doing to help it? It is placing small business in a dreadful position. In nine months time interest rates will go through the roof due to the funding of this massive Budget deficit. Small business is failing and it will be very difficult for it to exist with a continuation of Labor Party policies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are discussing a matter of public importance introduced by Senator Jack Evans. At the outset I indicate my complete rejection of the proposal he places before the Senate. In listening to the last speaker, Senator Watson, we heard epitomised the problem that the Liberal Party faces when it looks at the matter. Senator Watson talked about small business but it is clear from what he has just said that he can see only one side of the small business area. He has recorded the vast number of people in Australia who are employed in small business but he has talked only about the employers. He gratuitously insulted the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission which is considering a job protection case. He implied that the Commission will not judge the matter on the facts that are placed before it. He also implied that it will make some decision that is not based on the facts.

SPEECH.PARA: We have to look at all the people who are in small business, both the employees , who have been forgotten by Senator Watson, and the employers. The Australian Labor Party has given in its election program a great deal of emphasis to this problem. The Minister for Industry and Commerce, Senator Button, has indicated the plans that we have in this area. We have no apology to make to Senator Jack Evans who is not in the chamber or to the Liberal Party about the program that is under preparation for small business. We need to look at the total picture. No matter how much Senator Watson wishes to deal with the detail of the matter, he was part of a government that did more to destroy small business in this country than has occurred since the Depression of the 1930s. It is that macroeconomic atmosphere that Senator Watson has to be taken back to now.

The Fraser Government was synonymous with confrontation and the characteristic of its seven years was that small business people had anarchy; they had no ability to plan their business. We all know that the Fraser Government's speciality was the 'next election', it was always agitating for the next election. There was no planning; there was no preparation. While all that was happening at an economic level, Ministers such as Mr Viner, the former Minister for Industrial Relations, were setting out to create an industrial relations climate that was continually disrupting industry. We had record alterations to the arbitration legislation, record threats to the trade unions and in the whole process we had industrial disputes which very often affected small business because in many cases it was in large enterprises that the industrial disputes developed but they carried through to and affected small business.

We have moved away from the Fraser Government's ideological confrontation. We have now changed to a government that is seeking in a planned and proper way, to try to take on some of the problems, problems that we received as the epitaph of the Fraser Government. Small business people should be angry with the Fraser Government's record. I will deal with some of the aspects of it to remind Senator Hill and Senator Watson of the Government of which they were a part. That situation has now changed because we have a government that, instead of causing strife, is attempting, with the Australian Council of Trade Unions accord, to go back to a centralised wage system so that people will understand where they stand in relation to regular central wage adjustments. We have the prices and incomes accord. We will, as Senator Watson said, revitalise small business.

A number of speakers in this debate have drawn attention to the way in which small business in particular has been affected by bankruptcy. In 1975, 1,200 bankruptcies occurred. This can be compared to the figure of 4,000 mentioned by Senator Jack Evans and the figure of 5,000 referred to by Senator Maguire. A tremendous increase has occurred in the number of bankruptcies. They occurred particularly in the commerce, building, construction, transport and storage industries. They are the particular areas in which small business has been affected. The Fraser Government was defeated in many ways because of its failures in that area. In Victoria, a similar position applied. A 60 per cent increase in bankruptcies in that State was typical under the previous Victorian Government. It fell and we now have the Cain Government in Victoria. Clearly this Government will be pleased to be judged by the economic climate that it creates. This Government expects, reasonably, to be given more than six months in which to try to rectify the crisis that is faced by small business in this country because of the activities of the Fraser Government.

Let us examine what this Government is doing. This week the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) has instigated an inquiry in relation to the transport industry where a great number of bankruptices have occurred. The Premier in New South Wales outlined last night a major construction program for New South Wales which I am sure will be most successful. That is an example of the co-operation between the Hawke Labor Government and the Wran Government in trying to overcome the major difficulties that particularly affect small business. In the area of the construction and building industry to which my colleague Senator Maguire referred a major initiative of the Government-it is probably the centrepiece of the Government's activity-is the revival of that industry. The revival of that industry, more than any other industry, probably will allow small business people to be employed and to be prosperous again.

Senator Jack Evans correctly said that there was a tremendously effective ratio between capital and labour in small business. The problems we have to face have resulted from the strategy of the previous Government. It is only now that we realise that the Liberal Party actually is in some way in support of small business. The reality is that while it was in government everything it did set the tone of the economic climate against small business and for big business. I ask honourable senators to examine the 1982 report of the Foreign Investment Review Board in which it is revealed that foreign investment in enterprises in Australia, as a proportion of net private investment, rose from 17.5 per cent in 1978 to 22.5 per cent in 1979, to 34.1 per cent in 1980 and to a staggering 44 per cent in 1982. A legacy of the Fraser Government was to allow foreign investment to increase dramatically in this country. In answer to what Senator Hill has said, I point out that if we look at what that investment represented we find that in the 1981-82 year out of 1,038 acquisitions only 40 were new businesses; 998 were acquisitions of existing Australian businesses. Therein lies the problem. Under the Fraser Government we had a situation in which businesses were being taken over and no effective incentive was given to Australian enterprises. In the same year, 1981-82, the Foreign Investment Review Board report showed that half of the total expected investment was attributable to 10 proposals. A large part was for the minerals processing and development sector. Half of the total investment concerned major enterprises which were being taken over in Australia.

The significance of these figures has to be considered. I should like to illustrate my point by giving one example. In Queensland, with the encouragement of the Bjelke-Petersen Government, there was a proposal for a hypermarket in Queensland, to be owned effectively by the Pick-N-Pay South African organisation . The effect of such a hypermarket of course would be to threaten all the small businesses and enterprises in the vicinity of that particular organisation. That is the problem which small business has to face. A policy of the Fraser Government which the Opposition now wishes to forget is that it has favoured big business. For the first time honourable senators opposite, who are now in opposition, are talking about small business.

The position of the Australian Labor Party, of course, is that we have changed the guidelines so that there has to be good reason for investment in Australia. There has to be new technology, new expertise and projects that will increase employment so that there is a direct benefit to the Australian people. What I am saying is that during the Fraser period of government there was a dramatic crowding out of finance for the small business sector. This Government recognises that the central role of the small business sector means that it has to get financial assistance. We recognise that one in every two persons in the private sector is employed in small business. Everything this Government does will assist that section of our economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —How are you going to do that?

—In relation to access to finance, I will reiterate what has been said by Senator Button for the benefit of Senator Messner. One of the problems is that banks and other institutions have often been overtly cautious and conservative in their assessments of whether or not small business should be financed. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) announced in May a review of the Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System. It has, as one of its terms of reference, the need for an adequate supply of finance at reasonable cost for the small business sector. That is clearly the position of the Government. As Senator Button said, it is the overall infrastructure and environment that the Labor Party wants to create. Unfortunately, banks are also reluctant to provide debt finance to small business. They often lack the necessary technical expertise or inclination to assess the prospects of small business organisations . We believe that the close relationship of the Commonwealth Development Bank of Australia with the banking system and its experience in dealing with small business make it an ideal institution for a broader role in small business finance. I hope that small business will not have the same experience that it had with the Fraser Government. Many small business people were not aware of the resources of the banking system available to them. The Fraser Government effectively did not want to let small business know of the resources that were available to them. It was a constant complaint that people were not aware of the types of investment available to them.
—That is rubbish.
—Oh, rubbish.

—Honourable senators opposite say that this is rubbish. The facts are that I represented the Opposition shadow spokesman on the Small Business Advisory Council in the last couple of years. Liberal Party appointees constantly complained about the fact that not enough advertising and not enough information was given about the facilities available to small business in this country. The Minister for Industry and Commerce and the ministry of science and technology have announced that action will be taken to encourage the development of a substantial venture capital market in Australia. An amount of $40m will be available for investment in higher risk industry ventures. This is something of which this Government can be very proud. It is one of the many initiatives that we are going to take. All I would say to Senator Jack Evans, who is not in the chamber, is that the next time he seeks to make small business a matter of public importance he will have further evidence of the Labor Government's determination and achievements in the small business area.
—The discussion is concluded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Papers are tabled in accordance with the list circulated to honourable senators. With the concurrence of the Senate, I ask that the list be incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The list read as follows-
1. Videotex in Australia: Interactive Information Services-ASTEC Report- pursuant to section 6 (2) of the Australian Science and Technology Council Act 1978.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Annual Review 1981-82

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I welcome the annual review for 1982-83 of the Australian Development Assistance Bureau. I believe that it reflects the responsibility which Australia is taking in the world context of giving aid to overseas countries. I believe that it is most important for Australia to participate in such functions in both assisting the developing nations and enhancing Australia's international standing. Looking at the record over the last three years, I see that development assistance in 1981-82 amounted to $657.8m and in 1982-83, $744.6m. For 1983-84 there is an estimate of $836.6m. I believe that the Australian Government is doing well in this regard. The amount in total represents 0.5 per cent of the gross national product. I understand that the target of the United Nations is 0.7 per cent. So Australia, I believe, is doing extremely well in this sphere. It is to be noted also that aid to Papua New Guinea in 1981-82 amounted to $252.8m. In 1982-83, it was $274.8m. In 1983-84, the amount is approximately $302.1m. There again, I believe that the aid that has been given in this area is warranted. It must be of considerable assistance to our neighbours to our north.

I believe that we have to be very careful in the way in which we allocate this money. Some people in the community say that charity begins at home. I am not one of those people. I believe that Australia, despite its pressures, tensions, strains and so on, is still a lucky country. Many countries do not have the facilities or the way of life that we have in Australia. Therefore, I believe that we should give this assistance. I believe also that it should be done not just for the sake of giving. We should ensure that we and the recipients get value from the helping dollar. Therefore, I was very pleased to see that the Government, through the committee headed by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden), intends to review assistance programs. I look forward to hearing the result.

One hears allegations around the country-an allegation was made on the Four Corners television program on 27 August 1983-that money sent to the Philippines for road building was used for roads for the military. That is just an example. Perhaps it is harsh criticism; perhaps it is not. What I am saying is that we must be very careful that the funds that are sent from Australia to these countries are well spent. There is the suggestion also that money does not reach or benefit poor people. A survey which was conducted by the Institute of Philippine Culture into one area of the ADAB program found that, despite the provision of considerable funds, 91 per cent of farmers had not improved their yield or standard of living. Many of the farmers were dropping out because of the high costs involved. This is only one example. I suggest that the review of the assistance program should look at this area. It has been suggested in other countries that food is not getting through and that money is not being spent wisely. While I believe that perhaps there is some basis for these criticisms, I do not believe there are grounds to ease funding these Third World countries. What we must do is ensure, through this committee to review assistance, that the money is well spent. Because my time has almost expired, I leave my remarks at that, despite the fact that I would like to mention many other matters on this subject.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to follow up the points made by Senator Kilgariff. I agree with him that it is essential that whatever aid moneys we give are well and fairly spent. I think there are degrees of human misery which should have a first call on our appeals. Reading through the paper on the annual review of the Australian Development Assistance Bureau, I noted that Ethiopia has been allocated food aid to the value of about $5 1/2m, whereas no food aid at all, as far as I know, has been provided for Eritrea. I want to speak briefly on behalf of the Eritrean people.

SPEECH.PARA: Although much of this northern province of Ethiopia is no longer under the control of the Ethiopian Government, there is a severe problem of malnutrition. I do not even like that word basically. The problem is one of starvation. I think that all members of parliament received a letter today from Mr Harry Martin who is the National Director of Community Aid Abroad. It was addressed to all members of this Parliament. The letter stated that 200,000 children in a population of 1 1/2 million Eritreans were confronted with starvation. That is a cold, naked fact of enormous importance. In other words, there are probably more children starving in that one place than there are children in a fair-sized Australian town. I think it is a fact that we cannot ignore. Mr Martin's letter went on:
Dr Mike Toole of Community Aid Abroad has just returned with identifiable and reliable channel of aid for people who have been by-passed by international appeal.

He mentioned that a letter had been sent to the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) urging a response. He asked us to raise this matter in Parliament and to urge the Federal Government to do something about it. I must say that I have not had time today to check out this matter in detail, although we have had something of a talk with Dr Mike Toole. We understand there is a mechanism there which he can well justify. I plead with the Government to listen to him and to consider this matter with some seriousness. Here is an area of concern, an area of great need, that is, I believe, largely overlooked by the world. I understand that some assistance is coming from Scandinavia, but that a great deal more needs to be done. I know that a number of honourable senators, including Senator Michael Tate, who is present in the chamber, have been deeply concerned for some time with the fate of the Eritrean people.

I say only that I am assured that there is a means of operation and that the areas in which people will be operating are now relatively peaceful. I say ' relatively peaceful', because I do not think anybody can make a final judgment of those matters. A fleet of vehicles is available which could be used. The competence is there. The country is prepared to allow this aid effort to proceed because I suppose it understands, as we ought to understand, the absolute enormity and appalling nature of the tragedy which is taking place in that country. Mr Deputy President, through you, I draw this matter to the renewed attention of honourable senators. Also I appeal to the Government to consider this matter most carefully and, if possible, to inform the Parliament of what action it proposes to take.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE FOR THE SCRUTINY OF BILLS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the seventh report of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills concerning:

SPEECH.PARA: Australian Capital Territory Smoking and Tobacco Products Advertisements Prohibition Bill 1983
Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1983
Home Deposit Assistance Amendment Bill 1983
Meat Inspection Bill 1983
Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Committee I lay on the table Scrutiny of Bills Alert Digest No. 9 dated 21 September 1983.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Medicare legislation sets the clock back eight years to the original Medibank and all of its associated problems. We know how health costs skyrocketed during that period. Indeed, evidence was given to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, which held an inquiry into the payments of the Commonwealth medical benefit schedule fee, that when the Fraser Government came to office health costs in Australia had accelerated at their highest rate in Australia's history. There was a rise of 36 per cent per annum. By 1979 that rate had been reduced from 36 per cent to 10 per cent per annum. There is no doubt that what this Government is about is nationalising both the doctors and the health funds. That is an absolute statement of fact. The Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) said that he wants all doctors to be paid by the Government; that he wants all doctors to accept bulk billing. Once a whole profession is paid by the Government it is nationalised. No other statement about that can be made. The Minister said very clearly that he wants all doctors to be paid by the Government. Once that has been accepted, the profession is nationalised.

SPEECH.PARA: The introduction of the new scheme will mean the death of the private health funds because the Government will take away 60 per cent of their business. Senator Gietzelt virtually admitted earlier today in his speech that this legislation would nationalise the health funds. What did the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) say in his policy speech at election time? He said that nine out of 10 Australians would pay less for health needs for themselves and their families. There has been no attempt made at the truth at all. Indeed, he was just showing his contempt for the Australian people. He knew that under the present scheme 20 per cent of the population were paying no insurance at all. Yet, he had the hide to say that nine out of 10 Australians would pay less under the new scheme. There was no attempt made at the truth. He showed nothing but sheer contempt for the Australian people.

What has the Minister said? The Minister tried to tone down the Prime Minister' s statement. He said that what the Prime Minister said was not quite true. The Minister has now said that of the remaining 80 per cent that do pay something, two-thirds will be better off. That is a little closer to the truth than the Prime Minister's statement. He was telling complete untruths in his policy speech. The Minister's statements are still far from the truth. I will come to that matter in a moment.

At present 20 per cent of the population are holders of free health cards. They include pensioners, the unemployed and low income earners. A total of 16.1 per cent of Australian families live in Queensland. They already receive free hospitalisation and pay only the basic medical fee. They do not pay a basic hospital fee. A total of 16.1 per cent of Australian families do not pay basic hospital insurance. Of course, we have to consider also the 42.4 per cent of families which are two-income families because, let there be no doubt at all, every income earner who is paying tax will pay a levy. So 42 per cent of families in Australia will not be better off; both income earners will be paying a levy. They will not be paying a family contribution. Of course, 100,000 Defence Force personnel already receive free health care. They will not be better off. They should look at the levy that they will be paying. Sixty per cent of Australians take out private insurance for private hospitalisation. They will pay a one per cent levy which includes public hospitalisation as well as a contribution to a private health fund for private hospitalisation. They will pay double for their hospitalisation. Of course we must not forget, because Senator Tate tells us that it is not nationalisation, that all doctors will not be bulk billing. Their patients will have to pay 15 per cent of the fee out of their pockets because this Government says it is wrong for them to insure themselves. Since when has it been wrong for Australians to take out insurance which they consider necessary for any reason whatsoever? This Government, in its big brother attitude, says that it knows best what is right for the Australian people and it will tell them. It says to them: 'No, it is not good for you to take out gap insurance, you should pay out of your pocket. We know what is best for you'. These facts give the lie to both Mr Hawke's original statement and to the Minister's statement that two-thirds of the remaining 80 per cent of the Australian people paying for their health care will be better off.

Let us look at the levy. It is supposed to cover 85 per cent of medical fees and a bed in a public hospital. The Minister said that that is the same as the basic hospital and medical table. Again, that is most untruthful. It covers 85 per cent of the medical fees, but it supplies only a bed in a public hospital and not the doctor of choice-only the resident who happens to be on duty at that time. It takes away a patient's choice about having his own doctor in a public hospital. If a patient wants a choice of doctor then that patient would have to pay additional private hospital insurance. People are not aware of this because the Minister has blatantly told them that the levy will be the same as basic hospital and medical insurance. That is not true because basic hospital and medical insurance at the moment covers 85 per cent of the medical fee and a bed in a public hospital with a doctor of choice-not a resident.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that our Dr Blewett?
—That is Dr Blewett. He is not a doctor of medicine and I suppose we must forgive him for that.
—No, not like your mates, ripping the system off.

—Mr Deputy President, would you please ask Senator Tate to be in his place if he cares to interject. The present basic hospital insurance contributions can go towards a bed in a private hospital also. However, this levy will not give patients a penny towards beds in private hospitals, so Dr Blewett, this Minister for Health, is not telling the Australian population the truth.

SPEECH.PARA: This one per cent levy is meant to cover the contributions that people are paying to the private funds. At present that rate differs in the various States. In my State, it is very low. It is $9.70 and if we take off the 30 per cent rebate it comes down to $6.79. In New South Wales it is $13.80 and with the 30 per cent rebate it is $9.80. Tasmanians pay 30 per cent less in their contribution rate for basic tables. Are Tasmanians to be given less of a levy? No, of course they will not. They will be subsidising the bigger States. At the moment, patients in Tasmania are advantaged because their doctors are not paid as much on the schedule fee as doctors in other States. I seek leave to incorporate the schedule in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you telling me they all keep to the schedule fee?
—Senator Tate, you are interjecting far too often.
—I am being provoked.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Provocation is not a ground for interjection.

INTERJECT.PARA: NSW Vic. Qld SA WA Tas.

TALK.START.PARA: —This table indicates that doctors in Tasmania do not get paid as much on the schedule fee as doctors do in other States. Because of this, the Tasmanian patient is advantaged by lower contributions. I will ask the Minister in the Committee stage of the debate whether it is intended that this be carried through in the levy.

SPEECH.PARA: We are asked by many people whether that one per cent will be increased. The Opposition parties have said yes. We expected the government to be honest. But there is no need for this Government to be honest and, indeed I do not believe it will be. It will keep the levy at one per cent. Anything else comes out of Consolidated Revenue anyway. Taxes are increasing as inflation rises. Any difference will be covered by Consolidated Revenue, so there is no need for the one per cent to be increased. Senator Haines today, in her typical fashion, because she understands little in this area, said that the universal health scheme will be funded by a one per cent levy. No one in this place, even the Minister, would say that. We know that the one per cent levy will raise $1 billion, according to the Minister's own figures. This is only one-eighth of the total amount because it is $8 billion that is presently paid by the Federal and State governments. That leaves out the contribution rate altogether. So Senator Haine's statement that it is a universal health scheme funded by a one per cent levy is a lot of rubbish and the people of Australia will not be hoodwinked by that.

We also have a $14m computer bought by the taxpayers. We attempted to forestall that but we were unsuccessful. The Government went ahead and bought it and double banked on all the private funds. Mr Dawkins, on 7 September, assured us that in future there would be a financial impact statement with all ministerial second reading speeches. That is lovely, high-falutin stuff, but where on earth is it? We do not have that financial impact statement with the health Bill. I wonder why. It is because he is attempting to hide the real costs from the Australian people and he has no intention of putting the financial impact statement in even though, as I say, on 7 September, long before this legislation was introduced, we were promised a financial impact statement. It has not been forthcoming.

We have been told that this scheme will involve only $62m in additional costs. That is very misleading. Once again it is not true. The Government says that the actual additional costs will be $1.742 billion. It then does a sleight of hand and says it will take the levy off that. It takes the levy off, then it also takes off the $550m which it stole from the people as their rebates and then it says that that is the actual cost. We have been told that the levy replaces the contribution rate. Now we are told that it is really just raising money to cover Medicare. It is a sleight of hand that is thoroughly dishonest. The real extra costs will be $1.742 billion-the only legitimate reduction of $80m is a saving on the reinsurance trust. That means that $1.662 billion is the additional cost of Medicare-not $62m. It really is a very deceitful situation.

We come now to the effect that Medicare will have on the consumer price index. We find that it will lower the CPI by 2.6 per cent. People of Australia are not quite aware of this yet but because they will no longer pay the contribution out of their pockets but pay it in tax the contribution will be taken out of the consumer price index and the consumer price index will fall by 2.6 per cent. The pensioners will not be too happy when they realise what is happening. A single pensioner will lose $2.30 and a married couple $3.90. Pensioners do not pay for their health care at all at the moment but they will lose money because of the sleight of hand and because the contribution rate will not come out of their pockets but the tax will. Inflation will still go ahead. It is an artificial thing, but when a married couple get their cheque they will be $3.90 down. When Senator Peter Baume tried to indicate this to Senator Crowley, she completely misunderstood the situation. She did not have a clue about what was going on and said: 'If Senator Peter Baume could tell me how lowering inflation will hurt pensioners I would be most interested'. She does not understand, because she has not been in the Senate very long, that that inflation is artificial, that that CPI reduction is an artificial situation. Inflation will keep going on but the CPI will be artificially reduced and the pensioners will lose out all the way along the line-and the Prime Minister promised that he would not be touching the pensioner's cheque. It will be interesting to see what the wage earners do about that particular matter.

What is to happen to the voluntary health organisations? Voluntary health organisations are, as the name implies, voluntary. They are run by voluntary boards. In the past they have been the cheapest. We are told that big is beautiful, that we will have one fund only and that will be much cheaper. Senator Gietzelt said that we will have one fund and nationalise the lot. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table which points out that from 1978 to 1982 the voluntary health insurance organisations were able to administer their funds at a far cheaper rate than Medibank Private.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy President. As I said a little earlier, the funds will be nationalised because 60 per cent of their business will be taken from them and given to Medibank Private, the Government organisation. Five thousand jobs will be lost. The Minister does not even argue with this figure. He says: 'Yes, of course the jobs will be lost, but the Government will pick up some of them'. He has offered to pick up 2,500 employees-half of them. That means we will have an additional 2,500 highly paid public servants and 5,000 fewer people in private industry. My goodness, that is a jolly good compromise!
—That is not true.

—That is exactly what the Minister for Health said-that the Government would pick up 2,500 highly paid public servants and get rid of 5,000 people out of the private funds. The private funds have been told that they can diversify. I will come back to that at the Committee stage because there is no guarantee that Medibank Private will be allowing them to diversify without its diversifying too.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps we can have a little look at what Senator Haines has been up to. She has been blowing her own trumpet and telling us she has done a tremendous amount of negotiating while we sat back and did nothing. She said in effect: 'The Liberals seemed to have been sitting back for months taking things quietly. I don't know whether it was because they hadn't got their act together, because they weren't particularly concerned or because they were going to vote against the whole lot and weren't interested in helping anyone along the way'. I have spent the last three months negotiating with the Government, at times with acrimony but generally with courtesy on both sides and have finally come up with a considerable amount of co-operation, the result of which is that quite a number of concessions that will assist the funds, their employees and their contributors have been achieved.

Let us have a look at what else Senator Haines has done. She has said she has made agencies. Dr Blewett has ridiculed that. Last Sunday week he said that he had really conned Senator Haines because all he has said is that other funds can act as a post box. Dr Blewett has said: 'Of course the Government will not pay the funds for this; anyone can post it off. Get your next-door neighbour to put a 27c stamp on an envelope and to act as a post box'. What advantage would that be to the private funds? Absolutely none! Indeed, the private funds will be down the drain because they will not be paid for it. What else did Senator Haines do for the private funds? She acted as a negotiator for three months while we all sat back. She came up with the suggestion that the private funds would be able to fill the $150 gap in insurance for the chronically ill. It is not to be paid by the private funds; it has not a thing to do with the private funds. It is just another couple of million dollars cost to the Government and the taxpayer. That is no help to the private funds. What has Senator Haines been doing in her three months of negotiation? She certainly has not helped the funds or those 5, 000 people in any way at all. She has done absolutely nothing and, as Dr Blewett indicated in his talk-back session last Sunday, he conned her. Boy, did he ever con her!

Mr Deputy President, we come now to a matter of grave importance to Tasmania. Again, this Government cannot be trusted. I have before me quite a number of letters between Minister for Health Blewett and Minister for Health John Cleary in Tasmania. I seek leave to have these documents tabled.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The whole thing started on 15 April in Adelaide when Dr Blewett had a meeting. He specified then that Tasmania would have a choice of remaining in the cost sharing arrangements or taking up an alternative packet. That was on 15 April. Between 28 and 29 April the Health Ministers Conference was held in Hobart. He then said that all the detail will be arranged at a later meeting in Canberra. On 18 May Dr Blewett wrote to Mr Cleary in relation to the hospital cost sharing agreement and formally offered budgets he had approved under that agreement for the financial years 1981-82, 1982-83 and 1983-84. Mr Cleary wrote back and said that he would agree to the 1983-84 budget under the cost sharing agreement-note, 'under the cost sharing agreement'-subject to the inclusion of certain appropriate adjustments. On 15 June there was another meeting of the Health Ministers and there was no talk at all of the termination of the cost sharing agreement. A transcript of that meeting shows that Dr Blewett said:

SPEECH.PARA: It has never been my intention that we should try to dictate to the States on these matters, but to try to get an arrangement which we can all live with satisfactorily.

We then had the Premiers Conference and, following that, a communique. A draft report of that communique was queried by the Premier of Tasmania, and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) was told by the Premier that he could not agree with the draft communique. Mr Keating said: 'Don't worry, further detail has to be agreed to'. Because of Mr Keating's assurance the Premier of Tasmania made his biggest mistake ever. He took the word of the Treasurer and agreed to the communique. The biggest mistake the Premier could have made was to trust the Treasurer and take his word at that Premiers Conference.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is certainly a very serious allegation. You had better be right.

—It is an extremely serious allegation. The honourable senator has the letters; he can read the Premier's letter. On 13 July a letter and a telex were sent to Dr Blewett by the Tasmanian Minister for Health requesting some details and stating:

SPEECH.PARA: Clarification is vital to Tasmania before any final decision can be made.
On 14 July, Dr Blewett, at the Health Ministers Conference, said:
. . . there will need to be officer to officer decisions with the two cost sharing States . . .

So by 14 July, well after the Premiers Conference, Dr Blewett acknowledged that there would be officer to officer decisions with the two cost sharing States. There were still two cost sharing States; no other decision had been made. On 28 July Mr Cleary got a letter from Dr Blewett saying that it was accepted at the Premiers Conference that Tasmania would move away from the current cost sharing arrangements. What a double banger that statement is. All one has to do is read the transcripts. I turn now to 16 August and a letter to Dr Blewett from Mr Cleary, our Minister for Health, saying that Dr Blewett's assumption that Tasmania would terminate the cost sharing agreement was a misinterpretation of Tasmania's position. No more was done or said until the Budget came out and Tasmania realised that the Commonwealth Minister had no intention of discussing it any further, no intention of having officer to officer discussions or agreements but indeed had overidden the State once more.

TALK.START.PARA: —You do not mean--

—Senator Tate should be sticking up for his State. He should at least read the letters. This is a disgrace. Immediately the Budget was announced Mr Cleary said: 'This is not the situation as indicated in my letter of 16 August'. We will come to this again because there were further letters right up to 14 September and 15 September when the Premier of Tasmania wrote to the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, appealing to him to ask Keating, because Keating had promised him--
—Who is Keating?

—The Treasurer had promised him at the Premiers Conference that there would be further talks about it. The deception has been colossal. I am appalled that the Premier of my State had trusted Mr Keating, the Treasurer of the Government, and had been let down so badly. We cannot take a man's word, when that Minister lets the Premier down as he has. We will come to that later in the Committee stage. I support all the amendments put by the Opposition.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Contrary to Senator Walters's opening statement these Medicare Bills are a reminder of the fact that this is 1983. The shibboleths of 1973, 1974 and 1975 will not do. During some of the wilder allegations of the previous speaker I was strongly reminded of a pathetic advertisement that was run in all the Australian newspapers in 1974-75 of a rather appealing, I suppose, statement being made by a prospective patient who said: 'But darling, I do want my own doctor and my own hospital room'. We have a population now which is much better educated about health care, a medical profession which to a large degree has seen the light, a Government committed to preventative measures, and initiatives in community and occupational health, rehabilitation and domiciliary care.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to address some of the less wild allegations made by the previous speaker and will leave the more specific ones to those with a better knowledge of Tasmania. I believe that in all the discussion about unemployment of clerical assistants previously or currently employed by private insurance funds, there has been very little recognition of the fact that private funds have a very high rate of worker turnover. In any case, many funds have been computerising at a great rate over the last months and many of their workers have been made redundant. I hear very few complaints and see very few tears on behalf of those workers. In case any pensioners were listening this afternoon and became highly confused by the allegations that were made about the cost of Medicare I assure them that what we heard were hypotheses and wild guesses about the cost of living in 12 months time. Of course, pensioners will not pay the levy.

In joining in debate on the Medicare Bills my purpose is to make an appeal on behalf of all those Australians who depend on this Government for a scheme of medical and hospital care which is equitable, easily understood and effective, and who voted overwhelmingly on 5 March for such a scheme. My appeal is to the members of the medical profession who by their co-operation can make Medicare work and work well. If doctors really have the welfare of their patients at heart they will abide by the spirit of the legislation and by the best traditions of their profession. There is no need, I know, for this sort of admonition to be made in the vast majority of cases; compassionate doctors of social integrity will continue to provide high quality care in a responsible manner. There may be some doctors who are convinced or confused by the irrational opposition of the New South Wales branch of the Australian Medical Association to direct billing, or bulk billing as it is commonly known. Direct billing is a characteristic which will undoubtedly enhance Medicare for consumers and which in my view holds great advantages for doctors and the practice of medicine generally.

There are the obvious gains to practitioners of bulk billing of time and effort saved, the avoidance of bad debts and less complicated bookkeeping. Estimates of these cost savings have suggested that 15 per cent is on the conservative side, resulting in no economic disadvantage for the doctor. If the busy practitioner then finds that an accounts clerk is redundant or partly so, I suggest that the costs saved should be invested in improving the practice by, for example, employing a counsellor or a physiotherapist or, better still, someone to provide care for the children of patients or those children attending with their parents , a perennial need in suburban practices and a service which would be of enormous assistance to patients and practices alike.

We still hear the monetarist myth that services must be paid for even with just a small amount if they are to be properly valued. Even if this were true, how could it be so and how could it be a justification for refusing to direct bill? For a start, most people will be paying one per cent of their income towards their health care and will be very well aware of the fact. They will be justifiably resentful, I believe, about the doctor who refuses to direct bill on that spurious ground. Does a doctor, unlike a professor of medicine or a school teacher, need to be continually reassured of the value of service given by having the patient reminded of its cash value? I believe we have had ample evidence over the past 10 years of potential for a greatly improved relationship between givers and receivers of medical services. We have a new generation of practitioners in all health disciplines who do not consider their qualifications as the equivalent of an open cheque on the public purse, who are prepared to co- operate with this Government, and who need no constant reminder of 15 per cent of their fees to bolster their sense of self-esteem.

I turn now to the bogey of abuse and overuse referred to by the previous speaker and by a number of others during this debate. It is now clearly understood that apart from the patient's initial visit it is overwhelmingly the practitioner who determines the length and cost of treatment. As the percentage of total private hospital beds has risen from 1.04 per thousand population in 1971 to 1.34 per thousand population in 1981, which is a 27 per cent increase, the number of clients has tended to expand to occupy those beds. There are some demographical explanations-for example, a changing of the age structure of the population-and there have been changing expectations. But it is generally accepted that more doctors and more hospital beds mean more hospitalisation and more surgery, much of it of questionable necessity. If one looks at the published statistics of medical use per capita for the year 1975-76 and compares it with earlier and subsequent years, one sees that the number of medical services per head increased in 1975-76 to 5.50 compared with 5.39 for the previous year, an increase of only 2 per cent. Services per head in subsequent years were 5.70 for 1976-77, a 3.6 per cent increase and 6.58 for 1979-80, a 4.9 per cent increase.

These figures have risen year by year in line with changes in the age structure of the population and a general increase in medical utilisation which, interestingly enough, rose by the largest percentage a year after Medibank. Irrespective of the insurance system in operation, medical utilisation has risen by an increasing percentage every year of the decade. Was there any massive abuse of the free public hospital care offered under Medibank in that fearful year? Again, the answer is no. The initial effect of universal entitlement to free public hospital care was to increase the proportion of public patient days by a little over 4 per cent, equivalent to about 3 per cent for all hospital patients. The subsequent movement was about one per cent a quarter. This varied from State to State, suggesting that factors other than cost were involved. Perhaps paradoxically private hospital use increased in the Medibank year of 1975-76.

These are clearly crucial responsibilities for the medical profession to address, individually and collectively, but not by any test of what is fair and reasonable a justification for penalising victims by refusing to direct bill and thereby sabotage the scheme. The humane and responsible practitioner will now have the opportunity to build a thriving and popular practice amongst those on low incomes who have only briefly in the past 10 years had access to such low cost care outside the public hospital system-people of all ages seeking contraceptive advice, adolescents with their particular problems, families with young children and all of those whom this legislation seeks to assist.

Medical practitioners in Australia are in a unique position. They are members of the only industry-I remind Senator Walters-whose right to private entrepreneurship is enshrined in the Constitution. They are educated at great expense and in some cases are prone to consider themselves thereby entitled to high rewards. Others, probably the majority, take their responsibilities very seriously. Let me repeat my initial plea to practitioners of good faith to be prepared to bulk bill, to do the decent thing by the people and by the Government which the people elected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Townley Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —So far in this debate on the Medicare Levy Bill 1983 and cognate Bills, we have heard from several Tasmanians in the other House and from Senator Walters in this House. I think all of them have made very important points that do relate to this series of Bills, to which the Opposition has moved an amendment which points out the difference in its philosophy with regard to the different types of health schemes available. At the outset I say that I regard this legislation as truly socialistic. It certainly reveals this Hawke Government in its true colours. It is socialist manoeuvre introduced by Mr Hawke's socialist Government. This legislation will effectively nationalise a large part of the health services of this country. It will change the way health services are given to the people of Australia. I will mention in a few moments the particular effect it will have on an agreement between Tasmania and the Commonwealth.

SPEECH.PARA: First of all, what are the essential features of this legislation? If I had to choose one, I think I would say it was the lack of choice. Anyone who has followed the debate either here or in the other House will have realised that we will have much less choice after Medicare comes into operation. Medicare will be run by a centralised bureaucracy that will be controlled in and from Canberra. Medical insurance will be limited and controlled. Doctors will be made to bulk bill. I think one will find that as the costs of this scheme go up, as they inevitably will, the doctors will be squeezed financially. That is certainly what has happened in other countries. Another group that will be adversely affected when the squeeze comes, when this monster gets out of control, is private hospitals. Just why it is that the Government does not like private hospitals, I do not know. But I am sure that a greater number of Government members and senators would not care one iota if the private hospitals failed completely and vanished entirely from the health scene in this country.

I am worried a lot by this big brother attitude, by the attitude that Canberra knows best and by the entire philosophy that Canberra can operate something like this better than is presently being done. But perhaps I am worried most about the long term cost of Medicare. We saw today on the front page of the Sydney Morning Herald that a quarter of the people in this country now depend on Commonwealth benefits. The article contains a list showing the categories that were applying for and getting certain pensions and benefits in June 1973 and compared them with the figures as at June 1983. I realise that Senator Gietzelt did make a statement a little earlier stating that the figures were not entirely accurate, but I think it would be for the benefit of the Senate if I were to have that table incorporated in Hansard, and I seek leave to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President. That is one area in which the cost of running this country is getting out of control. There will be an increased tax bill of about $1.7 billion per annum just to run Medicare. That will cover additional government expenditure that was previously met by private insurance. Only one-eighth of the total cost of the health scheme will be covered by the one per cent levy. That one per cent is, of course, an arbitrary figure. So Medicare will give the illusion of free health care, but it will be hiding from the consumer the real cost. I believe that it will not improve health care or the economics of health care at all in this country. As well as the Commonwealth cost of $1.7 billion, the States will have to raise additional billions of dollars for the health care of their people. All of this has been well covered by other speakers, particularly Senator Peter Baume in his very sensible speech. I refer anyone wanting details of this matter to his speech, which was made yesterday.

SPEECH.PARA: I now say something about the Canadian experience of health care because in many ways Canada and Australia are comparable. We have similar parliaments. Canada has provinces where we have States. The populations, although different, are certainly comparable, and the Canadian medical scheme is even called Medicare. Mediscare is what one doctor called it when I was talking to him last night. I think that will be the way this scheme will eventually end up. At the moment the Canadian budget is so squeezed that even little simple items in the wards of the hospitals are unavailable, I refer to items such as facial tissues. What is much worse, the patients are under care of doctors whose system training has desensitised them to such an extent that they function seemingly without compassion and, I am told, even without common courtesy. There is interaction in Canada between the Federal Government, the provincial governments, the medical fraternity and the taxpayer. Of course it is the taxpayer who, one way or another, has to pay the other three.

In Canada, the Federal Government has tried to lay down the law for the provincial hospitals to follow. That is what is going to happen here. Not only State hospitals but also private ones will be under the control of this Canberra -run bureaucracy. The manner of payments to the provinces in Canada is linked to the gross national product. It is not linked at all to the cost of running the hospitals. As the economy has slumped in that country over the last few years so the Federal contribution to the hospitals has also fallen. The provinces had to increase their taxes, cut back on services or charge some patients directly for their services. That is what has caused the turmoil in the Canadian system at the moment.

Is that what we want or what we want to head towards in this country? Is the Federal Government going to be able to keep finding the money necessary to feed this system? Why will it work in Australian when nearly every country that has tried to give every person the health services that he or she wants has found that the costs are prohibitive. I think Senator Lewis also mentioned Canada as well as the United Kingdom. Sweden is an example which is often mentioned by our socialist friends. That country's economy is in real trouble at the moment. I was talking to some Swedish people the other day and they said that if Sweden's deficit keeps increasing the way it does, which is largely due to its social services and so on, in the early 1990s its entire budget will go towards paying interest on the money it has had to borrow to sustain those services.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is your authority for this?
—I was talking to some members of the Swedish Parliament just a couple of days ago.
—What party?

—I did not ask them to what party they belonged. I could find that out for the Minister, and I am willing to do so. It is largely hospital costs that run away. The activities of the medical fraternity and general practitioners do not really lead to an expansion of costs. However, try as one may, it is extremely difficult to keep hospital costs down. I do not think there will be the incentive under Medicare for hospitals to manage money as economically as they would under the present scheme. Of course, I am not saying for a moment that costs will increase the day after the introduction of Medicare . I think we will see a more gradual increase in costs. I can easily see the arbitrary levy of one per cent will be lifted as time goes by. Of course, what the levy does not cover will be paid for by general tax. This cost will either gradually increase our deficit or it will lead to increased taxation.

SPEECH.PARA: I cannot believe that at the moment this country can afford to start spending on such a scheme. Our deficit is so huge that we are joining the league of large borrowing countries such as Mexico, Poland and Argentina. Although our quantity of debt may not be very high, our debt per head to the international banking community is very high. In fact, it is certainly higher than that of Argentina. The most recent figures I have are for last year. Since then, of course, we have budgeted to increase the debt per head from nearly $1,900 to something like $2, 300. Again, for the benefit of the Senate, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a small table which compares the position in Australia, Poland, Brazil and Argentina.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some people say that the recovery in this country that is going to help finance this system will follow the United States recovery. We do not always understand just how that happens. However, we get direct benefits from any increases in sales in America. For instance, Tasmanians sell a lot of zinc to the United States which is used in the manufacture of cars. So if car production goes up we make more sales. That is just one example. The question that is haunting people in the United States is whether or not the recovery will be sustained. The Federal Reserve Board in the United States has shown a determination to keep the growth of money supply in check in order to control inflation. That has tended to drain from the banking system any money that might otherwise be available. It reduces the supply of credit and so dries up interest rates. Interest rates in the United States have gone up by 2 per cent since May. Many people in that country feel that recovery is linked to interest rates. They argue that if interest rates are low one can get some good recovery; as interest rates go higher one gets less recovery; and if interest rates go high enough recovery can be stalled. As I say, at the moment recovery is continuing. However , it takes a while for the effect of interest rates to filter through the statistics of a country. The constant worry in the United States is the fact that there is little or no likelihood of any fall in interest rates, certainly not in the near foreseeable future. In fact, the real prospect in that country is that interest rates will go higher.

SPEECH.PARA: One may ask: What effect does that have on us in Australia and why do I relate interest rates to Medicare? Many people in Australia are taking the United States recovery for granted. I believe that is a grave error, as is just waiting for the recovery in that country to affect us and sweep us along with it. As the United States interest rates go up we will find it harder to attract money to cover our deficit. I believe that our interest rates will have to increase even higher than they are now due to competition in the international markets for the available money. I would not be at all surprised to see our interest rates go up 2 per cent or 3 per cent in the next 12 months. I say this because the Government will have to try to cover the cost of our huge deficit in some way. It is my belief that anything that adds to our deficit, as will Medicare, is certainly at this stage of our country's life a very bad thing. Higher deficits make recovery from the present recession we are in quite difficult. The present recession is quite different from any recession we have seen since the war. We are not necessarily going to follow the United States pattern.

Of course, I should mention that we are not the only country which is trying to get money to cover deficits. Many Third World countries are also in there bidding, making competition for that international money supply even more difficult for us. Therefore, as I think Senator Watson said this afternoon in another debate, it is even more likely that our interest rates will rise. What I am trying to emphasise is that this country cannot rely on outside help for its recovery. Australia has to recover by itself. So we need to control the deficit. We need to control expenditure on unnecessaries, and I believe the introduction of Medicare now is not necessary. Medicare could lead to a higher deficit and consequent higher interest rates which will affect everyone, which will stop any confidence in the country and which will tend to slow recovery. Medicare is a huge, unnecessary expense for the Government at this time, and I believe that it will become increasingly more expensive to operate as time goes on.

While I am on the financial aspect of Medicare and its implications to the deficit, I would like to mention the Tasmanian situation.
