The Tasmanian and Federal governments have a formal cost-sharing agreement for public hospital services which is not due to expire until June 1985. The Federal Government has introduced legislation to revoke the agreement, even though the agreement could remain in force and would not in any way jeopardise the introduction of Medicare . The Tasmanian Minister for Health is of the opinion that the initiative taken by the Commonwealth in introducing this legislation into the Parliament to terminate the cost-sharing agreement is without any legal or constitutional foundation. He says in a letter dated--

TALK.START.PARA: —But with his agreement.
—No, I am sorry. I do not think it is with his agreement. I will seek leave to incorporate the letter in a moment. It will show quite clearly that it is not with his agreement. In his letter he says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it is a serious and indefensible breach of trust and is at considerable odds with normal relations between Governments.
Perhaps for the benefit of the Senate I should seek leave to incorporate this 1 1/2-page letter from Mr Cleary, the Tasmanian Minister for Health, which is dated 16 September 1983.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Office of the Minister for Health Hobart, Tasmania 16th September, 1983. Open letter to all Tasmanian Members of Commonwealth Parliament and to all Senators
Medicare LegislationCommonwealth/State Cost Sharing Agreement for Public Hospital Service
It is with great concern that I write to you on a major matter of importance to the Tasmanian Government.
The Commonwealth Government has introduced legislation into the Federal Parliament to revoke its cost sharing agreement with the Tasmanian Government for public hospital services.
Our two Governments have a formal cost sharing agreement for public hospital services which is not due to expire until June 1985.
It is possible for this agreement to remain in force, and not in any way jeopardize the introduction of Medicare.

As evidence of this, I attach for your information, a formal exchange of letters between the Commonwealth Minister and myself (dated 17th May, 1983, and 23rd May, 1983 respectively) agreeing to a budget for 1983/84 under the agreement.

However, notwithstanding this fact, the Tasmanian Government appreciates the desire of the Commonwealth Government to have a uniform set of financial arrangements with all States. To this end, on behalf of the Tasmanian Government , I have consistently conveyed to the Federal Minister for Health, the Hon. N. Blewett, M.P., a willingness to examine any proposals put forward for consideration to discontinue the Cost Sharing Agreement prior to its scheduled expiry date of 30 June, 1985. To date, the Tasmanian Government has not received a firm proposal from the Commonwealth Government for the Agreement to be discontinued and for a specific indication of the actual amount of any grant that would replace it.

I would have thought that until such a proposal is received, considered and agreed to by the Tasmanian Government, the Cost Sharing Agreement would continue until its expiry date. In my understanding, to vary the agreement, which is ratified by reciprocal Commonwealth and State legislation, there needs to be agreement in writing between the two Heads of Government and subsequent enactment of legislation.
Unless, and until, such an agreement is reached, the Tasmanian Government will continue to fulfil its obligations under the Cost Sharing Agreement.

In my opinion, the initiative taken by the Commonwealth Government in introducing legislation into the Federal Parliament, to terminate the Cost Sharing Agreement, is without any legal or constitutional foundation. In my opinion, it is a serious and indefensible breach of trust and is at considerable odds with normal relations between Governments.

I attach for your information copies of relevant correspondence and other documentation relevant to the negotiations which have taken place between the Commonwealth and Tasmanian Governments on both Medicare and the future of the Hospitals Cost Sharing Agreement between our two Governments.

On behalf of the Tasmanian Government I would be pleased if you could take whatever steps are necessary in the Federal Parliament to delay or defer or veto the legislation soon to be considered in the Senate which will terminate the Tasmanian Cost Sharing Agreement.

As I said earlier, this is a matter of considerable importance to the financial relations between Tasmanian and Commonwealth Governments. The Tasmanian Government would appreciate your support on this matter.
Should you have any queries or wish to discuss this matter with me personally, please do not hesitate to contact me at the earliest opportunity.
Yours sincerely, John Cleary Minister for Health

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me conclude by saying that I believe that 'Mediscare' is the right name for this scheme. I hope I am wrong, but right now I am scared of the cost of this Canberra madness; I am scared of the big brother effect; I do not like the idea of identity cards that people will be required to carry; and I know we cannot afford such a scheme at this stage. I would have preferred to see a gradual improvement in the scheme that is presently working fairly well. Mr Whitlam learned that Australians do not like rapid change. I believe that Mr Hawke will regret the day that these Bills and ideas were brought into this Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that I am pleased to be speaking immediately after Senator Townley and not Senator Walters, because at least my blood pressure has had a chance to go down since Senator Walters finished her speech. Her ranting and raving was stirring up honourable senators on this side of the chamber. That is not to say that Senator Townley did not also talk a lot of nonsense, but he did not present it in the same stirring way as did Senator Walters. Even Senator Townley talked about this scheme involving socialisation, echoing Senator Walters's accusations about nationalisation and that sort of nonsense.

SPEECH.PARA: Certainly, this scheme emphasises the differences between the Government and the Opposition. But it is a bit much to say that bulk billing or direct billing of the Health Insurance Commission involves nationalisation. Medical practitioners will have a free choice in what they decide to do. If 100 per cent of them happen to bulk bill-I would be very surprised if they did-that is entirely their choice. It is stretching the word a bit to call that nationalisation.

The other ignorance of Senator Walters that needs to be pointed out and put to rest-I will pick out some of the things that she referred to-was her claim that what the levy will cover is not the same as what basic hospital and medical insurance presently covers. She suggested that under the present scheme someone with just basic hospital insurance is not limited to being a patient in a public hospital. In fact, such a person is so limited. Senator Walters tried to suggest that a person with such basic insurance was covered for private medical costs as a public patient. Of course, that is just untrue. It is an example of the way in which she tried to mislead the Parliament and the public about the introduction of this scheme.

At the height of her speech, if one may use that word, she also claimed that Medicare would not give a penny towards private hospital costs. Of course, as everyone knows and as Senator Peter Baume, who is in the chamber at the moment, will acknowledge, a subsidy will be paid from Medicare towards the costs of private hospital accommodation. Of course, on top of that, everyone will be covered for his medical costs in a private hospital. Those who take out private insurance to cover the additional costs not covered by the Medicare subsidy will , of course, be able to claim the expenses of the medical practioners who treat them in that private hospital, which will be of course, an additional charge on Medicare.

I will refer briefly to the argument that has been manufactured in recent days by Mr Cleary, the Tasmanian Minister for Health, and some of the Tasmanian Opposition members of Parliament. Mr Cleary has suggested that he did not mean what he said when several months ago he agreed to the scheme. He is now apparently indulging in rearguard action on the matter and trying to generate a dispute where there was not one. Of course he agreed to the scheme. He knew it involved the ending of the previous cost sharing agreement. I understand that he will have further discussions with Dr Blewett tomorrow, when no doubt that will be made clear to him and he will be reminded of his previous agreement. I should point out parenthetically that the cost sharing agreement that is apparently being so definitely defended by the Opposition and by the present Tasmanian Government was, of course, a continuation of the agreement made by the previous Federal Labor Government and a former State Labor government under the original Medibank arrangements. It is a bit much for Mr Cleary to jump in and oppose the ending of the cost sharing agreement and its replacement with more uniform arrangements which are proposed under this scheme.

One other point from Senator Walters that I need to answer relates to her being upset about there not being any gap insurance. She argued that everyone should have the right to insure for whatever he wants. May I point out that even the previous Government did not allow insurance for the gap between the 100 per cent schedule fee and whatever the medical practitioner happened to charge. Those who bothered to, or thought they could afford to, take out extras insurance and have included in that coverage the gap between 85 per cent and 100 per cent of the schedule fee, found themselves still having to pay a gap to the medical practitioner. It gave the profession, or some members of it, an opportunity to set their fees at higher than the schedule fee and still to argue that individuals should make a contribution towards their medical expenses because they were covered for gap insurance and that therefore doctors had to charge a higher fee.

What the Government is doing in preventing gap insurance and limiting the maximum cover under Medicare is ensuring that there will be a much greater observance by the medical profession of the schedule fee. Of course, not all doctors will do that. Unfortunately, there is no obligation on them to do so. But at least there will be some indication to them that the so-called moiety that patients will be required to pay if the doctors do not bulk bill will not be covered. I remind the Senate that the Australian Medical Association insisted many years ago that there should be a patient contribution. Yet we have had Senator Walters getting upset about the abolition of the option of gap insurance .

I wish to make a brief reference to what I though I heard Senator Lewis say earlier in the debate this morning. It seemed to me that the central point of his opposing the scheme was that, because everyone would be entitled to treatment in a public hospital, somehow or other there would be a ranking of the access of individuals to that treatment. He suggested that Senator Crowley, whom he followed, and other senators and medical practitioners would be able to queue jump in public hospitals. In my time of seeking treatment in public hospitals I have never sought, nor has the opportunity ever been offered to me, to jump the queue. If there had been any suggestion that I could, I would certainly not have accepted it. One takes one's place and accepts it. It seemed to me a quite empty objection by Senator Lewis to the scheme. I point out to him anyway that the change in the health insurance arrangements will not affect that sort of situation. Those who at present are entitled to treatment in public hospitals because they have at least basic health insurance will, of course, be entitled to it under Medicare. There will not be much change in public habits under this scheme.

It has to be pointed out that, whether we like it or not, Medicare is not all that revolutionary a scheme. To hear some members of the Opposition one would think that the end of the world was at hand. But at least some of them are acknowledging that the scheme is a change in the way of paying for health care. It is a little different from the argument that we had to put up with during that period from about 1969 through 1975, during that runup to the introduction of Medibank in mid-1975, when there was no acknowledgement from anyone that this was really all it was. The Opposition suggested that it would make traumatic changes to the method of health care in Australia. One can see that the tune of the Opposition and of large chunks of the medical profession for that matter, have changed quite a bit. As I have said, whether or not one likes it this scheme does not change things very much at all. It does not change the general system of private practice, fee for service medicine. That is left unscathed. In fact, it is further propped up and underwritten by Medicare. What it does mean is that all Australians will be covered for their health insurance and they will pay for it in a fair way. At the moment people have to pay for a substitute for basic health insurance. It is the same amount regardless of income. When Medicare comes into operation people will pay according to their means as they pay for education, defence or any other essential service in this country.

This debate is in a way a re-run of the Medibank debate of several years ago. However, one must acknowledge that at least this is a cooler debate. Of course, the numbers in the Senate are now different. There is general acknowledgement that the scheme will come into existence and that people's health insurance arrangements will be improved because of it. While one could say a lot more in this debate, especially in answer to some of the wilder accusations of the Opposition, I believe that the matter is urgent. This debate has been enough of a marathon as it is. I want the Minister for Health, Dr Blewett, to be able to celebrate the passage of this legislation tonight, or, at the latest, tomorrow. It will be the culmination of his months of hard work developing this scheme and doing the necessary negotiations and explanations. I certainly look forward to its introduction on 1 February.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1983 and associated Bills. The main features of the legislation are that it will increase dramatically the cost of health care in Australia and costs to a great many Australians. It will quickly lead to a much lower quality of health care than we presently have; it will destroy the traditional doctor-patient relationship; it will lead to overcrowding in hospitals and overservicing by doctors; private hospitals will be severely disadvantaged; the number of health funds will be significantly reduced and many will have to close their doors. The essence of the proposed legislation is a return to the tried and failed Whitlam Government Medibank scheme, except that on this occasion it is designed to destroy irretrievably private health fund insurance in Australia. Proponents of Medicare have argued, among other things, that by replacing a number of privately operated, non-profit health insurance organisations with a government run scheme, Medicare will be simpler than the present situation. For the vast majority of Australians this system will not be simple, suitable or cheap.

SPEECH.PARA: For people who are satisfied with basic health insurance cover certainly there will be only one authorised insurer to operate in Australia, namely, Medicare. However, for those who seek to insure themselves for private accommodation, for a choice of doctor and for a variety of services, which will not be included in the Medicare schedule-for example, chiropractic consultations-the system is infinitely more complicated. Such people will have to go to Medicare for a refund of their basic expenses and to their private health fund for that portion of their expenses which exceeds the basic medical or hospital rate unless, of course, they are in Medibank Private. Once they could have obtained a full refund through the private fund with which they have chosen to insure themselves but now they will have to perform two separate operations to get exactly the same result. In the first place, two operations will be necessary for them to pay their premiums, a one per cent levy on income for Medicare and a further payment for what are termed ancillary benefits and gap insurance. If Members of the Labor Government regard that as a simplification of the present situation I really despair of their ability as administrators of our economy and our country .

Proponents of Medicare also argue that the income levy is a fairer way of determining premiums than the present flat insurance premium. What they have chosen to ignore is that the disadvantaged in the community, such as elderly pensioners, the unemployed and the low income earners, are already provided with free medical and hospital care under the previous Government's arrangements. For them nothing will change by the introduction of Medicare, except, of course, for single pensioners who will lose $2.30 a week of their pension and for married couples who will lose $3.90 by what appears to be a sleight of hand, in that the Government has removed this expense from the consumer price index. The Labor Government is committed to tying pensions to indexation. Of course, with the CPI being artificially deflated pensions will, of course, go down. As far as this legislation is concerned, absolutely nothing will be achieved and pensioners will receive nothing except a lower pension.

I admit that for those who are marginally above the low income cutoff point there are difficulties in meeting the full costs of insuring themselves. However , as my colleague the Minister for Health in the previous Government made clear on a number of occasions both prior to and after the 5 March election, plans were being drawn up to alleviate this problem. There is no need to make these dire and fundamental changes to the private health insurance system simply to overcome this defect. A sensitive Liberal Government was dealing with the problem without the overreaction of setting up a nationalised health insurance system. In any case, the levy is not as fair as its supporters claim. At present single and family rates are offered by the private funds, reflecting their understanding of the likely average utilisation of health facilities. Under Labor's levy system, a single person will pay the same as a married person who has the same income, despite the fact that a single person is likely to make much less use of health services than a family.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will there be family rates for defence expenditure?

—We have the circumstance in which a married couple, without a family and who are both working, pay the levy twice. The Government's pay for use principle is being very selectively applied in this situation. There are many obnoxious features in this legislation. Perhaps one of the most unpleasant aspects of it is the Government's crude and blatant attempt not only to force doctors to bulk bill but also, in doing so, to force people out of their free choice of a private health fund. Why would the Government provide an opportunity for doctors, provided they bulk bill, to accept 85 per cent of the standard fee as full payment from Medicare and further legislate that in the event a doctor does not bulk bill, the patient must pay the balance and yet, at the same time, not allow the patient to take out insurance with a private fund to cover the 15 per cent difference? The answer is obvious. The intention is to destroy the private medical funds and to force doctors to bulk bill. At the same time the Australian Labor Party is increasing, by $4m, surveillance of overservicing. By the very nature of its enforced proposals it is encouraging doctors to overservice to make up the difference and is encouraging patients to overuse the facilities.

SPEECH.PARA: By offering what the Government terms free basic cover it will also create a situation in which greater pressure will be placed upon the public hospitals to the point where perhaps some private hospitals will be forced out of business. It will be a sad day indeed in this country when much needed hospital capacity is sacrificed on the altar of socialist ideology. Perhaps the most important issue at stake here is the market efficiency of nationalised health insurance. I refer to the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System which commented on this matter in chapter 26 of its final report:

Retention of government ownership of a financial institution is only justified from the point of view of efficiency of the financial system if both currently and on reasonably expectations for the future:
(i) it fills a market 'gap'. . .
(ii) the market gap would not be filled as effectively if the institution were privately owned; and
(iii) it represents the most cost-effective method of dealing with the market gap. . .

I put it to the Senate at this point that Medicare fulfils none of those criteria. With 39 privately owned funds, not including Medibank Private, open to public membership as well as 27 employer-operated funds, there is clearly no gap in health insurance which is required to be filled. There is already a sufficient number of funds. When the free medical and hospital arrangements for the disadvantaged are taken into account, the community is almost completely covered without Medicare. As I indicated earlier, in relation to the people marginally above the low income cut off point who were having difficulty meeting health insurance premiums, some adjustments were already being considered by the previous Government which would have ensured that coverage by the present scheme would have been universal. In terms of filling a market gap, Medicare is irrelevant. Let us examine the second criterion of the Campbell Committee. Medicare will not fulfil the market requirements as effectively as privately operated funds. I have already mentioned the two step operation which people who have insured themselves for more than the basic cover will have to perform to get their refund. The Government's new arrangements will not inconvenience a small minority in this respect because, in fact, the vast majority of members of the private funds currently insure themselves for more than the basic cover. Of the seven million Australians who have private medical insurance, 4.5 million or 64 per cent have taken out gap and ancillary cover with their funds. More than half of the people insured for medical benefits with private funds-I am excluding Medibank Private from these figures though the trend there is no doubt the same-have indicated their preference to take out more than simply basic medical cover. They will be inconvenienced considerably by Medicare if it comes into being. Similarly, in terms of hospital cover, 7.4 million Australians are insured by private funds and 3.5 million, or 47 per cent, of those insured have opted to take out more than the basic hospital care which Medicare will be offering. For those people, Medicare will also be a great inconvenience.

Not only does Medicare fail the Campbell Committee's first criterion but it also fails the second criterion. In fulfilling the obvious preferences of health insurance consumers, Medicare will be less effective than the privately operated funds it is seeking to replace. The final judgment that the Campbell Committee made on government operated financial institutions concerned their cost effectiveness. In this respect, the clear experience of Medibank Private is that the government run scheme is markedly less cost effective than the privately run competitive scheme. Two indicators of economic efficiency in health funds are the ratio of management costs to contributions income and the ratio of management costs to benefits paid out by the funds. I have a brief table which compares the record of Medibank Private with the record of the private funds in the five years from 1978 to 1982. I seek leave to incorporate it in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The table read as follows-
RATIO OF MANAGEMENT COSTS TO CONTRIBUTION INCOME
RATIO OF MANAGEMENT COSTS TO BENEFITS PAID OUT

TALK.START.PARA: —This table demonstrates that in every year the management costs of Medibank Private compared to the contribution income and benefits paid out are substantially higher than the private funds. They are simple measures of economic efficiency and prove that a government run, nationalised health insurance scheme will be more costly to administer than the existing non-profit privately operated health funds.
—But you keep on changing their rules year after year.

—No. This is irrelevant. Irrespective of any changes to the system that is the cost which will fall on the taxpayer either by eventually causing the Government to increase the levy from one per cent of taxable income to some higher figure or through transfer payments from Consolidated Revenue. Honourable senators may remember that in 1978 Medibank Private made a loss of something like $20m. It was then shored up by a government grant of $21m in November of that year to allow it to continue to be liquid. I can well envisage the same thing happening again if Medicare becomes established in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: The Campbell Committee made several other comments about the operation of government financial institutions which are also relevant at this point. The Committee said that institutions such as Medicare 'should compete equally or reasonably equally with its private sector competitors'. In the past, as the $ 21m grant to which I have just referred proved, Medibank has not done that. There is no reason to expect that Medicare will be any more successful in the future. More importantly, the Government has required as a benchmark figure that the health insurance funds have reserves-in the case of the larger funds four weeks and, in the case of the smaller funds, eight weeks of contribution income- in order to meet unexpected high claims. While that requirement is not actually written into the National Health Act, it is understood and is observed by the private health funds. On the other hand, in 1981 Medibank Private held an average of 3.4 weeks of contributions in reserve. In 1980 it was 1.8 weeks and in 1979 it was 1.4 weeks. In other words, in a competitive environment, Medibank Private has not even been able to comply with the standards which the Government has seen as reasonable for the other funds.

The point to be made is that the government run health insurance scheme has not fulfilled the Campbell Committee's criterion of competing equally with the private sector. Relative to the private funds, it has been operationally inefficient. Once again, there is no reason to expect that Medicare will be any different. To summarise this point, I refer again to the report of the Campbell Committee:
. . . an established GFI-
That is, a government financial institution-

may demonstrate managerial, operational and innovative qualities of a high order and achieve an adequate rate of return but that alone would not necessarily justify continued public ownership unless it were filling a market gap in the most cost-effective way and there were reason to believe its performance would suffer under private ownership.

What the Committee was saying is that even enterprises which are government owned already should be sold unless they are fulfilling those criteria and those commitments. How much more pertinent are those criteria when the Government is seeking to establish new public enterprises such as Medicare and when it is seeking to enter a field which, except for the unfortunate Medibank experience of the Whitlam era, has been traditionally left to the private sector? It is regrettable that the Government has decided to proceed with Medicare. It is particularly regrettable that it has chosen to do so at this time. The tender for computer equipment announced by the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) in July was a simple case of spending $14m that would otherwise have been quite unnecessary on equipment which is already available. The Minister is seeking to get information which is already available to the private health funds. At a time when the Government pretends to preach budgetary restraint, it is inconsistent that it should be acquiring new functions which have been admirably filled by the private sector.

The 5,000 employees who will lose their jobs with the private health funds, many of whom will not be able to find new jobs with Medicare, will no doubt be confused about the Government's rhetoric on unemployment and the priority it gives to job creation. The Government is well aware that in creating Medicare it is destroying 5,000 jobs in the private sector. These poor souls who have been thrown on the unemployment scrap heap by this Government which feigns compassion and promises employment know-the Government has failed to explain this-that Medicare begins in February but the private funds will not begin to retrench staff until some time after that date. In the meantime, of course, Medicare will be recruiting staff. The great majority of positions, particularly the senior positions, will have already been absorbed; so these people will not be able to find employment in Medicare.

So far, this Government's record has been one of on-going job destruction. Medicare will be just another example of this policy. In fact, the Government's whole approach to the introduction of Medicare has, in my view, been very destructive. It has quite deliberately excluded the private funds from acting as agents for Medicare in the hope that many of these funds will not survive. The one per cent levy against Australian taxpayers is, in itself, a misleading figure. It represents approximately $1 billion additional taxes but that is not the cost of Medicare nor does it bear any relationship to the cost of health in Australia. The Government has calculated that in 1983-84 in a full year of costing Medicare will cost approximately $1.7 billion. That must be added, of course, to the $55m of further taxation that is now being paid by taxpayers as a result of the abolition of the health insurance rebate.

The Government would have people believe that, by paying their one per cent levy, they are being made conscious of the health costs within the community. The truth of the matter is that the total cost of health care in Australia is approximately $8 billion which is paid for in further taxes. Despite the obvious simplicity of allowing the private funds to operate as Medicare agents-after all , they have all the facilities and branches in place already-the Government has decided to make the Health Insurance Commission, or Medibank Private as it is more commonly known, the sole agent. That is a clear indication that this Government's intention to create a nationalised health insurance scheme is based on socialised ideology and not on a desire to improve the existing situation.

The Government is seeking to ensure that Medicare is a permanent edifice of the Government which, after all its weaknesses and shortcomings become obvious, cannot be dismantled because only a very small part of the present private health funds' structure would be left to take the responsibility back. It is the Government's hope that, unlike the post-Whitlam situation, Medicare will have to be retained through the lack of any viable alternative. The issue of sole agency , which has been argued mainly on the grounds of the immediate loss in employment, should therefore be seen as something else in relation to its longer term effects. In the bankruptcies, mergers and takeovers which will inevitably occur among the private health insurance funds, more jobs will be jeopardised than the 5,000 expected to be lost immediately.

TALK.START.PARA: —They do not care who goes broke.

—No, the Government does not care who goes broke. However, Australia will also lose the wide choice of private insurance and the alternative system which has served us so well over several decades. By allowing Medibank Private to provide gap and ancillary cover, as well as being the sole agent for Medicare, it is being given an enormous, and in my view quite unfair, advantage over the privately operated funds. It is not difficult to foresee the Government coming back to the Parliament at some later date to lift the ceiling on the pretext, perhaps even for the genuine reason, that most people would naturally prefer to have all their health insurance cover under one roof.

SPEECH.PARA: I am concerned at the loss of free choice that will occur if Medicare is set up knowingly and willingly by the Labor Government. I am concerned at the inherently higher costs of government-run organisations which will, in time, lead to a higher levy than the one per cent which is proposed at present and which will also entail budgetary assistance for Medicare. All Australians will become increasingly wary of the growing tendency of both State and Federal Labor governments using their legislative powers to impose a certain lifestyle and values on the community, which are sprung directly from the Australian Labor Party's own ideological commitment to socialism. In this place we should all be concerned that, in the likely event that Medicare will be as much a failure as Labor's previous experiment in nationalised health insurance, this Government is working to ensure that there is no alternative to fall back on in the event that it does collapse, as inevitably it will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Medicare package of Bills which has been introduced by the Government. The package represents the culmination of many months of intense activity by the Labor Government to set in place the legislative and adminstrative structures necessary to support the Medicare program. Our eyes have always been firmly set on this objective as a necessary fulfilling of our mandate, a mandate bestowed on us by the Australian people in March this year. We will fulfil this promise despite the obstructionism of honourable senators opposite. The Minister for Health, Dr Blewett, in implementing this policy, to this point has behaved in an excellent manner in his negotiations with those who are prepared to negotiate genuinely. He is to be commended for that.

SPEECH.PARA: The Medicare program represents a real attempt to fulfil a proper objective of a democratic socialist government that no one in Australia should be deprived of or denied adequate medical advice or hospital care because of his or her financial status or ability to pay premiums to health insurance funds. To put it another way, if somebody suffers a traumatic accident which has occurred on the road or within the place of work or suffers some severe prolonged or chronic illness, that should not lead to some crippling financial burden-either directly or by payment of health insurance premiums-being placed on that person or that person's family. Our objective is to ensure that, should some person be unfortunately placed in that position by way of accident or prolonged illness, crippling financial burdens ought not to be added to the task of healing and of getting better. That is our ideal and we put it forward unashamedly.

To speak as if we are interested in nationalising medicine in Australia, which is of course, constitutionally impossible, is an absurd charge. To say that we are abolishing the freedom of doctor of choice is also quite misleading. Under our scheme any person in Australia can choose to have a consultation conducted by any doctor. A person can visit any general practitioner of his or her choice. Medicare will cover any referral by that GP to a specialist. Any radiology, pathology or other diagnostic service will be paid for by Medicare. People will receive free treatment in public hospitals by the hospital's doctors in a ward assessed by the hospital to be adequate to the task in hand. That is sufficient freedom of choice for most Australians. If they want to get a particular private doctor and if they want to stay in a private ward they are quite entitled to pay an extra premium to secure that. There is no abolishing of choice of doctor. There is certainly no attempt to nationalise medicine in Australia. That needs to be said quite firmly.

This scheme is a practical and compassionate one. The cost to the community will be borne by the one per cent levy imposed on taxable incomes. People have said that that will be inadequate. To that I say that, with this Government's assault on tax avoidance and tax evasion, proving as effective as it is, this one per cent levy will provide sufficient funds. If the previous Government had been more robust perhaps in its attempt to stop tax avoidance and evasion it would have seen that this was possible. Members of the Opposition are making their judgments on the inadequacy of the levy on the basis of their own inadequate performance in the administration of our tax laws.
It is important to note that the trade union movement has fully endorsed this proposal. The Australian Council of Trade Unions, in a release, stated:
The smooth and successful introduction of Medicare on February 1 1984 is an intrinsic part of the prices and income accord between the Australian Government an the ACTU.
The ACTU praised the proposal, as did the National Economic Summit Conference. The Conference communique stated:
The Summit notes the announced health policies of the Government and believes that it is imperative that at the Commonwealth level a stable system should be introduced as a matter of urgency.

The trade union movement and the National Economic Summit Conference endorsed the Government's plans in this regard. Yet honourable senators opposite refuse to go along with that endorsement. They make sniping and obstinate remarks which further confine them to the political wilderness in which they currently find themselves. Can we get any definite statement from Senator Messner who, I think, is the only shadow Minister present in the chamber? I ask whether he agrees with the Opposition shadow spokesman on health, Mr Jim Carlton, when on 22 July he said: 'If the Liberal Government is ever returned'-he was speaking very hypothetically-'it will be committed to dismantling Medicare'.

TALK.START.PARA: —You know that was not his statement.

—I have it in inverted commas, so it must be his statement. Senator Messner refuses to agree with or refute that statement. I take his silence to be somewhat acquiescent in that proposal by Mr Jim Carlton but, thank goodness, it will never come to pass. The obstructionist attitude of the Liberal and National parties in this matter has not been matched by that of the Australian Democrats whose spokesperson on health, Senator Haines, has proved to be a tougher yet more sensible advocate than was the case with the Liberal and National parties. I think that part of the Democrats' position on this is to be noted with, if not wholehearted approval, a due acknowledgment of the sensible role which they have played in this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to spend some time on the role of the Health Insurance Commission. The Commission has been given the exclusive administration of Medicare. As is well known, it has been operating Medibank Private in recent years and has been operating it in an extremely efficient fashion in latter times. It is true that it went through a bad period, but that was mainly because of the frustration and the hindering of it as well as the assault on it by the very senators who sit opposite.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner I was about to expand on the role of the Health Insurance Commission which has been given the exclusive administration of Medicare. It is well known that that Commission has been operating Medibank Private in recent years. It is legitimate, I guess, to ask whether we, as parliamentarians, can have confidence in its ability to discharge its assigned functions, what is to be its relationship with existing funds and how it will affect them. In relation to the first question as to its ability to discharge the task assigned to it by the Government, I believe that the answer is that it can discharge those functions efficiently and well. Being a national organisation administering Medibank Private, it has a wide network of branches and cash payment centres which will be further expanded into a comprehensive Australia-wide accessible system. Page 8 of the interim ninth annual report of the Health Insurance Commission revealed:

SPEECH.PARA: During its short but turbulent history, Medibank Private has achieved a growth rate well above that of the industry generally and now provides health insurance cover for more than 2 million Australians.

A significant number of Australians already benefit from that organisation's ability to provide a service which has obviously attracted a good proportion of the Australian insured population. It is further revealed in that report that Medibank Private, despite some of the statements made by honourable senators opposite during the afternoon, is operated in a way which has ensured more than adequate reserves and a good trading surplus. Senator Crichton-Browne will be pleased to know that that interim ninth annual report, which obviously he had not had an opportunity to peruse, stated:

At 30 June 1983 the net assets of Medibank Private stood at $58.5m . . . This is equivalent to 1.3 months of break-even contribution income . . . and exceeds the level of one month which has been indicated as acceptable for large organisations during the period leading up to Medicare.

I quote that merely to demonstrate that, judged by the proper criteria of adequate reserves and good trading surpluses, Medibank Private is revealed as being an efficiently run organisation. It augurs well for the putting of Medicare into the hands of the Health Insurance Commission.

Of course, the computer network which was also the subject of some comment by honourable senators opposite has indeed proved to be so good that that is what gives the Government such confidence in handing this task to the Health Insurance Commission. The abolition of Medibank Standard established an environment where Medibank Private had to develop its own computer facilities. In just over a year the world's largest on-line health insurance claims processing system was designed, developed, tested and implemented, and an entirely new computer network was planned, purchased and installed. That was a very impressive achievement. As I said, it augurs well for the future.

I cannot overemphasise to the Commission and to the Government how essential it will be for the long term viability of Medicare within the life of Australian society that that computerised dealing with claims be as efficient as possible to process and deal with claims as speedily as possible. In a question I asked this afternoon, I referred to doctors, particularly the ordinary general practitioners-ordinary in the sense that they are the earliest medical practitioners to whom people turn if they are suffering from some illness-having every right at the moment to be utterly sceptical of the ability of the system to handle bulk billing of accounts in a totally efficient way. This affects the very viability of their practices, with delays of many months being experienced. I emphasise that the present system is not operated by the Health Insurance Commission. I was pleased to receive the assurance from the Minister representing the Minister for Health in this place, the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes), to the effect that the Health Insurance Commission had given an undertaking to the Government that such claims would be processed within a fortnight of their receipt. I think if doctors can be assured of a good cash flow in relation to their practices and the discharge of their functions in relation to those patients for whom they bulk bill, it will indeed encourage them to participate in the Medicare program in a way in which the Government wishes them to participate.

In relation to the second part of my question which, as I said earlier, dealt with a legitimate concern, namely the relationship of Medicare with the existing private funds, much has been said about the very existence of the funds and the employment prospects of their employees. What we had from honourable senators opposite, I am afraid, was really quite outdated assertions which I traced back to a letter of 6 May 1983 from the Voluntary Health Insurance Association of Australia to the effect that 5,000 people in the private health funds will be put out of work upon the introduction of Medicare. That statement was made by the spokesman in this place, Senator Baume. It was made again today by Senator Austin Lewis. The figure of 5,000 being put out of work is being constantly reasserted. Even if that were true on 6 May 1983, Liberal-National Party senators need to take account of various alterations and concessions which have been made by the Government since 6 May 1983. Very significant arrangements have been made with the private funds which are not acknowledged by those opposite.

I mention some. Firstly, 11 regional funds based outside capital cities have been offered agency relationships. Those funds employ some 600 people, generally in areas with a very high unemployment rate and with few alternative employment opportunities. Therefore, negotiations were undertaken. I can speak for the Tasmanian negotiations which were undertaken so ably by the Minister for Health. They were well conducted. I congratulate the Government on recognising that, in relation to those 11 regional funds, proper arrangements needed to be put in place. Indeed, I am hopeful of another fund coming to an arrangement also with the Government to ensure the employment prospects of employees within the present fund. Secondly, of course, a whole package of concessions was negotiated by the Minister with the health funds and offered to them on 22 July. To save time, I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard the list of those six concessions which were offered by the Government to the private health funds on 22 July.
Leave granted.
The list read as follows-
Details of Concessions Offered to the Private Funds by the Government
Medibank Private would have a ceiling on membership numbers as at 31 January, 1984.
Medibank Private not be allowed to locate in new Medicare Offices.
Medibank Private contribution rates would include the industry average for administration costs and not undercut the rates of the other private funds.
The Minister would minimise Government intervention and controls over private health insurance.
Legislation would be adjusted to facilitate mergers between funds.
The funds may diversify their activities using surplus reserves above a determined minimum.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Those concessions must ensure the viability of funds operating, as they will, with many new opportunities if they are aggressive and competent in the market-place which they say is their ideal. I believe that, in fact, many of us on the back bench on the Government side feel that the concessions offered, particularly in the restriction of Medibank Private, are indeed too generous. Nevertheless they are there.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, one has to acknowledge that one of the means of achieving a basic health insurance system which will be cheaper to the Australian community will be to reduce the number of people involved in providing that insurance service. Some employees in some private health funds will not be able to be employed by those funds. Once again, the Government has said that they will be given preference in employment in the Medicare program. That should alleviate most of the distress. There is no way in which the scaremongering by the Liberal- National Party will come to pass. This Labor Government will not wantonly create unemployment in the community. I believe that the continually reiterated assertion that $5,000 people will be put out of work by the introduction of Medicare will be found to be utterly untrue. In 12 months time when we review the situation in this chamber I believe those honourable senators opposite, if they continue to assert so, will be found to be totally discredited. On the contrary, I believe that 12 months from now this Government will be able to take proper credit for the setting up of the Medicare program.

As I said in my opening remarks, a practical expression of what is an ideal within the Labor Party and shared to a large extent, I am pleased to say, by the Australian Democrats is that no Australian or no Australian family ought to have crippling financial burdens added to the distress of some traumatic accident or some chronic or long-standing illness. In those situations, we believe that a properly administered and efficient scheme, with the funds to run it being provided by a one per cent levy on taxable incomes, will be a compassionate and justifiable response from the community to the need to ensure that no Australian has added to the task of getting well the need to provide funds, either through taking out loans, by eating into capital or in other ways adding to financial distress within the family. We believe that the Government is to be commended on bringing this legislation to pass and I believe that in 12 months time, when we review this scheme, we will have rightly earned the gratitude of the Australian people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking in the Medicare debate, I want to inform the Senate of the problems that will confront Queensland and Queenslanders because of the introduction of Medicare. Medicare in Queensland has actually occasioned the same havoc as a natural disaster. If it had been a cyclone, the State would have been eligible for equal assistance from the Commonwealth under the Commonwealth-State natural disaster scheme. But not so with Medicare. Queensland has to carry an unfair and unequal burden foisted on it by a Labor Government that does not like or recognise Queensland's free hospitals. I really do not know why, because the free hospital system was brought in by the Australian Labor Party in the 1940s. However, for the Senate I should like to spell out the problems in relation to the introduction of Medicare in Queensland. Under Medicare, free public hospital treatment, both in- patient and out-patient, will be restored in all States from February 1984. The Commonwealth will compensate States for revenues forgone. That is the crux of the matter-compensation. Queensland's public hospitals are free, so the State has very little by way of fees to forgo and thus we miss out on that compensation. Other States which were charging fees, that is all the States except Queensland, will receive $130 per patient day for public disadvantaged in -patients. In Queensland, the State does not charge public ward patients. The State receives nothing for these patients from the Commonwealth. For out- patients and other services other States charge. Queensland does not. Thus, the other States will receive substantial amounts from this area too while Queensland will receive only small amounts. As at July 1983, Queensland was to receive only $37m under Medicare for its public hospital system, compared with $ 233m for New South Wales and $175m for Victoria. Queensland's allocation of $37m was primarily for Commonwealth subsidy of private patients in public hospitals. Queensland, therefore, receives nothing under Medicare for its public patients and out-patients in public hospitals.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind the Senate that all Queenslanders have to pay the health tax of one per cent. In other words, they have to pay now for what they could previously have for nothing-free doctors, public hospitals and free treatment as public ward patients. The relative figures at 1 July were: New South Wales was receiving $44.20 per head of population; Victoria, $44.70; Western Australia, $ 56.20; and Queensland, $15.10. In other words, the average figure for the rest of Australia was approximately $50 per head of population while Queensland was receiving only $15 per head. I think that this was grossly inequitable. I wonder why Queenslanders seem to be considered second class citizens.

Queensland should have been receiving compensation similar to that received by other States. The Commonwealth should reconstruct the formula to allow Queensland to receive the same amount, on a per capita basis, as the other States. I consider that this would be simple enough to do. The Commonwealth merely had to work on the basis that the State applied fees. But of course that seemed to be too difficult. Queensland should have been receiving $103m but the State has been given a paltry $37m and, sad to say, only $15m was actually allocated in this year's Budget. I ask the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes): When will Queensland and the people who live there receive the further $22m due to them for 1983-84 to ensure equality with other States? Ironically, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on 19 February in Brisbane promised a rescue grant that could be up to $100m. The $15m that has been allocated in the Budget falls far short of the $100m that was promised by the Prime Minister, which of course is another broken promise, although I suppose he will probably come to Queensland now when the election comes around and he will say that he will give Queensland the rest of it.

The Queensland Government applied much political pressure at the Premiers Conference and as a result Queensland's allocation was lifted to $86.7m or $29 per capita, which is almost $22 less than the average received by the other States. As I said earlier, Canberra and the Labor Government treat Queenslanders like second class citizens. There is no logical reason why Queenslanders should receive less. They will pay the same health tax. The Queensland Government is seeking the further $22m for 1983-84 to ensure equality with other States. The Queensland Government is fighting to get a fair and equal deal for Queenslanders from a biased Commonwealth Government. I can assure the Senate that it will not give up the battle. What is more, I will be reminding Queensland electors during the next few weeks that they are receiving for health care only 40 per cent of, or $20 per person less than, that which is being received by other States.

The introduction of Medicare on 1 February will not change anything from the present free hospital system. Patients will be entitled to free accommodation in a public ward only. They are actually covered for only 85 per cent of doctors' fees. One thing I certainly do not agree with is the fact that one cannot insure for the gap of 15 per cent. It is not everybody who wants to go into a public ward. Ninety-nine per cent of medical benefit fund contributors in Queensland have what they call basic hospital cover. Queenslanders covered by health insurance for basic hospital care were entitled to have a shared or intermediate ward to the value of $120 a day in either a public or a private hospital. It is wrong to say that Medicare will provide shared ward accommodation. It will not. Medicare will cover public beds only.

Medicare is fraught with problems. For example, consider a confinement. If the mother-to-be wants her own doctor, in intermediate or private facilities she will have to be insured for a full nine months to be eligible for refunds. Under Medicare, if the mother-to-be has not insured before conception, she will have to pay a minimum of $500 for a normal birth and as much as $1,000 if it is a caesarian birth. Funding Medicare is a problem too. The health tax of one per cent will raise $1 billion of the $8 billion a year needed to fund the scheme. I wonder how the extra money is to be raised? Is it to be raised by a wealth tax, a death tax, or perhaps the capital gains tax that the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Senator Button) was telling us about today in the Senate? Most certainly the Federal Labor Government is not telling the people of Australia the straight facts. Medicare will cause job losses. Senator Tate told us that 5, 000 people would not lose their jobs. Five thousand low income clerks will be retrenched by the private health insurance companies simply because a government bureaucracy, with some 2,500 public servants, is to take over 60 per cent of their work.

It certainly is clear to me that Labor is anti-private enterprise. In fact, Medicare is a major act of nationalisation. Labor talks about unemployment but its disastrous health policies will add to it. Medicare will take away freedom of choice from patients and doctors. The direct relationship between patient and doctor will be interfered with and doctors of course will be forced to submit to the bulk billing of patients at the rate of 85 per cent of the schedule charges. As I said before, one has to remember that one cannot take out insurance to cover that gap of 15 per cent. Pensioners who received free medical treatment under the system introduced by the Fraser Government will lose 2.6 per cent through the consumer price index adjustment, disadvantaging single pensioners-

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I take a point of order. I draw your attention to standing order 406. Senator Bjelke-Petersen is clearly reading her speech and, moreover, it could have been written anywhere.

—The question of senators reading speeches was extensively debated in the last session of Parliament. The opinion of the Senate was that it did not desire the Chair to be more rigorous in the enforcement of that standing order. The distinction between copious notes and reading speeches is a very difficult one to draw from the chair. It was really left to individual senators to obey the spirit of that standing order. I think, though, it would add to the confidence of the Senate if Senator Bjelke-Petersen looked up from her copious notes for longer periods and more often. I call Senator Bjelke-Petersen.

—Actually, Mr Deputy President, I just wanted to quote some figures that I have here. I would be very pleased if I could just read them into the record because apparently the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Walsh, does not like to hear the points I am making. I want to make quite sure that I have them correctly in Hansard. As I was saying, pensioners will lose 2.6 per cent through the CPI adjustment, disadvantaging single pensioners by $2.30 a week and pensioner couples by $3.90 a week. One must not forget that it was the Prime Minister's election promise not to take money out of pensioners' pockets. So much for Labor's promises. Actually, too, the Prime Minister in his policy speech promised that nine out of 10 people would pay less under Medicare. Dr Blewett says that two-thirds of Australians will pay less under Medicare. Under the Fraser Government, 20 per cent of Australians paid nothing at all; they received free health care. So if we take two-thirds of the 80 per cent that are left, that means that only 53 per cent of Australians will pay less for their health care.

SPEECH.PARA: One other matter I want to raise in regard to this Bill is the proposal by this Government to issue children of 14 years of age with their own personal Medicare cards. I actually asked a question of the Minister about this not so long ago and I just want to put the matter on record. This provision will enable children to approach a medical practitioner for any reason at all, including a request for contraceptives, without parental permission. I believe the harm that might be caused by this is incalculable. It will encourage young people to deceive their parents and will certainly do nothing to help family life in this country. No 14-year-old has reached a level of discretion that would enable him or her to take responsibility for health matters. I feel the Government has learnt nothing from past mistakes, both in Australia and in Britain. Under Britain's national health scheme, the poor and disadvantaged wait at the end of long queues before they can receive their hospital treatment. I have a horrible feeling that the same thing could happen in Australia under Medicare.

Mr Deputy President, Medicare is not a national health scheme but a national health disaster and it is certainly a disaster which Australians have to subsidise through this health tax of one per cent of our income. Regrettably, Queenslanders will have to pay for their health care whereas now, if they want to, they can get their health care in public hospitals in Queensland and not have to pay anything at all for it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, the Senate is debating the four Bills that the Government has introduced to implement Medicare . It falls to me, I understand, to be the last speaker on the Opposition side before the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) responds to the second reading speeches and we go on to the Committee stage.

SPEECH.PARA: Medicare is not about improving health in Australia. There will be the same medical and hospital provisions that apply now, there will be the same doctor consultations and medical treatments will be the same. There will be the same hospitals, and hospital treatments will be the same. Medicare is not directly about improving health in Australia. What Medicare is about is the cost of health. Medicare proposes an enormous rearrangement of how the health resources of the nation are paid for. This rearrangment is best summarised as the introduction of a government monopoly, as institutionalising a single government bureaucracy. Put in another way, this rearrangement of costs of the nation's health is plainly the nationalisation of 60 per cent of what has until now been the private insurance arrangements of Australians.

This is a socialist decision. It will remove individual choice and it will transfer decision about health from the individual and the family to a bureaucrat-Big Brother knows best; 1984 is the year of Medicare's introduction. As we know, bureaucratic monopolies lack competition, they generate costs easily and they are not efficient. So these cost rearrangements are in fact ultimately about health in that they lead to reduced access to health care for many Australians, as I will show in my speech. This arises from the queuing and congestion expected in a monolithic and bureaucratic system, and from the disincentives of the overall cost of health going up for a majority of Australians.

Therefore, I want to concentrate my remarks tonight on the costs of Medicare. Whether or not the Government has set out to mislead the public, the public, with all the propaganda it has seen, has been led to believe that the cost of the new Medicare arrangements is only $1,000m; that is, the amount to be raised by the one per cent increase in everybody's income tax-the Medicare levy. But the national health bill for Australia is eight times that amount. The total bill is $8,000m and that money has come from taxpayers and consumers through the Commonwealth Government and through the States. The $1,000m Medicare levy is in fact a 3 per cent increase in the actual tax paid. Instead of 30c in the dollar being paid in tax, it will be 31c in the dollar-a 3 per cent increase in the actual tax paid. This is tantamount to raising income taxes by 1c in the dollar for everyone. I know that the increase is greater than that for some taxpayers on higher incomes but I speak here of the majority case. If we then interpret this one per cent surcharge on income tax, we see that despite the promises of the Labor Government there is this increase in income taxes for all Australians.

In fact, the greatest part of the national health bill will come, as in the past, from general tax revenue. It will come not only from this quite direct tax levy but also indirectly from the extra $700m required to meet the net cost of introducing Medicare. It will also come from payments to health costs for the three million Australians who receive so-called free medical and hospital care. These three million people comprise, as is well known, two million pensioners and a further one million disadvantaged persons who generally are of low income. Both of these groups are not required to make any contribution to their health costs.

As I said earlier, the nation's health bill is $8 billion. Of this, only $1 billion will come from the new health levy that is to begin in February 1984. Very much of the remainder will come, as now, from general government revenue raised by taxation. The net additional cost of Medicare's introduction will be $ 1,700m. Taxpayers will meet $1,000m via the tax levy and a further $600m will be directly gained by the Government abolishing the tax rebate that has been available in respect of taxpayers' contributions to private health insurance schemes. Of course, this tax rebate was abolished on 1 July this year, some seven months ahead of the time that the Government promised it would be taken away from Australians. This tax rebate, which has been extended to some 75 per cent of Australians, will make up the additional $600m or so needed to meet the net cost of Medicare. This year a family would pay a basic private health insurance of $650 in a whole year. For this payment the previous Government allowed a tax deduction of 30c in the dollar. Thus the $650 annual premium, or $ 13 a week, for a normal family package of private health insurance would gain about a $200 tax rebate. The net cost to that family under the present scheme would be not $650 in a year but $450. This direct tax deduction of some $200 has been abolished by the ALP Government. Accordingly, taxes will rise by not only the amount of the tax levy but also this forgone tax rebate.

In addition to these direct tax imposts that will pay for the net additional cost of introducing Medicare, there are the additional billions of dollars already provided in earlier annual Budgets for the nation's health bill, especially to pay for fully subsidised health benefits for pensioners and the disadvantaged, to whom I have referred, and to make direct payments to the States in respect of hospitals, nursing homes and community health programs. How do these costs translate to the ordinary families of Australia? In the last election campaign, the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, made this solemn promise in his policy speech:
It will mean that nine out of ten Australians will pay less for the health needs of themselves and their families.

That was Mr Hawke's promise in his policy speech in March. He said that nine out of 10 Australians would pay less for health. This promise has already been broken. Moreover, the promise is patently false. Already it is clear that three million Australians have free health. They have had it for many years. In a nation of 15 million, three in 15 or two out of every 10 cannot pay less because they cannot pay less than nothing. But now the Government itself admits that under Medicare-this is the up to date estimate-of the other eight out of 10, two -thirds will pay less and one-third will pay more. Two-thirds of 80 per cent is 53 per cent. From this calculation we see how quickly must the Government's figures be revised-only half, or five out of 10 Australians will be paying less for health care.

I ask honourable senators to listen as I continue because the situation gets worse. I have to be frank and say that I do not accept even this estimate. If the Government now says that only five out of 10 Australians will be paying less for their health under Medicare, I suspect that because of the four or five other factors that I will go on to outline that this can be reduced even further to a quarter. What are my reasons for this further revision? First, it is everywhere apparent that the so-called one per cent levy to be introduced in February 1984-I call it the 3 per cent levy because it is a 3 per cent actual increase in taxes paid-will turn out to be insufficient. The ALP Government, I believe, will quite quickly find some pretext to increase the one per cent levy so as to cover the inevitably higher costs of Medicare's bureaucratic and unrestrained commitments. Secondly, in the short term it must be acknowledged that the majority of Australian families take up health insurance cover which provides a greater benefit than the basic and very limited package that Medicare allows. This will mean an additional-an add on-private health insurance premium which will be the only way a family can be sure of securing reasonable cover of the cost of even a shared ward in a private hospital. Medicare is, of course, geared to public hospitals. That additional premium will also secure for that family a choice of doctor.

The Government's estimate that five out of 10 Australians will pay less under Medicare is based on the assumption that the cost of this add on private health insurance package-a minimal package, not the extravagant health insurance packages that may still be available-will be $5 a week. But is this a fair estimate? It is not. What will it actually cost? A more realistic estimate is that the cost will be $8 a week. We will only know the exact cost when the legislation is in place and the funds directly respond to the circumstances later this year. That $8 a week is for only the minimal package of the add on private health insurance. Going on the past preferences of most Australian families for a choice of doctor and access to the least costly level of private hospitals, I estimate that families will pay this $8 a week plus the Medicare taxation levy of 1c in the dollar of taxable income, which for the average family is estimated by the Government to be $7 a week. That comprises a total cost of $15 a week for the average family, instead of the $9 a week that is paid under the present scheme. The $9 figure is derived from the fact that the average family paid $13 a week for private health insurance and obtained a $4 a week tax rebate under the former Liberal-National Party Government. When the add on private additional cover is taken into account, families across Australia will find that the new Medicare arrangements are costing them more.

If this is the broad picture of the costs under Medicare, which already shows that most families will not pay less, when Medicare is looked at in more detail there are still other areas for increased cost to the Australian family. For example, let us consider gap insurance. The gap arises because under both the old scheme and this new scheme basic cover provides for only 85 per cent of the medical fee due to a doctor. The remaining gap-that is the remaining 15 per cent -is paid for directly by the consumer up to a maximum of $10 for any one payment to meet this gap. Up to this point private health insurance has been allowed to provide gap insurance, that is, by a contributor paying the extra appropriate premium to a health insurance fund the fund would then pay all the gap costs up to the level of standard medical fees. Under Medicare there is a sharp change. The Government has banned gap insurance. This means that unexpectedly for many Australians they will not be able to provide in advance for this but will have to pay at least 15 per cent of all their medical bills. This is an additional cost to all that I have already indicated will be the increased costs under Medicare. The Government has a slick answer for this; and this is what is called bulk billing.

The Australian Labor Party Government's approach is to put pressure on all doctors to charge a total fee to a patient, which amounts to only 85 per cent of the standard or approved medical fee. If a doctor sends all his bills in bulk for all his patients to the Medicare office and no bills at all to the patients, Medicare will pay the doctor 85 per cent of the standard fees, and that is all the doctor will receive. The Government's idea is to create a discount war between doctors. So, if a doctor is not satisfied with the 85 per cent only fee, there will be pressure upon his patients to move to another doctor who will. This is an arrogant way-this brow beating, threatening and bullying of the medical profession-in which the Government is seeking to overcome the void which it has created by banning gap insurance. To the extent that the Government's bullying tactics do not work, however, the consumers of Australia will pay for not just one gap but every gap for every medical bill that is incurred. The Opposition is opposed to this and believes that insurance to cover the gap should be an available option at whatever the market-place determines that insurance cost to be. The Australian Democrats are also rightly concerned about this aspect, and this has led to Dr Blewett's so-called concession to the Democrats. The concession appears to be that no one will be required to pay for these 15 per cent gaps once $150 has been expended on gaps in any one year. Dr Blewett in this matter is treating the Democrats with contempt and they are foolish to be crowing about this concession as some kind of triumph. This is so because gap insurance in any event could be offered for considerably less than $ 150 a year.

Another example of additional cost arises from the need for most families-those families that will require the add-on private health insurance package-to have to deal with two organisations instead of one, as in the past. The Australian Labor Party Government has banished the private health insurance funds from any part in the basic Medicare health cover scheme. They are banned even from being agents for the scheme. Not only has this socialist Government nationalised the industry by grabbing 60 per cent of its work and giving it to the Medicare monolithic bureaucracy, but the private funds have been excluded from even being agents for the Medicare scheme. The nationalisation of the private health insurance industry will directly cause 5,000 employees to lose their jobs. The professional expertise of these men and women will be lost. The services they could have provided will be lost. Medicare's bureaucracy will be set up anew, duplicating many of the very resources thereby made redundant. For example, at least $14m alone has been spent on new computers. There will be 2,500 new Medicare jobs, but that still leaves a net loss of another 2,500 added to unemployment in Australia directly by the introduction of Medicare. These Medicare jobs will be exceedingly expensive because they are in the public sector, not in the private sector, with higher salary levels, extended superannuation and so on. To cap it all off I believe the service to the public will not be as good as before. For example there will not be as easy access because there will be fewer local outlets and increased bureaucracy in the procedures.

I put it to the Minister that the answer in part could have been to allow the existing experts in the private health insurance industry to act as agents for Medicare. The Opposition strongly urged this. Even now we would use our numbers if the Democrats would join us to achieve this. But the Australian Labor Party Government has rejected this proposal with all the increased costs that the rejection entails. My point here is that part of the increased cost directly borne by consumers is that they will need to deal with two organisations for health cover instead of one. This two-stop shopping approach is opposed by the Opposition. It has also been raised by the Democrats and it has led to another Dr Blewett concession, but it is even with more contempt towards the Democrats that he makes it, for it turns out that the concession is his statement that after all anyone can pass on correspondence to Medicare by putting a 27c stamp on the envelope and posting it to the Medicare office.

Yet another example of additional cost is what will be borne by the people of Queensland. Medicare will provide free hospitals, but Queensland already has free hospitals. As some of my colleagues in the coalition outlined earlier this evening, Queenslanders have to this point gained only $37m direct compensation from the Commonwealth Government for a provision that the State Government had already given to them anyway. The Australian Labor Party Government's response so far to Queenslanders has been to give them only this puny $37m to help the State Government. I believe that Queensland will be in all kinds of difficulty to get more adequate compensation. Medicare has brought special disadvantages for all Queenslanders.

Yet another example of additional cost is that to be borne by two-income families. It may still surprise some families where a husband and wife have direct incomes that both incomes will attract the one per cent Medicare levy. When the levy on both incomes is added together, that family may well be surprised to find that it is paying more than it was before.

I now turn to the case of Australia's two million pensioners. Pensioners may at first say: 'Well, these Medicare arrangements do not bother me very much because I have had free health care in the past and I will have free health care in the future'. There are losses for pensioners. First of all, from next year pensioners will not receive an increase in pensions to cope with their increased costs of living. This will happen because of what one could call the inflation fiddle, or the consumer price index fiddle, according to the definitions of statisticians. When statisticians are calculating the rate of inflation next year they will artificially reduce the CPI by 2.6 per cent as a direct result of the introduction of Medicare. All pensioners will be deprived of 2.6 per cent of their incomes next year and thereafter, even though they will receive no compensating advantage from Medicare whatsoever. This will amount to a cut in all pensions. It will rob single pensioners of $2.30 a week and married pensioner couples of $3.90 a week in 1984, the year of Big Brother.

The Australian Labor Party Government knows that this is an artificial situation that will directly hurt all two million pensioners in Australia. The ALP Government has already hurt pensioners. In May it hit the over 70-year-olds with an incomes test. In May it hit superannuation lump sums for retirees with a 30c in the dollar tax. In August all age and service pensioners were hit with Senator Grimes's assets test. The situation is still confused, but an additional penalty has been placed on pensioners. In February all pensioners will suffer actual cuts in their direct income-$2.30 a week for all single pensioners and $3 .90 a week for all married pensioner couples. Is it any wonder that of all Australians, pensioners are crying out about the hurt from this Government. They have been cheated by the Labor Government. The hope and promise some thought they saw at the last election have been broken and shattered.
