There is an additional penalty for pensioners, and that is the congestion and the queuing and the extra pressure on public hospitals that the whole Medicare system will lead to.

I have not even addressed one large final group that will certainly be paying much more as a result of the introduction of Medicare, and that is those people who are on above average incomes. Here the socialist Government shows no restraint at all. The socialist logic here is: 'You have higher than average incomes, you are rich and no matter how much has been taken from your income by direct income taxes, we are going to take another progressive tax on the national health plan'. As a Liberal, I am opposed to this socialist principle. My view is that if the ALP Government wants a higher contribution for health to be made by those on higher incomes, it should act appropriately and honestly by directly increasing income taxes. The Government should display its intentions plainly and honestly rather than under some cover of a health levy.

In the face of Medicare's introduction, those Australians who pay more tax but for less benefit to themselves and to other Australians as a whole have one grand remedy, and that is to vote out the ALP Government at the next election. So, in summary, the package of Medicare legislation that is before the Senate does nothing to improve the quality of health care in Australia. It is a socialist decision. It represents a move away from individuals and families to bureaucrats and politicians. It will increase direct government costs by $1.7m. Taxation will be increased by $1.7 billion to cover the scheme. Medicare gives the illusion, however, of free health care, hiding the real cost to the consumer . Medicare threatens so much of the private health insurance funds, the private hospitals and even private medical practitioners. Medicare will not improve the delivery of health care, nor will it improve the economics of health care in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because of the constraints of time I will be very brief. I will not canvass at length matters that have already been raised by the long list of speakers who have participated in this debate. Some of the matters that have been raised are also of concern to me. I simply mention some of those matters in passing. I believe that the Government has, of course, been concerned about the need to redistribute the cost of medical and hospital services in the community. Of course, one is either blessed with good health or one is not. It is essential to realise that in some cases the cost of providing services to an ill person is too great for individuals and families to bear. I can understand the Government's desire to bring about a more equitable system than the present system of paying for health care in Australia. However, there is and will be a continuing concern in the community about the total cost to the community of health care and the method of ensuring that those costs are kept within reasonable bounds. Of course, this concern has exercised the minds of many speakers from both sides of the Senate today.

SPEECH.PARA: I am concerned, as are a number of other people in this Parliament, about what we believe to be the needless cost in terms of job dislocation and disruption because of the Government's intention to centralise the delivery of health care benefits from one office, namely the Health Insurance Commission. I have made my views known to the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) and publicly. For the life of me I cannot see even now that the argument that is advanced that Medicare will assist in an ordered and controlled delivery of health care outweighs the real problems that will arise in terms of the disruption and dislocation of the jobs of workers in the voluntary health insurance industry.

I make specific reference to the fact that particular funds have been given agency roles, and I appreciate the Government's moves in that direction. I know that the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes), who is in charge of this legislation in the Senate, will be discussing with the APPM Council on 30 September the possibility of that fund operating as an agency. I hope that those discussions are fruitful. I believe that it would benefit not only the people concerned but also the system as a whole because Associated Pulp and Paper Mills Ltd will contribute quite a substantial amount towards that particular fund. If one can get a few bob out of industry, so much the better. I wish the Minister well in that, and also the representatives of the APPM Council.

Concern has been expressed during the debate that the services of public hospitals will be overburdened as a result of this measure. I hope that the Government will monitor this very carefully because services in public hospitals are already burdened. One has only to speak to the unions-say, the Hospital Employees Federation-to know that they are always fighting attempts by hospital boards and the like to reduce staff and to curtail services. The pressure is on and it is suggested that the pressure will be considerably greater as a result of this legislation. Of course, this is at a time when quite costly facilities are available in the private and charitable hospital area. Again, I hope that the Government recognises this and that the Minister takes a very broad approach to the question of categorisation of these hospitals and bears in mind that there are a number of people, particularly those seriously and terminally ill, who desire to enter a hospital which has a particular character, which is consistent with the values that they have held over a number of years and where they can enjoy-if that is the right word-the medical services as well as the spiritual services that are available there. I hope that the Government will bear that in mind. I realise, now that the time for amendments has passed, that there is no opportunity to attempt to achieve that position. But I trust that the Government will bear that in mind when it makes its decision in respect of charitable and/or private hospitals.

A couple of matters have not been dealt with and I want to deal briefly with them now. I cannot understand why the Labor Government does not view sympathetically the claims by chiropractors that their services should be included in Medicare. After all, it is suggested that chiropractors, skilled as they are, can provide services at probably half the cost of similar services provided by the medical profession who, in very many cases, are able to provide much better services. I wonder whether the Government and the Opposition have seriously considered their claims. The time will come when the many people who avail themselves of the services of chiropractors will ensure that their voices are heard.

The final point which has not come up for discussion but which has been the subject of considerable correspondence to me, and probably to other members of the Senate and the House of Representatives, is the issuance of Medicare cards to children. A number of articles in the Press have expressed concern that from October children from the age of 14 will be able to seek their own medical advice on any health matter, including contraception, because they will be able to obtain a separate Medicare card. That is what the Press has stated. In fact, strictly speaking, that is not so. But under clause 67 of the Health Legislation Amendment Bill the functions of the Health Insurance Commission include the planning and establishment of the organisation, et cetera.

If a child in fact goes to a doctor, the doctor can bulk bill. If the child is able to write the doctor would, of course, be required, as I understand it, to send in an application form for a Medicare card. With all the new computers which the Health Insurance Commission has told us that it has, which in any event I understand our Joint Committee of Public Accounts will keep an eye on, it can churn out a Medicare card and that will be sent to the child. At the appropriate time I propose to move an amendment to the effect that nothing in that particular provision would authorise the Commission to issue a Medicare card to a child. I believe that that is a matter which deserves appropriate consideration at the appropriate time, which will be in the Committee stage.

In commencing this address, I said that I would not canvass at length all the matters that have been canvassed over the whole of the debate, which has ranged over most of today. But I ask the Government to give due consideration to the matters that have been raised and the particular matters that I have raised relating to charitable institutions, private hospitals, funds, chiropractors and the issuance of cards to children.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Harradine said, it has been a long debate during most of today. For me it has been a much longer debate. I came into the Senate in 1974 and we have been debating health insurance and health schemes ever since. I find it incredible that the Opposition could express such righteous indignation and wax so eloquently about the Australian Labor Party's Medicare scheme-a scheme which has been put before the people for the last two or three years in great detail by the present Minister for Health (Dr Blewett), both in opposition and in government, and a scheme which was quite clearly spelled out to the people of this country before the last general election and for which, as Senator Haines said, we so obviously got a mandate if we got a mandate for anything.

SPEECH.PARA: I am absolutely surprised at the gall of the Opposition to suggest that this scheme is confusing or is not understood when in fact the Opposition, when in government, presided over not one health insurance program but in fact five. As shadow Minister for Health during all those years, each year I debated the legislation which was introduced and each year, as I finished the debate, I said : 'I will see you here again next year. This will not work. It obviously cannot work. You will have to change it again'. Each year that very thing happened.

I am also interested in some of the extraordinary arguments and contortions of logic that we have heard this afternoon. I will refer to one while it is my mind -that is, the argument which Senator Teague made at the end of his speech. Senator Teague made much, in a speech that went for half an hour, about the inequity and the unequal treatment of families. Senator Teague, as have other honourable senators on both sides of the chamber at various times, talked about the problems of single income families in this community. Yet in an extraordinary display of logic Senator Teague complained bitterly that a family of two taxpayers would have the levy placed on both taxpayers and that this was grossly inequitable and a terrible thing. What Senator Teague quite clearly is proposing is that a single income family with a taxable income of $20,000 should pay the one per cent levy on that $20,000 but a two income family with two incomes of $10,000 should pay the levy on only $10,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. The Minister has totally misunderstood my argument. It is purely a question that they will be surprised that they have to pay, not that it is inequitable that they have to pay.
—There is no point of order. If Senator Teague is claiming that he was misrepresented he can make a personal explanation at the end of the Minister's speech. I call the Minister.

—Senator Teague, by raising the point, quite clearly disagreed with the placing of the levy on those two incomes. If Senator Teague does not believe that the system whereby the levy is placed on each taxable income is fair-Senator Baume mentioned the same point-he should say what he would do in its place. If he wants to put an extra burden on single income families he should say that that is what he is proposing and that is what should be done. However, I do not intend to detail to the Senate exactly what the Medicare legislation does. That has been done in the second reading speech, it has been done in the other place and it has been done by the speakers on this side who have preceded me. However, I do wish to make a couple of general points and to reply to some of the specific points that have been made by various speakers.

SPEECH.PARA: On the general points, I must agree with Senator Baume when he said that what this legislation is about is a basic difference in philosophy between the conservative coalition Opposition and the Labor Government. It is a basic difference in principle as to how we fund health insurance. Senator Baume made many points about the fact that this was the nationalisation of the health insurance industry and that it was akin to the nationalisation of the health industry as it exists in Britain. One can briefly say that it is an extraordinary scheme that can be labelled as nationalising the health scheme when it preserves the fee for service system, when it preserves the voluntary health system, when it preserves the private hospitals and when it allows people -doctors or patients-to opt out of the system completely if they want to and ignore the existence of the health scheme. That sort of hyperbole and exaggeration is the sort of thing that we must face in all debates in this place .

However, there is a basic difference of principle. Senator Baume and his conservative colleagues believe that health care is best and most efficiently funded in this country through the principle of the free market. Senator Baume articulated that view well. He believes that people will buy health services, will shop around for the best prices, that their activity in this regard will result in competition between the providers of health care-in other words, the doctors-and hence what will result will be a low price, competition and a better system for the patient and the community.

On the other hand, the Australian Labor Party believes that basic health cover, medical and hospital cover, is best funded and contributed to on the basis of the patient's ability to contribute as we consider that this is a community service. We retain private health insurance to supplement this for those who so choose it. I have been listening to Senator Baume and the followers of the beloved Adam Smith who sit opposite espousing the free market principle. It implies always choice, a knowledge of what is purchased and the existence of alternative sources of service or goods. If one applies the free market principle to the medical market, these factors just do not exist or they exist in a very limited way. The choice is rarely one for people. It is certainly not a choice of timing. They cannot decide when they will be sick; they cannot choose the type of illness to fit in with what they can afford at any particular time. In most suburbs and towns in this country they have a limited choice of doctors and these doctors almost invariably arrange, through their local organisations, to charge similar fees and provide similar services. Above all, all the knowledge is on one side; it is on the side of the provider, the doctor. Rare indeed is it that a patient can effectively question the service or make a judgment about alternative services and alternative treatments. There is no free market and there can be no free market with inequality of knowledge and inequality of bargaining power. It is a market which is loaded against the patient. It is a market which is particularly loaded against those with chronic illnesses, who have to go repeatedly, not by choice, to get the services and the care that they need.

A second different principle which is so often espoused in this place-it has been espoused today by Senator Lewis, Senator Teague and Senator Baume-is beloved of all the conservatives in this place. It is what I call the gypsy principle. That principle is that only by covering the palm with silver does the patient appreciate the service that he or she is given, is the doctor-patient relationship preserved and can overuse be prevented. Of course, this principle is an insult to the medical profession. It is an insult to most doctors, asserting that they will operate effectively only if they are paid cash. These assertions are certainly not backed by the evidence. In surveys done in 1977, published in 1978 and presented in this Parliament, it was shown that the number of patient attendances to doctors who bulk billed was on average less than those who had charged this magic moiety.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can you tell me who mentioned that in his speech?

—I can tell the honourable senator; it was Senator Lewis, Senator Teague and Senator Baume. But we have another contortion of logic; we have the principle that it is terribly important that the patient pays this money, that he pays this cash so that he knows what it is about. Yet the same people complain that there is no gap insurance, that people should be able to insure against this gap-this precious moiety-which preserves all that is best in medicine in this country.
—And Queensland.

—And they defend vigorously the situation in Queensland where no cash changes hands. Yet we have this extraordinary business that we must have a patient moiety. To discipline the patients and to preserve the doctor's ability to relate to his patients we must have the handing over of cash but when it really counts the gap must be covered. Medicare will cover basic health insurance free from the complexities and worries of the current private health insurance scheme. It will be fairer to all Australians; it will contribute to the nation's health costs according to a person's ability to pay. This is in stark contrast to the scheme whereby the flat contribution rate which applies means that couples with an income just above the health care card limit must pay 7.2 per cent of their total income towards basic health cover, whereas a couple on $50,000 a year pay only 1.4 per cent of their income for exactly the same cover. I fail to see the equity in that and I do not believe that anyone who thinks about it can see any equity in that.

SPEECH.PARA: The usual red herrings were brought up by Senator Baume and others who referred to the national health service scheme as it exists in Britain. Senator Peter Baume quoted from some fairly obscure literature. I point out to the Senate that we are not introducing the British national health scheme. I point out to the Senate that what we are introducing in fact is a new system of health insurance in this country. Of course, the British health scheme has problems. If we are to give examples let us quote from some knowledgeable respectable journals in this country to get some clue about why the British health scheme is now in trouble. I will quote from the New England Journal of Medicine where the following comment appeared:

Whether the so-called monetarist policy of the Thatcher Government is considered to be harsh or just realistic may depend on one's own political viewpoint but it has undoudtedly had a profound effect on the national health service, the universities and their medical schools and research activities. Even before the economic recession became serious, the NHS authorities were subject to rigid budgetary limits and because of the high rate of inflation many authorities have found that in real terms their budgets have been reduced. In short, this means that any difficulties being experienced by the national health service have in fact been the deliberate result of the British Government's decision to reduce allocations to the national health service in real terms.

It is wrong to claim in the way that Senator Peter Baume did that the problems of the British national health scheme are in fact inherent in the system; they are the result of a system which is common throughout European countries but has been administered by a conservative government, a conservative government determined to bring it down.

Senator Baume also referred to the significant new tax on income with the Medicare levy. He considers that the levy will rise as the inadequacy of funding emerges. I point out that this was introduced and debated as though the introduction of a levy were something new in this country. I remind the Senate- it should not be forgotten-that despite the fact that the attempt by the Labor Government in 1975 to introduce a levy was defeated by Senator Baume and his colleagues in this place, it was the Fraser Government which followed that Labor Government and which introduced a levy of 2.5 per cent. The reason the levy was so high was that the Fraser Government allowed at the same time opting out to private insurance in this country. A Medicare levy of one per cent of taxable income is a realistic levy in a universal scheme because all persons earning income above the threshold will be required to pay the levy. In addition, despite the frenzied effort of those honourable senators opposite to discredit the cost estimates of Medicare which have been available for a considerable time , they have not been able to find any specific area of criticism.

I remind this House about the hidden tax the Fraser Government introduced in 1981 by replacing half tax indexation with the health insurance rebate which meant that only those who had expensive health insurance were eligible to obtain any tax advantage at that time. That is taxation by stealth; that is increasing the burden on people by stealth.

We have also heard in various speeches, as is to be expected with an election coming up in Queensland, comments in respect of that State which particularly relate to the Medicare levy. Senator Baume said that Queenslanders would be paying the levy for something which they now receive at no cost at all. On this occasion, apparently Senator Baume believes in the free lunch after all. It is true that Queenslanders now have a free hospital system. It is free at the point of service. But as we have been reminded by those honourable senators opposite, someone has to pay. Quite clearly those who are paying are Queenslanders. This Government, in introducing the levy, has recognised that Queenslanders may be overlevied if there was no adjustment to Queensland other than the Medicare compensation granted to that State. We recognised this in negotiations with Queensland. Therefore, Queensland has been offered compensation of an amount of $35m in a full year in recognition of this problem. That matter has been debated in this place and another place at great length since those discussions took place.

Senator Baume again had the gall to raise the spectre of the Government setting out to take something away from pensioners. Senator Teague, of course, shed crocodile tears on this point. I must say that only the Opposition could put forward an argument which would say that because prices generally fall particular groups in the community are worse off.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prices will not be falling.

—Let me say that we heard nothing of this in relation to the health insurance changes in November 1978 which deflated the consumer price increases on which the November 1979 pension adjustment was based. We heard nothing about it at that time. Pensioners in this country need not be concerned that this Government will forget them in the way the previous Government forgot them at that time. In addition, the wages and salaries pause introduced by the Fraser Government with the sole objective of reducing pressure on prices, and therefore the CPI, also had a similar effect. I am sure that pensioners in fact will welcome the new arrangements which will reduce pressure on prices and remove the stigma of their having to produce a pensioner card to get medical and hospital services in the future.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Baume was then moved to raise a whole series of problems in relation to prevention and community health services. I point out to this Senate that, in contrast with the previous Government, this Government has made available to State health authorities an additional $20m in a full year for new and additional community health services. It will be a matter for the States to decide how this money might best be spent in accordance with their assessment of priorities. I hardly see the relevance of that argument to the introduction of the health insurance scheme.

Senator Haines, however, made an excellent and more constructive contribution to this debate, as one would expect from someone who has in fact taken an active part in negotiations on behalf of various people in the last few months. Senator Haines has taken a constructive approach rather than the destructive approach of my colleague from Tasmania. Senator Haines, of all the speakers from the other side of the House, recognised that the Bill was concerned about the payment of health care, that it aimed to improve access to health services and that it particularly aimed to produce access to health services for those who could not get health insurance now because they could not afford it. Senator Haines pointed out that the Government does have a mandate for health insurance arrangements and the associated levy for what is called Medicare. She pointed out, just in case honourable senators opposite have forgotten, that, as evidenced by the last election and at polls since, Australians generally agree with the introduction of this levy.

Senator Haines also referred to the extensive consultations which she and others have had with the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett). The Minister, in seeking consensus and in realising the sorts of problems of dislocation that were being raised by the Opposition, recognised that there was in fact a need to look at the difficulties faced by the people who would possibly be declared redundant, to look at the difficulties faced by some people in certain sections of the community and to look at the specific case of the closed funds and the special funds which exist in Tasmania, as all Tasmanians would know. In fact, it is as a result of that consultation right across the spectrum of people concerned with the provision of health care in this country that in fact this legislation is being introduced with the general acceptance of the whole community.

Senator Haines made specific reference to a Medibank advertisement which she had been told about and which apparently occurred in Western Australia, contrary to the commitment of the Minister on this matter. I have not seen the advertisement nor have I been able to get hold of a copy of it. I am informed that certainly no such advertising has been authorised by Medibank management and that in accordance with the Minister's commitment no joint advertising of the type which is alleged to have occurred will occur in the future.

Senator Walters made the usual contribution she makes to these sorts of debates . She did not add much that was new to what we have heard her say over the years in this place. But she did raise a matter of significance in relation to Tasmania and in so doing berated Senator Tate and any other Tasmanian senator from this side of the House who happened to be around at the time. The basis of her comments was highly selective quotes from letters from the Tasmanian Minister for Health, which basically come down to a shopping list of items in an attempt to blackmail the Commonwealth into increasing its already generous offer from 1 February 1984. It is the sort of approach that we have become used to from the Tasmanian Government at the moment. The most significant document which Senator Walters mentioned was the communique issued on behalf of the heads of Government, including the Tasmanian Premier, following the Premiers Conference which said:

The Heads of Government agreed on the revised proposals for Medicare as outlined by the Minister for Health in the Premiers Conference, including the basis for compensation payments to each of the States as outlined by the Minister.

The document referred to was entitled 'Medicare Program: Financial Proposals by the Commonwealth, 30.6.83', and it was circulated at the Premiers Conference. That document made specific references to South Australia and Tasmania as follows:

South Australia and Tasmania to be reimbursed for both in-patient and out- patient revenue losses on the basis of the existing cost-sharing agreement arrangements being terminated and their replacement by identified health grants equal in value to the cost-sharing grants applicable at the 1st February 1984 plus revenue loss adjustment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Now read a copy of the Premier's letter.

—Senator Walters has the gall to tell us that the Premier agreed to this only because of some conversation he had with the Treasurer (Mr Keating) . I also inform Senator Walters that on 14 July there was a Health Ministers Conference about these arrangements and that the Tasmanian Minister for Health had nothing to say. Like his Premier, he had nothing to say until he got back to Tasmania, where, for local consumption, he started to berate. There can be no doubt on the part of anyone reading those documents that Tasmania accepted the Commonwealth proposals put forward at the Premiers Conference, as indicated in the final communique of that conference.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to mention one other matter that Senator Walters raised. I think it is important to point out that in dealing with the facts she is somewhat careless at times. That was demonstrated by her quoting incorrectly the basic medical hospital contribution rates for the Medical Benefits Fund in Tasmania. She quoted them at $9.70 per family per week, rather than the actual cost of $11.92. It is that sort of carelessness with the facts that shows that she and her colleagues in the Tasmanian State Government are playing politics with what is, in essence, a very important matter for the people of Australia.

Similarly, with jobs, Senator Teague, in great detail, claimed a 5,000 job loss to the voluntary health insurance funds. He was quoting figures which were preliminary figures before the negotiations with the voluntary health funds, before the Minister pointed out that they would be able to diversify, and before the Minister and the health funds got together about the preference for health insurance employees in the Health Insurance Commission. No health insurance organisation in this country at present would quote the outrageous figures that Senator Teague quoted. In fact, there will be a smooth changeover and a smooth introduction of this legislation. It will be smooth because of the care with which the Minister for Health has negotiated with the various organisations.

Senator Haines raised the question of private hospital categorisation. It is worth while clarifying that for Senator Haines and others in this place. The three categories to be introduced are based on services provided and types of patients treated in those hospitals, and the Comonwealth subsidy of $20, $30 and $40 a day is according to category. The fund benefits of $80, $100, and $120 per day will be based on the same categories. Therefore, we have totals of $100, $ 130 and $160 a day available from the basic hospital table alone. The initial draft guidelines about which Senator Haines talked were guidelines only, circulated for comments by the private hospitals and the States, with which the Minister is bound to consult under the Act.

Since then there have been discussions with both the private hospitals and the States, and the new criteria have been introduced. Suggestions by private hospitals have been sympathetically considered and will be further discussed at a meeting on 26 September. The revised guidelines will take into account the particular services provided by medical and psychiatric hospitals and the staffing levels that they provide. Regard will also be had to the level of maternity services provided at private hospitals, with rather less emphasis on surgery alone. The guidelines-this is important-will, of course, be tabled in the Senate and, therefore, they will be open for debate in this place. We believe that open government in this area and open discussion about the guidelines are important. Open discussion, we believe, will lead to a more rational and sensible system.

Senator Harradine raised a couple of matters which I will deal with now. Perhaps we can deal with them in greater length at the Committee stage. We will be monitoring the effects of the introduction of Medicare on public hospitals. We will be looking at the numbers of patients which those hospitals have and the loads with which they have to deal. As a result of that we will endeavour to increase the standard of facilities in our public hospitals, standards which are already high.

The problem of chiropractors, which was raised by Senator Harradine and Senator Harradine alone, has not been considered in the introduction of the health insurance scheme by this Government any more than it has been by previous governments. This scheme is about what one might call the traditional medical services. Rather than try to introduce a whole new element to the scheme, it was felt that it would be better to introduce the scheme initially for the traditional medical practitioners. One of the problems with chiropractors has always been-like everyone else in this place, I think, I have had discussions with them-in defining just what is a chiropractor and working out just who is and who is not accepted as a chiropractor in this community. I know that in some States there is registration; in others, there is not. What the chiropractors really need to do is get their act together in this regard.

Senator Harradine's problem with the issuing of cards to 14-year-old girls in particular has been debated in this place and considered by an Estimates committee in recent times. The simple fact of the matter is that the provision of these cards will not be necessarily widespread. It will not interfere with the laws of the States. In some of the States, if not all of the States, a 14- year-old may receive medical attention on going to a medical practitioner, and get it quite legally. If that is the case, that person is entitled, like any other citizen, to have the benefits of the Medicare system. However, we can go into that in more detail at the Committee stage.

I thank honourable senators for their contribution to the debate. I am sorry that those opposite cannot remove the blinkers from their eyes and cannot see that the introduction of a universal health insurance scheme, which is equitable to all and is based on people's ability to pay and not on people's wealth-a scheme which provides basic health care and access to health care for all citizens in this country who need it, whether they are chronically or acutely ill-is an important reform, a social reform which has been Australian Labor Party policy for as long as I and most of us have been members of the Labor Party. It was a reform introduced in 1974 and sabotaged in 1975. On this occasion, as we have not had the delay of a double dissolution and a joint sitting, it will be introduced, established, and I am sure accepted, by the whole community. I doubt whether we will hear much about the disbanding of Medicare in the Opposition's policy speech at the next election. I thank the Senate again. Let us proceed to the Committee stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I claim to have been misrepresented.
—Does the honourable senator wish to make a personal explanation?

—Yes. I respond briefly to two matters which were raised at the beginning of the summing up speech by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes). He alleged that I had argued in my speech that there was a particular inequity in both members of a two-income family paying the levy for Medicare. That was not my complaint. I did not complain about that whatsoever. Rather, I was drawing attention, when the costs of Medicare were being assessed, to the fact that many families with two incomes have been surprised to learn that both incomes will attract the levy. My concern was with the costs and the estimates of costs. Secondly, I did not in any way refer to a gypsy type of principle involving money by some magic passing from the palms of every individual to doctors in respect of the 15 per cent gap payment. Neither did I refer to such a principle, even in concept. My references to the gap-the 15 per cent of the medical fee to be paid-were made only with regard to the estimate of additional cost that would be incurred by those individuals and families in paying the gap. I saw no such magic in money passing across palms, as Senator Grimes alleged.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the words proposed to be left out (Senator Peter Baume's amendment) be left out.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Original question put:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Clauses 1 to 11-by leave-taken together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —This may be an appropriate occasion to state again the position which the Opposition has taken in its consideration of these Bills. We have opposed the second reading of the Health Legislation Amendment Bill and the Senate has now given that Bill a second reading. We have expressed our opposition to the principles of Medicare and that opposition remains. We have notified in another place, through our spokesman Mr Carlton, what our intentions would be in government in returning to a more appropriate system of health care delivery and financing. That has already been put on the record. At this stage in the debate, however, the Senate has the opportunity and the responsibility to exercise its review role in improving the legislation. It is our intention during the Committee stage to propose a number of amendments which we believe will be of assistance to the legislation and which will be important to be considered. We hope that honourable senators on all sides will take a reasonable view of the amendments which will be proposed.

SPEECH.PARA: I indicate that I will probably say a few words on particular clauses of the Bill which we oppose because they implement the provisions of Medicare but, having divided on the amendment to the second reading and on the second reading, we will make our opposition known and will not seek to divide on every clause all the way through the Committee stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that this is the only occasion on which I can bring up the situation of the Victorian Bush Nursing Association, the costs incurred by that Association, and the disadvantage it will be put under by this legislation. I ask the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) whether the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) has now met with representatives of the Victorian Bush Nursing Association, which he had not done prior to 14 September. It appears that at the time this Bill was being debated in the House of Representatives, when Mr Carlton informed the Minister of the figures, the Minister was unware of the disadvantage under which the Victorian Bush Nursing Association would be operating. I ask the Minister whether his colleague in the other place has now identified the problem of the Association and whether he intends to do anything about it.

—I assure Senator Walters that my colleague the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) was aware of the situation of the Victorian Bush Nursing Association. The matter had been brought up by our colleague the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Mildren), among others. At the moment there is no categorisation of these hospitals. I am informed that discussion is proceeding at the moment concerning the guidelines as they will affect the bush nursing hospitals which are in this unusual situation. To my knowledge, those discussions are proceeding satisfactorily and we hope to have resolved any difficulties, perceived or real, in the near future .
—Does that mean that the legislation will have to be altered?

—I can see no reason why the legislation should be altered under these circumstances. It is my understanding that in fact meetings on this matter were held as recently as yesterday. These hospitals are in a different situation from other hospitals, but the matter is in hand. The matter is understood by the Government and always has been understood between the Government, and there is between now and February, of course, to resolve that problem.

—If, as the Minister for Social Security has said, the problem has always been understood by the Government and the matter has been brought to the attention of the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett), why was the situation not gone into? Why did the meeting not take place before the legislation was brought down and before the Bill was debated in the House of Representatives? Why was the situation not fixed before the legislation was brought into the House of Representatives if the Minister knew right from the beginning that he was discriminating against this group of hospitals?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I point out to Senator Walters that the categorisation of hospitals is continuing. The guidelines have not been finalised. When the guidelines are finalised they will be brought into this place and we will be able to discuss them at that time. The matter she talks about refers not only to the bush nursing hospitals but also to other hospitals which have yet to be categorised. It is part of the process of the introduction of Medicare that that should go ahead. The difference, of course, is that under this system we will be able to look at those guidelines and discuss them. The Director-General of Health yesterday had discussions with representatives of the bush nursing hospitals about this very matter. They are aware that the Government is considering the matter. People in those districts are aware that the Government is considering that matter. I hope that Senator Walters is now aware of it.

SPEECH.PARA: Clauses agreed to.
Clause 12 (Entitlement to medicare benefit).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition opposes clause 12. Clause 12 is the clause which extends the Government contribution to medical insurance in Australia from 30c in the dollar to 85c in the dollar when the schedule fee is charged. It is thus the clause of the Bill which shifts substantially the role of government in the intervention in health care delivery in Australia. We believe that it extends very substantially the intrusion of government into the payment for health services. This has really been the subject of much debate during the second reading stage but this is--
—I thought you said you accepted the second reading vote.

—That will not stop us expressing our opposition. We are trying to take a reasonable and civilised approach to the debate and I think Senator Coates is not really assisting. I will make known our opposition at the appropriate places. If Senator Coates wishes us to start dividing, we will do so . At the moment it is not our intention to divide unnecessarily. As I say, this is one of the clauses which are central to the implementation of the Government' s Medicare scheme. It is one of the clauses which we oppose. I want to place that opposition on the record and indicate that the Opposition does not support this clause.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause agreed to.
Clauses 13 to 17-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 18 (Medicare benefit not payable in respect of certain medical expenses) .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —To clause 18 the Opposition wishes to move the first of the amendments which have been circulated. I have received advice that amendments 5 and 6 may need to be redrawn slightly. We have had advice from parliamentary counsel. When those redrafts are available I will circulate them. It has been suggested that we could improve them. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 11, clause 18, sub-clause (1), paragraph (b), after proposed new sub- section 17 (4), insert the following sub-section: ''(5) Sections 48 (other than paragraph (1) (a)), 49, 49A and 50 of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 apply in relation to guidelines under paragraph (4) (c) as if in those sections references to regulations were references to guidelines and references to a regulation were references to a guideline.''.

Clause 18 gives the Minister for Health the unfettered authority to alter or to cancel new or existing contracts governing the terms and conditions of employment between salaried or self-employed medical practitioners and recognised hospitals. It applies both to salaried doctors and recognised public hospitals and to private practising, self-employed medical practitioners and hospitals with whom they have some contractual arrangement. I understand that the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) has on some occasions expressed his concern about the private practice arrangements of medical practitioners in hospitals. Those arrangements-I did not refer to this matter during the second reading stage-which exist between salaried doctors and the State employing authorities are matters of State jurisdiction; they are part of the State health delivery system. But insofar as those doctors seek to recover insurance benefits there is , of course, a Commonwealth interest. The Minister has stated that his concern related to the use of 'diagnostic and some therapeutic services . . . where there is not usually any direct doctor-patient contact, where there is substantial scope for generating additional revenue, and where there is a significant technical content to the service which is provided by the hospital rather than the doctor'.

Some may find it difficult to follow exactly what the Minister was talking about. Those who are familiar with the operation of hospitals will know that the kind of services he was talking about relate mainly to diagnostic services, services such as radiology and pathology, and other services which are generated by the hospital. I agree with the Minister that there have been some elements of concern about the arrangements which have existed between doctors and the State hospitals which have employed them. I think it is appropriate that the matter be taken into consideration. It is appropriate that the public interest be looked at. But the Minister, on the ground that there is a problem, is now seeking the authority in this clause to make the payment of medical benefits by Medicare conditional upon his approval of the contract in each individual case entered into by the hospital and by the doctor. That may be all very well but there two points which concern us greatly.

The first point is that the Minister's determinations are not to be subject to any scrutiny of parliament, as most subordinate legislation and regulations are. That is not to say that we deny the Minister his capacity, as part of the Federal Executive, to make administrative decisions. Nor do we deny the Minister the right-if that is the Government's wish-to examine contracts. All we say is that it is not appropriate that that should be the case when there is no capacity for the Parliament to examine, as we examine other Executive decisions, whether the decision should stand or be disallowed. The Opposition is concerned that that capacity is missing from the provision before us.

We are also concerned, of course, that no right of appeal rests with the doctors if these decisions are made. The Opposition is concerned that the guidelines which are to be formulated by the Government in respect of the contracts are to be published in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette but that there is no reference to any capacity for parliamentary disallowance. It is for this reason that the Opposition seeks to amend clause 18 in terms of the amendment which I have moved. I just observe, because we have several examples of where the Opposition will be seeking to have certain decisions of the Minister made subject to parliamentary scrutiny, that the clause as it stands cuts across the work of the Senate of recent years. Over recent years the Senate has worked to limit the growth of ministerial discretion not subject to some later review by the Parliament. We have worked towards protecting the rights of individuals to review and to appeal Government decisions.

I am not saying that any decision by the Minister about a contract between doctor and hospital will be inappropriate. I have no reason to say that. All I am saying is that it is appropriate that there exist a mechanism by which the Parliament can maintain its capacity to examine and, if it wishes, to disallow a decision in relation to a contract. We are totally unconvinced by the response which the Minister for Health gave in another place. Dr Blewett attempted to explain away the interference by the Federal Government in the award conditions of these health professionals by saying that it was really just an agreement with State Health Ministers and that the State Health Ministers would be making the determinations in any case. I point out that we are talking about the payment of the Commonwealth medical benefit, which is a matter falling directly within the power and capacity of the Commonwealth. It is directly given to the Commonwealth as a constitutional responsibility. The payment of the Commonwealth medical benefit, which is a matter for the State, is a matter for direct determination by the Minister for Health. It is to be determined between the Minister for Health and the doctor concerned. It is entirely possible for a State to make an agreement with a doctor and for the Minister to determine that that particular contract will not be appropriate. It is not ultimately a matter for the State Health Ministers. It is very clearly a direct matter for the Commonwealth Minister, as it relates to the payment of the Commonwealth medical benefit. Because of that I believe it is appropriate that we move to accept the amendment I have moved. For those who heard the amendment and wondered why it was worded in the way it was, that is the standard kind of wording to bring these particular determinations within the provisions of the Acts Interpretation Act; that is, to bring them into a situation where they do become subject to scrutiny by the Parliament and disallowance by either House if so determined.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, the Opposition is moving six amendments tonight of which the amendment the Committee is now debating is the first. The Australian Democrats will be voting as a bloc on five of those six amendments. So far as I understand it, after discussions with my colleagues, we are not voting as a bloc on this one. I have considerable sympathy, as a member of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, for the point of view that Senator Baume is putting, as indeed does at least one of my colleagues, and certainly I will be supporting it. I am not, therefore, speaking at the moment on behalf of my party as a whole.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand that the guidelines formulated have been formulated following discussions with the States and I believe with certain visiting medical officers who are likely to be particularly affected-for instance, the radiologists. I understand also that the guidelines follow these sorts of lines: Visiting medical officers will be entitled to receive-the Minister can correct me if I get some of these figures wrong, but I think I have them right-up to 125 per cent of senior specialist salary without the hospital deducting anything for its facility fund. Between 125 and 150 per cent of senior specialist salary, I understand that the hospitals concerned will be deducting something like 20 per cent of the amount above 125 per cent and below 150 per cent for their facilities fund. Once the visiting medical officer is in receipt of 150 per cent or more of senior specialist salary the hospital will deduct 40 per cent of the amount above 150 per cent and 20 per cent of the amount between 125 and 150 per cent.

Those guidelines seem perfectly reasonable to me. Nevertheless, it does not alter the fact, I believe, that Senator Baume has a perfectly legitimate point when he states that he believes that some sort of parliamentary scrutiny should apply to these guidelines. But one wonders why, when we are talking about a State and Federal government agreed set of guidelines we are not giving the States the right to disallow. It may well be that they, too, would like to have the power of veto. If we get into that sort of position we are approaching the ludicrous. I just repeat that I speak for myself and not for my Party in supporting Senator Baume's amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise to the Committee that I have not been in the chamber or listening-
—It is our first amendment, Senator.
—I understand that; I have just been told. Whilst I have studied the matter-
—We are having a conscience vote. Are you?

—Yes, I am. I have studied the matter previously. I apologise to the Committee for not having heard the debate on this clause as I would like to have done. I indicate that, consistent with my view of the audit and control functions of this Parliament, I will be supporting the proposition that has been put forward.

— This position has arisen many times in this chamber over the years. I remember one occasion quite a long time ago when it arose just before the Senate went into recess some time in December. Indeed, at that stage Senator Cavanagh, who was one of the leading legal lights in the then Australian Labor Party Opposition, insisted that a Minister should not have powers that were not brought before the Parliament. It was not good enough for him then that decisions be gazetted. He said then-and we agreed with him; indeed the legislation was changed-that parliament should have the right to disallow any ministerial decision. This is something for which I have fought ever since I have been in this place. Senator Cavanagh certainly would not be allowing the Government to get away with just gazetting ministerial decisions. I know that he would be pushing for the right of parliament to disallow any ministerial decision. It is in agreement with this ideal that I believe the Government should be accepting the Opposition's amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does not agree with the Opposition's amendment largely because we believe that it is unnecessary. I do not think Senator Walters even knows what it is about. The guidelines-not the contracts-which the Opposition seeks to have tabled in this place are drawn up by agreement after consultation between the Minister and the State governments. The guidelines will incorporate the practices which are approved by the States. It is an agreement between the Federal Minister and the State governments. The contracts will not be brought in here and laid on the table of the Senate; the guidelines will be. We would have some interesting situations in hospitals if the guidelines were approved by the State Ministers and the Federal Minister and someone for some reason or another moved for their disallowance in this place and then 15 sitting days later-which may be three months later, after the contracts have been drawn up-the guidelines were disapproved. However, if the Opposition in its desire to make sure that it looks at every speck of legislation, at every guideline and at every regulation which is brought forward by the Minister under the new Medicare system insists on that happening and has the numbers to do so I cannot do much about it, but I think it is an unnecessary impediment.

SPEECH.PARA: On my reading of it, Senator Haines got her figures nearly right until she said that visiting medical officers will receive up to 125 per cent of salary without the hospital making any deductions for the facilities fund. But before that deductions are already made. I assume she is aware of that. Her figures are certainly right after that. She did not seem to have any trouble or worries with them so I will not go any further into them. We oppose the amendment because we do not see it as being necessary. We would have thought that in the States House co-operation between the Federal Minister and the Ministers of the States in establishing guidelines would probably have been enough.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Withers Sen The Rt Hon R.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that the proposition put up by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) is extraordinary if one believes that Parliament ought to be able to supervise the actions of the Executive. The Minister is saying that if a Minister of the Commonwealth and Ministers of the State governments get together they can therefore frustrate the parliaments of both the Commonwealth and the States to inquire into what those Ministers have done. I suppose that one of the problems of being here too long is that I can remember that when one of the first agreements on off-shore exploration was introduced into the parliament in 1966 or 1967 a Senate committee inquired into it for a number of years as a result of a motion put down by former Senator Wright. The worry of that committee was-I am not arguing health problems but philosophical ones-that because the Commonwealth and the States entered into mirror legislation concerning oil exploration off Australia the Ministers could enter into some agreement which was supervised by no one. Neither the Commonwealth Parliament nor the State parliaments had any discipline over the Ministers of either the Commonwealth or the States. This legislation is going down exactly the same track.
—Precisely what you did with companies and securities, Senator.

—I agree with the honourable senator. Merely because we were wrong is no excuse for the Government to be wrong. I am delighted that Senator Tate should interject and say that we were wrong over the securities legislation . I am one of those people who happen still to be a citizen rather than a politician. I am very wary of politicians getting together in some cosy agreement to frustrate the will of the citizen.

SPEECH.PARA: As an aside, Mr Chairman, if you do not mind my diverting for a moment, that is why I worry about this interchange of powers without a referendum; where politicians can get together and plot to change the distribution of the powers between the Commonwealth and the States. I am old-fashioned enough to believe that if powers are to be changed I want to vote in a referendum. I do not like Commonwealth and State Ministers getting together to decide on the balance of powers in Australia. I want a vote. As long as I sit in this place, I am not terribly attracted to the idea that Commonwealth and State Ministers can get together and come to some cosy arrangement over which neither I nor the State parliaments have any power of disallowance. Those who sit opposite prate enormously about civil rights, a Bill of rights and the rights of the individual -all those sorts of fancy things. But they are prepared to put in legislation one of their propositions so as to get into some cosy arrangement into which the Parliament cannot even inquire. That is the only reason I intervene. I know nothing about the technicalities, but I think I know enough to say that Commonwealth and State Ministers ought not to be able to come to some cosy arrangement which suits them without either of their parliaments having a right to disallow.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry that I awoke Senator Withers from his long slumber. I really am concerned! It is so long since I heard him make a speech that it is almost worth while. It was good stuff, but we are talking about guidelines concerning contracts between State hospitals and medical practitioners within those hospitals. We are talking about guidelines which are being discussed by State Ministers, by the Australian Medical Association and by the Minister for Health. We are not doing anything drastic such as the Jamison Commission of Inquiry into the Efficiency and Administration of Hospitals recommended by removing the right of private practice in hospitals. We are coming to an arrangement between the States and the Federal Government about the contracts for employment of specialists in those hospitals. If Senator Withers wants to make a great national and constitutional issue of this, fair enough. I just repeat: We do not support the amendment because we think it is unnecessary and believe it could in fact impede arriving at sensible contracts in this area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take only one moment to draw the attention of Senator Grimes to proposed new section 17 (4) (c) which contains the words which concern us at present. It simply says, in part:

SPEECH.PARA: if the Minister has, by instrument in writing published in the Gazette, formulated guidelines with which agreements under this section are to comply . . .
The explanatory memorandum, with respect to clause 18 of the Bill, states:
. . . unless the practitioner has entered into an agreement in a form approved by the Minister for Health . . .

The Minister for Social Security may be saying that agreements are made with the States. There is nothing in the legislation to say that they need to be made in that way. As the legislation is written and as the memorandum is presented, these are Executive acts entirely appropriate for the application of the disallowance power. When I was a government back bencher-Senator Walters will remember this-we had to go to our own Minister many times to try to make the same point and to insist that actions under this kind of legislation be made subject to parliamentary scrutiny. There is nothing in the legislation to require there to be an agreement between a State and the Commonwealth. There is nothing that would prevent a Minister simply making guidelines and publishing them in the Gazette. The Parliament would have no power to have any say about that. I think we should be supporting the principle of the Parliament having that reserve capacity.

TALK.START.PARA: — May I add that it was with former Senator Cavanagh's support that Senator Peter Baume and I fought this battle over many years. I am sure that Senator Grimes would agree that he also was pleased with that fight at the time. The principle is as applicable today as it was then.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not getting into a frenzy about this matter. The guidelines will be published in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette. The effect of a Minister behaving in the way that Senator Peter Baume mentioned would be to empty hospitals in the States of their diagnostic specialists in this case. I just think it is making far too much of a conspiracy theory of a thin end of the wedge argument to go on in the way that we are. I repeat: We find it unnecessary; but, as I say, we are not going to the wall over it.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the words proposed to be inserted (Senator Peter Baume's amendment) be inserted.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause agreed to.
Clauses 19 to 23-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clauses 24 to 27-by leave-taken together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —These clauses are another part of the Bill which, in another place, was the subject of a division. It is another part of the Bill which we oppose. The Opposition's concern about these clauses of the health legislation is that they relate to the bulk billing provisions of Medicare. Also, one of the clauses relates to the decision to remove from private health insurance funds the right to offer to pensioners the payments of their benefits when doctors do not bulk bill. In those circumstances pensioners are required to recover 85 per cent of the schedule fee through a private insurance fund acting as an agent of the Government. We believe that both of the provisions which I have mentioned are undesirable. We think that they are not to the advantage of people. The sacking of the private health insurance funds from this function will not assist pensioners in those circumstances where their medical practitioners bill them directly.

SPEECH.PARA: We reiterate our concern about some of the principles contained in these clauses which underpin the Medicare measure. I do not want to reiterate the arguments made during the second reading debate. But I say again that it is within these clauses that it is appropriate to mention our concern for the effects upon employment in the private health insurance funds which will follow the adoption of these clauses of the Bill. The Government professes its concern for the unemployed and preaches jobs, jobs, jobs. How can it take these measures which will result in a net loss in employment? We might argue about the numbers, but there will be a net loss in employment.

TALK.START.PARA: —You did not argue last week. You said 5,000.
—I do not mind whether one job is involved. Any net loss in employment is undesirable. These clauses are the appropriate place to state once again our opposition and our concern.

—The Minister for Social Security ( Senator Grimes) referred in his summing up to the fact that the net loss in employment was somewhat less than 2,500, and he made such a particular point of being specific about figures. What is his information to the Committee as to the extent of the net loss in jobs as a result of this change?

—The net loss, as I think even Senator Teague will agree, is difficult to assess. It is certainly not the 2,500 that he talks about. Estimates from discussions between Dr Blewett and his colleagues and the voluntary health insurance organisations put it at a possible 1,500 at the most. The situation is that if one is introducing a centralised health insurance scheme which is in fact more efficient and is aimed at providing the access we are talking about, of course there will be a net loss of people. I remind honourable senators of the provisions that were made to assist the voluntary health insurance funds to diversify and therefore maintain staff and to assist the staff of health insurance organisations to get employment. During the second reading debate I argued vigorously with Senator Teague his claim of a total loss of 5,000, with which not even the voluntary health organisations agree, and the net loss.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak only very briefly. This clause is the basis of the whole legislation. The Government is trying to push through nationalisation of both doctors and the funds. Senator Tate groans every time I say it, because every time I say it the people of Australia are going to realise that this is really the Government's intention. If it were not, Dr Blewett and other people in the other place would not be urging doctors to bulk bill. A profession is nationalised when its members are totally paid by the Government. Once doctors bulk bill they are nationalised. Once their salary or income is totally paid by the Government they are nationalised. There is no other way of putting it. Senator Gietzelt assured us today that the most economical way to run the system was to have one big fund. He said that the proliferation of funds at the moment should be done away with. If that is not nationalisation of the funds, I do not know what is.

SPEECH.PARA: I proved today by my speech and the information I tabled that over the years Medibank Private has been unable to compete with the private funds and that its administrative costs have been greater than those of the private funds. This was the case from 1978 to 1982. Indeed, the administrative costs of Medibank Private are still greater than those of the private funds. Until this year, Victoria was the only State in which Medibank Private made any sort of a profit. Medibank Private still cannot compete in any of the States in which the private health funds are flourishing.

This clause is nothing short of nationalisation. It is the basis of the whole Medicare health legislation. I draw the attention of the Committee and those listening to this debate to the fact that the Government has decided to nationalise the doctors and the private health funds. If this legislation passes tonight we will have nationalisation in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to drag out this debate at great length. One must answer the tedious nonsense that Senator Walters has gone on with.
—Give us some of your tedious nonsense.

—I remind Senator Withers and Senator Walters that under this legislation and under the new Medicare proposals the doctor has the choice of whether or not to bulk bill. It is not anybody else's choice. It is absolute nonsense to equate that with nationalisation. It is the sort of nonsense that we have to put up with from Senator Walters, who airs her prejudices all over this place with great gusto every time she speaks. I answer again, as I did in the Estimates Committee hearing recently, Senator Walters's assertion that the management expenses of Medibank Private are higher than those of the other health insurance funds and that they have been rising. They have in fact been falling.
—I did not say they have been rising; I said they are higher.

—They are not higher. They were not higher last year and they are not higher this year. At the moment they are at 9.7 per cent. I think the good senator should go back to the Estimates Committee. If she does not believe the figures produced by the Department of Health in this place, the figures produced by the voluntary health funds, she should have questioned them at the Estimates Committee hearing. It was her duty to do so, but she did not. She sat mute. But she still parrots out this nonsense about the level of management expenses of Medibank Private.

SPEECH.PARA: Briefly, what we have introduced is a system of health insurance which provides accessibility to everybody in the community. It provides that they pay on the basis of their ability to pay. It still leaves the doctors with the ability to bulk bill or not to bulk bill, as they choose. It still leaves the system of fee for service. It still leaves the voluntary health funds with a function in the community. It still leaves our private hospitals intact. If that is the honourable senator's definition of 'nationalisation' I think she ought to buy herself a new dictionary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to make very briefly just three points refuting the absurd claims of Senator Walters that this clause of the Bill, or any part of the Bill, attempts to nationalise the provision of medical services to Australians. Firstly, it was a Labor government in 1946 which introduced a referendum which had the explicit effect of preventing civil conscription. It was placed in the referendum as part of a general bipartisan understanding that in fact doctors would not ever be conscripted or nationalised in Australia. As I said, that was put to the Australian people by a Labor government in a bipartisan spirit, and it makes the nationalisation that Senator Walters speaks of constitutionally impossible. So let us put that to one side.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, as Senator Grimes quite rightly put it, no doctor is compelled to bulk bill. As I said in my question at Question Time today, bulk billing will occur on a large scale only if it is made attractive enough to doctors in practice to do so, and to achieve that one will have to have a much more rapid response by the Health Insurance Commission to the payment of moneys to surgeries to keep the cash flow and proper remuneration coming to the doctors on a reasonable time span, not the some months of delay that occurs quite often these days. We received a reply that the Health Insurance Commission had given an undertaking to the Government that the turnaround would be within a fortnight of receipt of the bulk bills from the doctor's surgery. That is the way in which doctors will be attracted to make use of the bulk billing arrangements.

Thirdly, and linked to the absurd charge that we are nationalising medicine, is the question of doctor of choice that is always parroted. The fact is that under Medicare any Australian will be able to go to any general practitioner of his or her choice and seek an initial consultation, which is usually quite adequate treatment for some sort of illness. If the general practitioner then refers that person to a specialist, Medicare will cover the payments to that specialist. If diagnostic services of radiologists or pathologists are required, Medicare will cover that. If the person goes to a public hospital, that hospital will make an arrangement for the hospital doctor to look after that person in a ward which the hospital doctor and the hospital assess as adequate for the care of the patient.

If the patient then wishes to have a private doctor of choice in the hospital, of course the patient is perfectly free to do so. To cover the cost of doing so the patient may wish to enter into a private health insurance arrangement. There is no diminution of the right of doctor of choice under our proposals. The whole absurd allegation needs to be set at rest. Senator Grimes did it more than adequately. I simply felt compelled to rise to get my thoughts recorded in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —I now feel compelled to explain just where Senator Tate has gone wrong. Dr Blewett has said that the levy will provide the same cover as present basic hospital and medical contribution rates. That is not accurate. That is a distortion given to the people so that they think they will receive the same service. They will be covered for 85 per cent of the schedule fee; that is where the cover stops. They will be entitled to a bed in a public hospital-if, as has been suggested, they can get one. But they will only be able to be treated by the resident doctor on duty. They will not have the opportunity to choose a doctor, as they have at present. They will be treated only by the doctor on duty. It will not be the same situation as at present. At present, with basic hospital insurance, people can go into a public hospital and be treated by the doctor of their choice. It is the distortion that the Minister has tried to put across and that Senator Tate has now tried to back.
—The debate is running rather wide of what is in clauses 24 to 27. I would be grateful if further contributors to the debate stuck to the clauses.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take up the point made by Senator Tate and Senator Grimes. It is inevitable that the great majority of doctors will bulk bill. They will be forced by the legislation to do so.
—Choice, Senator.
—Come on. The average person follows his pocket. If one has a choice between-
—Are you talking about the finance committee of the Western Australian branch of the Liberal Party?

—I am sorry, but I do not see the connection. If one has the choice of paying absolutely nothing or paying the 15 per cent difference, and one gets the same service, inevitably one will go to the doctor who bulk bills. As the process matures, and doctors who are bulk billing attract the great majority of patients, other doctors will be intimidated and forced by economic circumstances to follow suit and also bulk bill. Of course, the legislation is perfectly designed that way. It does not allow cover for the gap of 15 per cent. It is designed that way to ensure that the private funds suffer and that the doctors are forced to bulk bill. It may not be within the definition of what the Government understands to be nationalisation, but it heads very much in that direction. It will destroy the private funds and will remove the choice of a doctor to bulk bill because doctors who do not bulk bill will not get patients.

SPEECH.PARA: Clauses agreed to.
Clauses 28 to 30-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clauses 31 to 39-by leave-taken together.

TALK.START.PARA: —These clauses provide very broadly for approval of the categorisation of private hospitals. I believe my colleague Senator Walters has referred already to the plight which faces the Bush Nursing Association. She was not sure whether these were the appropriate clauses. It is in fact covered under these clauses. The points which my colleague made about that Association and its concerns are very germane to the problems which may be faced by private hospitals in Australia. They represent a further development of Commonwealth bureaucratic control into the private hospital system. We are concerned about what the effects of some of this categorisation will be upon the viability of some of these hospitals. I simply say that the network of private hospitals is essential in some areas to pick up the inadequacies in the available public bed supply. If some of these hospitals, through inappropriate categorisation, are not able to continue in existence it just may be the public that suffers. So the Opposition has concerns about clauses 31 to 45. But in talking to clauses 31 to 39, I make those general points and indicate our concern and opposition to those clauses.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to clause 38 and draw attention to its provisions. That clause is headed, 'Agreements with States and Northern Territory for provision of hospital services'. Clause 38 provides that:

SPEECH.PARA: Section 30 of the Principal Act is repealed.
Sub-clause (2) provides that:

An agreement between the Commonwealth and South Australia or Tasmania that was in force immediately before 1 February 1984 under section 30 of the Principal Act ceases to have effect upon that date, except in so far as that agreement relates to the provision of hospital services before that date.

The background to this has been referred to already by my colleague Senator Walters this afternoon. It arises out of provisions which were made in relation to tax sharing and health grants for the States and agreements with the State of Tasmania in particular. This is provided for in the States (Tax Sharing and Health Grants) 1981, section 23 of which is entitled, 'South Australia or Tasmania may elect to terminate cost sharing agreement'. Section 23 provides:

If, at any time before 1 July 1985, the Premier of South Australia or the Premier of Tasmania elects, by writing under his hand furnished to the Prime Minister, that this section should apply to that State, the regulations may make provision-

The section goes on to set out in detail the termination of an agreement referred to in section 30 of the principal Act. I hope that Senator Grimes might be able to follow this through because I think it is quite important that he does so. I wish to draw his attention to section 23 of the States (Tax Sharing and Health Grants) Act of 1981, which provides that if a State-South Australia or Tasmania-elects to terminate a cost sharing agreement it may do so by writing under the hand of the Premier of that State, furnished to the Prime Minister. That is the clear intention of how provisions such as the subject matter of clause 38 of the Health Legislation Amendment Bill would be dealt with.
