In relation to that clause I would like to quote from some of the correspondence which has already been tabled. I think it sets out the fact that certainly there has not been any writing under the hand of the Premier of Tasmania indicating that Tasmania elected to terminate the cost sharing agreement. Further than that , there is a state of total disagreement in relation to this matter. The first letter to which I wish to refer-and I will do so as briefly as I can-is a letter of 13 July 1983 from the Tasmanian Minister for Health to the Commonwealth Minister for Health. On page 3 of that letter the Minister in Tasmania says:

Finally I must express my dissatisifaction at the lack of detail provided to date to enable this State to make an informed judgment as to whether or not it should remain under cost sharing arrangements and whether the compensatory grants under Medicare are adequate. Therefore I request that you give these matters your urgent attention. Clarification is vital to Tasmania before any final decision can be made.
I emphasise the last few words: 'Clarification is vital to Tasmania before any final decision can be made'.

TALK.START.PARA: —What date is that letter?

—It is dated 13 July 1983. I have just read out the final two paragraphs of that letter. In particular I draw attention to the final sentence. The reply to that letter is dated 28 July and the first paragraph identifies the difference between the two Ministers. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Thank you for your telex . . . concerning various aspects of the Commonwealth's offer to the States on Medicare which was accepted at the Premiers' Conference.

The Commonwealth Minister is saying that things were accepted at the Premiers Conference and the State Minister, in his letter, says that he wants further information before he can make a final decision in relation to Tasmania. There is a further letter of 16 August 1983 from the State Minister for Health, Mr Cleary, to the Federal Minister for Health, Dr Blewett. In the letter Mr Cleary states:

I also believe that this error has occurred due to your assumption in reporting to the Premiers' Conference from the Special Health Ministers' Conference, that all States had agreed to the introduction of the Medicare arrangements, and that the two cost-shared States would move to the same arrangements as the other States.

This assumption by yourself was, and still is, fundamentally incorrect. All that Tasmania has ever indicated has been a willingness to examine any proposals put forward for consideration, to discontinue the Cost-Sharing Agreement prior to its expiry date of 30th June, 1985.
The concluding paragraph of that letter states:
In conclusion, I would again confirm that Tasmania is looking to the Commonwealth Government to put forward a firm proposal for the Cost-Sharing Agreement to be discontinued-

Again it is quite clear that when this letter was written there was no agreement . Tasmania is saying that it wants information. It is continuing to say that. It is also saying that there was certainly no agreement, that the Federal Minister has a fundamental misinterpretation. The reply to that letter-almost a month later; a rather crucial month-is dated 14 September 1983 and has received some continuing misconception. It states:

First let me say that I am surprised and disappointed at the content of your letter. Until receipt of your letter, I was in no doubt that all States had accepted the Commonwealth's proposition to move to Medicare block grant funding from 1 February 1983.

I do not know how the Federal Minister could have said that in the light of preceding correspondence including, in particular, the letter of 13 July from Mr Cleary to Dr Blewett which made it quite clear that on 13 July there was no agreement. The letter states:
Clarification is vital to Tasmania before any final decision can be made.
The final paragraph of the letter of 14 September by Dr Blewett to Mr Cleary goes on to state:
I reiterate that, in the Commonwealth's view, a firm offer to move from cost sharing to the Medicare block grant funding arrangements has been made by the Commonwealth, and accepted by Tasmania.

The Minister's assertion is that the offer has been accepted by Tasmania. At this stage I refer again to the requirements in the legislation that an election to terminate the agreement must be under the hand of the Premier of Tasmania. So let us see what the Premier of Tasmania said in a letter dated 15 September 1983 to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). In the second paragraph on page 2 the Premier states:

The assumption that Tasmania has agreed to move to the same arrangements as the other States is not correct. All that Tasmania has ever indicated has been a willingness to examine any proposals put forward for consideration to discontinue the cost sharing agreement prior to its expiry date of 30th June, 1985.
Up to the present time there has been no formal or specific proposal put forward by your Government to:
(a) discontinue the cost sharing agreement; or
(b) quantify the proposed amount of any grant to replace it.
Rather, there has only been general discussion on the options.
The letter goes on to state that the Tasmanian Government would:
seek deferral of consideration of Clause 38 . . . and an early reply on the matters raised in our recent meeting in Hobart.

The Premier is referring to the discussions which took place between the Prime Minister and the Premier in Hobart at the end of August. He also refers to the reason why he agreed to the communique. Senator Walters has already quoted from the communique and I do not propose to quote it again in detail. I simply say that the State Premier said that he received an assurance from the Treasurer, Mr Keating, as to what was the meaning of the communique. He reiterates that there has been no agreement. He concludes by saying:
The Tasmanian Government has been co-operative in its discussions to facilitate the introduction of Medicare and feels it deserves a similar spirit of co- operation in return.
Consideration interrupted.

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Chairman do now leave the chair and report to the Senate.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: The Chairman having reported accordingly-

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.
